DOC.HEAD: Drought Brings High Fire Risk to Pogo's Home Swamp
DOC.TEXT: Pogo's home swamp is so dry that overcrowded alligators are starting to eat each other. A summer drought has turned the Okefenokee Swamp into a tinderbox, with water levels at their lowest in 20 years, said Don Perkuchin, manager of a 396,000-acre national refuge in the swamp. Fire danger and a wildlife crisis forced the refuge's closure to fishing enthusiasts and boaters. ``A lot of the canoe trails have no water,'' Perkuchin said. ``We're very dry and it's been a cumulative effect over the last decade. What it's going to take is a major tropical system to dump a 5- or 10-inch rain, or a long period of substantial rain to turn things around.'' Okefenokee Swamp, encompassing about 700 square miles mostly in southeast Georgia, is the real-life wetland the serves as the fictional home of comic strip character Pogo, created by late cartoonist Walt Kelly. Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge workers are using a helicopter to spot small fires, most sparked by lightning, Perkuchin said. ``We've had lightning strikes and we've had to go out and dump water on those,'' he said in a recent phone interview from his Folkston office. A fire discovered July 7 burned 4,500 acres of swamp land before it was doused. ``If things continue to stay dry, the fire hazard can get worse,'' Perkuchin said. Much of Georgia has been plagued by drought since June. Farmers have suffered up to $350 million in crop losses and some communities in the Atlanta area have had to restrict water use. Bill Cribbs, a biology professor at Valdosta State College who has made a lifelong study of the swamp, said the crisis is hitting wildlife. ``Younger gators are being eaten by other gators,'' he said. ``Fish resources are really taking a beating both from consumption by other animals and reduced habitat. A lot of the bird life you'd normally see, you just don't have around the swamp.'' The Suwannee River, one of two rivers that originate in the swamp, is almost dry, Cribbs said. ``It's not 6 inches deep in some places and you have to drag the boat,'' he said, adding that September and October are usually the swamp's driest months, followed by a three-month wet season that typically begins in December. ``I'm expecting it to get much drier before it gets better, unless we have a hurricane,'' he said. Alligators feeding on each other might actually be a good thing, he said. ``When you have a drought period and all the water recedes to these small areas, the alligators eat turtles, snakes, smaller alligators and even the raccoons that come to feed,'' he said. ``If they didn't eat their own population, there'd be nothing to hold the (alligator) population in check.'' Jimmy Spikes, assistant manager of Okefenokee Swamp Park near Waycross, said his park is still able to offer guided 25-minute boat tours, but had to cancel its two-hour tours deep into the swamp because of low water. Attendance is down because many tourists assume that all boat trails are closed, Spikes said, adding that the park featuring wildlife exhibits, snake shows and historical attractions usually draws up to 125,000 visitors a year. The swamp is home to more than 25 species of birds, including the sand hill crane and the endangered red cockaded woodpecker. Other residents include black bears, armadillos, at least two types of rattlesnakes, water moccasins and endangered eastern indigo snakes.

DOC.HEAD: Earth Heating Up Faster, International Scientific Investigation Says
DOC.TEXT: The Earth is heating up faster than previously documented and it is imperative that nations agree to reduce gases responsible for global warming, say scientists at a conference on climactic change. ``We face warming trends faster than at any time in 10,000 years,'' Mostafa K. Tolba, head of the U.N. Environment Program, said Monday in an opening speech outlining the results of a two-year international climate study. The conclusion that the Earth is heating by one-third of a degree Celsius each decade is among the conclusions of a draft document being debated at the four-day conference. About 300 government officials, lawyers and scientists from 70 countries are hoping to adopt a final report that would be a basis for United Nations action on fighting the ``greenhouse effect.'' The United States, represented by a 25-person delegation, has objected to some preliminary conclusions of the report, which was prepared by 1,000 atmospheric experts from industrialized and developing countries. In the past, U.S. officials have resisted a worldwide ceiling on emissions of carbon dioxide, the gas that scientists believe causes 60 percent of the ``greenhouse effect.'' Increasing levels of carbon dioxide are believed to trap heat from the sun, gradually warming the planet. The United States produces more carbon dioxide than any country, and 75 percent of all ``greenhouse'' gases are emitted by the Western industrialized nations. President Bush is among leaders calling for more exact measurements of the effects of carbon dioxide and precise predictions of the result of emission reduction before he would consider mandatory ceilings. The United States, the Soviet Union and Japan are the major industrialized countries which have not imposed voluntary ceilings on carbon dioxide production within their borders. The preliminary draft report by the scientists says emissions resulting from human activities are substantially increasing concentration of carbon dioxide and other ``greenhouse'' gases in the atmosphere. Tolba called for immediate negotiations on a treaty providing controls of carbon dioxide emissions. G.O.P. Obashi, secretary-general of the World Meteorological Organization, said, ``To solve the problem of `greenhouse' gases requires the industrialized countries to change their over-consuming ways. ``It also requires that development in the less industrialized world goes forward in a sustainable manner,'' he said. ``And this will require a large flow of assistance, both financial and technological, from North to South.'' The four-day conference in Sundsvall, 240 miles north of Stockholm, is expected to make specific recommendations on what the world should do about climate change. A second World Climate Conference will follow in Geneva in October, and a Framework Convention of Climate Change is scheduled in Washington, D.C. in February.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Up, Dollar Sharply Lower
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rallied for the third consecutive trading day today, while the dollar closed sharply lower. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 569.00 points, or 2.26 percent, to close at 25,710.76. The index gained 976.00 points Monday, following a 428.13-point gain last Friday. Dealers attributed the Nikkei index's gain to an overnight advance on Wall Street, declining oil prices and the yen's appreciation against the dollar. ``Share prices are recovering almost across the board,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, an analyst with Daiwa Securities. Since the Middle East crisis erupted after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Nikkei index had lost a total of 6,239.87 points, or 20.23 percent, as of last Thursday. Suzuki said a decline in the nation's interest rates, though marginal, also provided a favorable factor to the stock market. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond closed at 82.68 points, up from Monday's close of 82.54. The yield stood at 8.190 percent, down from 8.225 percent. The dollar closed at 143.20 yen, down 1.60 yen from Monday's close of 144.80 yen. After opening at 143.55 yen, the currency ranged between 142.95 yen and 143.55 yen. Currency dealers said the dollar remained weak throughout the day because of falling oil prices and traders' perceptions that tensions have eased in the Middle East. ``The yen-selling factor is dwindling because of the decline in crude oil prices,'' said Masahiro Sahara, a dealer with Industrial Bank of Japan. Persian Gulf crude oil prices were below late Monday New York levels in Tokyo today. Traders said reports that Iraq has pulled its troops back from Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia, and that OPEC will allow its members to exceed their quotas during the Mideast crisis have caused the market to weaken further. Dubai Fateh crude for October delivery was notionally valued at about $24.80-$24.90 a barrel, down from $25.04 level late Monday in New York. Monday's Asian level was about $29.45. United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar is scheduled to meet with with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz this week to discuss the Gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Government Finally Ready to Announce Assistance in Gulf Crisis
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan is nearing completion of a package to assist the multinational blockade of Iraq, and it will include sending medical personnel and financial assistance to the Middle East, government officials said today. A Foreign Ministry official said the package, expected to be announced on Wednesday, will include assistance for the multinational force arrayed against Iraq and aid to Middle East countries suffering economic hardship because of the blockade, according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. While the United States has poured tens of thousands of troops into Saudi Arabia to halt further aggression by Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Tokyo has been slow to decide on further measures beyond its participation in the global boycott on trade with Baghdad. Government officials have been promising ``unprecedented steps'' to punish Iraq, but have been slow to respond because of debate over the legality of sending military units to the Gulf and of providing the U.S.-led naval blockade of Iraq with direct financial aid. The Japanese constitution adopted after World War II bars the use of force in settling international disputes. Tokyo also is concerned about the safety of the more than 450 Japanese nationals still in Iraq and Kuwait, including about 20 who were whisked away from their Baghdad hotel to undisclosed destinations. A government source, speaking on condition he not be identified further, said Tokyo is ``very likely'' to send a medical team of up to 100 people to Saudi Arabia to help care for refugees in the crisis. Japan also plans to use civil aircraft to transport non-military material and food for the multinational force, the source said. The government is expected to charter two cargo planes from Japan Airlines, one source said. ``Transportation of military personnel and weapons is acceptable according to our interpretation of our domestic laws,'' said a senior government source, also speaking on condition of anonymity. ``However, there are difficulties to ask a commercial airline company to carry lethal and heavily military products.'' Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama returned Saturday from a tour of the Middle East in which he assessed the needs of Oman, Jordan, Egypt, Turkey and Saudi Arabia. While government officials have declined to estimate how much money Tokyo will offer, the assistance required by the region's countries could run into the billions of dollars.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: A PMs separate on Vaughan as a0456.
DOC.TEXT: Blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan, a two-time Grammy winner, died Monday in a helicopter crash at age 35. Vaughan, who had overcome drug and alcohol problems, gained popularity in the mid-1980s with his guitar jamming and blues sound, borrowed from such music legends as B.B. King. Vaughan toured this summer with blues singer Joe Cocker, and was to release a new record in September with his brother Jimmie, another well-known musician who formed The Fabulous Thunderbirds band. Vaughan had a platinum album with Double Trouble in ``Couldn't Stand the Weather,'' released in 1984. That same year, he won a Grammy for best traditional blues recording for the song ``Texas Flood.'' He won a 1990 Grammy in the contemporary blues category for ``In Step.''

Canadian novelist and short-story writer Morley Callaghan, who mixed with Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, James Joyce, Ezra Pound and other literary figures in Paris, died Saturday at age 87. The cause of death was not disclosed. In 1928, ``Strange Fugitive,'' the first of his more than 20 novels, was published. His novel ``The Loved and the Lost'' won Canada's 1952 Governor General's Award. Callaghan was also nominated for a Nobel Prize in literature. His other novels include ``A Native Argosy,'' ``Now that April's Here,'' ``Stories,'' ``They Shall Inherit the Earth'' and ``The Many Colored Coat.''
DOC.HEAD: Bobby Brooks
DOC.TEXT: Bobby Brooks, a Los Angeles theatrical agent who represented many prominent musicians, died Monday in the helicopter crash that also claimed the life of blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan. He was 34. Brooks began his career in the mail room of International Creative Management in New York. He had worked for Creative Artists Agency for the last four years and was one of its leading music agents. His clients included Eric Clapton, whose bodyguard and a tour manager also died in the crash; Crosby, Stills & Nash, Edie Brickell, Jeff Beck, Pat Benatar, Jackson Browne and Dolly Parton. He also represented actress Whoopi Goldberg.

Robert Edmonds, a filmmaker, author and teacher, died Saturday of pneumonia at age 76. Edmonds was a radio reporter for the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. and made films for the National Film Board of Canada. He was the author of four textbooks and became associated in 1972 with Columbia College in Chicago. In 1981, he was selected as a Fulbright Senior Scholar and taught in Israel, Yugoslavia and Belgium. His books are ``Writing it Right,'' ``Script Writing for Audio Visual Media,'' ``Sights and Sounds and Cinema'' and ``Anthropology on Film.''

Sister Marie Barry, president of Emmanuel College in Boston from 1969 to 1975, died Saturday at age 80. The cause of death was not disclosed. After teaching at several high schools, the Roman Catholic nun joined the English Department at Emmanuel in 1939, became chairman of the department in 1952 and served as academic dean of the college from 1960 to 1969. Barry was director of continuing education at Notre Dame Academy in Hingham from 1975 to 1980 and taught advanced-placement English.

DOC.HEAD: Everybody In The Pool: It's Hot, Hot, Hot!
Iran Arrests 20 Opposition Members; More Arrests Likely
DOC.TEXT: About 20 members of an Iranian opposition group have been arrested for waging ``psychological warfare'' against Iranian officials and more arrests are likely, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Ali Fallahiyan, Iran's Minister of Security and Intelligence, told reporters Monday that those arrested were members of The Association for the Defense of the Iranian People's Sovereignty and Freedom Movement. He did not say when they were detained. The Freedom Movement, headed by former Iranian Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan, is the only visible opposition inside Iran. Bazargan, 83, was the first prime minister of the Islamic Republic after it was established in 1979 by the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. He is known to be a pious Moslem with a large following among Tehran's powerful merchant community. Eight members of the Freedom Movement were arrested in June after 90 followers signed a scathing open letter to President Hashemi Rafsanjani calling for the restoration of constitutional rights. A source at the time said the letter, which shook the government, called Bazargan the ``only voice of conscience inside Iran.'' Earlier this month, one of those arrested in June appeared on television reading a statement that said the group had been directed by the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency. Fallahiyan said Monday that confessions obtained from those arrested would lead to more being rounded up, according to IRNA, which was monitored in Nicosia. He said those arrested aimed to ``wage psychological warfare against the Islamic Republic officials'' by repeating information disseminated by ``counterrevolutionaries abroad'' and the Voice of America. ``Besides being linked to the outside world, they were involved in efforts to wage psychological warfare and create dissatisfaction among people,'' the minister was quoted as saying. He said Iran's security service had identified and crushed ``U.S. espionage networks'' in the country, IRNA said.

DOC.HEAD: Yen Batters Dollar; Gold Rallies in Europe
DOC.TEXT: The dollar took a beating from the Japanese yen today but rallied against most other currencies. Gold recovered from its Monday lows in New York, where it closed at $388.50 an ounce, but was well below Monday's levels in Europe. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 143.20 yen, down 1.60 yen from Monday's close of 144.80 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 143.10 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.5478 West German marks, up from 1.5423 _1.2768 Swiss francs, up from 1.2670 _5.1888 French francs, up from 5.1745 _1.7475 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7365 _1,145.00 Italian lire, up from 1,142.75 _1.1390 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1335 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9510, compared with $1.9505 late Monday in Europe. London's markets had been closed for a holiday on Monday. Currency dealers in Tokyo said the dollar remained weak throughout the day due to falling oil prices and traders' perceptions that tensions have eased in the Middle East. ``The yen-selling factor is dwindling because of the decline in crude oil prices,'' said Masahiro Sahara, a dealer with Industrial Bank of Japan. Peter Kane, chief corporate dealer at Credit Suisse in London, said good news over the weekend had helped the yen but had little impact on the dollar. ``The dollar isn't benefiting either from an easing or a heightening of tension in the (Persian) Gulf,'' said Tim Fox, Treasury economist at Midland Bank PLC in London. He said this highlights the fundamental weakness of the dollar and said it is ``well-entrenched in a bearish trend.'' Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $392.55 a troy ounce this morning, as trading resumed following a bank holiday. In Zurich, the bid price was $392.50, down from $401.00 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong closed at $392.59 per ounce, down $18.36 from Friday's closing price. The Hong Kong market was closed Monday for a holiday. Dealers noted that although the price had advanced in London Tuesday, most of the bounce was technical rather than driven by investment demand. One dealer in London said there was support on the downside at about $387 an ounce, and resistance at $394. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.94 a troy ounce, down from Friday's $5.14 but up nearly 6 cents from Monday's close in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Say Contra Courier Knew Risks When Plane Was Shot Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS typo in overline to read `Knew' sted `New'
DOC.TEXT: Contra courier Eugene Hasenfus, jailed in Nicaragua while the U.S. government disavowed knowledge of a clandestine rebel supply network, is due no damages because he knew the risks involved, a jury decided. The federal court jury on Monday denied damages to ruled Hasenfus, his wife and the family of pilot Wallace Sawyer Jr., who was killed when Sandinista troops shot down their supply plane in 1986. Jurors agreed Hasenfus and Sawyer were working for Miami-based Southern Air Transport and had been hired by retired Air Force Gen. Richard Secord, but ruled the men were independent contractors well aware of the risks. Hasenfus, his wife and Sawyer's family sought to recoup lost wages and other damages resulting from the crash in a civil lawsuit against Southern Air Transport and Secord, who helped supply the Contra rebels. Hasenfus, of Marinette, Wis., was dejected after the decision. ``I've had so much taken from me already,'' he said. ``This is a disappointment.'' Hasenfus sought $57,000 in back pay and his wife Sally sought $66,000 reimbursement for legal expenses involved in extricating her husband from the Nicaraguan jail where he was held for three months after the crash. Mrs. Hasenfus said U.S. State Department officials had assured her that they would help pay for her husband's legal expenses while he was in jail in Nicaragua. But Hasenfus' attorneys were unable to link Secord and Southern Air to those State Department officials, explained one juror. ``If we could have proved the State Department (employees) were agents of Secord and Southern Air, we would have given them money,'' juror Ivis Charbonier said. ``We did feel there was a secret operation,'' said juror Wade Harris. ``We tried very hard to live by the evidence that they gave us, but there wasn't any proof of any oral agreement.'' Hasenfus had claimed in the lawsuit against Secord, an Iran-Contra figure, and Southern Air that they controlled the illegal network and were responsible for damages suffered as a result of the supply plane crash in Nicaragua. Attorneys for the defendants argued that Hasenfus and Sawyer knew the risks of the operation, but were acting on their own and were owed no special responsibility by the defendants. ``We do intend to appeal if we can raise the funds,'' said Brian Strange, an attorney for Hasenfus. A defense attorney said Secord was overseas and unavailable for comment. Secord is currently on probation after a guilty plea on charges of lying to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair. Before deliberations began last Tuesday, U.S. District Judge C. Clyde Atkins ruled in favor of Secord and Southern Air that the jury should only consider claims for back salary for Hasenfus and death benefits for Sawyer's wife in Magnolia, Ark. The plaintiffs had sought payment for legal bills, lost income, mental stress and other damages, but were unable to prove their claims of corporate _ and U.S. government _ responsibility for their actions. ``They removed their fingerprints quite well from everything,'' a shaken Hasenfus said afterward. ``We won a war here, but we lost a battle, in a way.''

DOC.HEAD: Pack of Menacing Dogs Keeps Police From Stricken New York Man
DOC.TEXT: Police were unable to reach a man felled by a heart attack in his yard because he was surrounded by 30 menacing dogs. Suffolk County police were called to the home of Raymond Jenkins, 70, Monday evening after neighbors reported the man was calling for help, Sgt. Vincent Diresta said. Jenkins was found lying on a table in his fenced-in yard, surrounded by 30 uncontrollable, snapping dogs, he said. Forty-five minutes later, the firefighters and animal control officers were were able to distract the dogs with fire extinguishers, enabling emergency workers to enter the yard and remove Jenkins, who was then examined by a physician and pronounced dead, apparently killed by a heart attack.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Saddam Demostrations Forbidden, Carrier Leaves Djibouti
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister says France, which is among countries whose military forces are standing up to Iraq, is forbidding rallies in support of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for the duration of the Persian Gulf crisis. ``We cannot tolerate demonstrations in favor of someone holding our countrymen hostage,'' the minister, Roland Dumas, told the Senate late Monday. ``They will be forbidden.'' Sporadic pro-Saddam demonstrations have attracted a few hundred people in the French capital since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. About 21,000 Westerners are stranded in Iraq and occupied Kuwait and considered hostages. Dumas also said that Interior Minister Pierre Joxe has taken ``all necessary measures'' since the crisis broke to ensure that the 1,700 Iraqi nationals living in France comply with French law. About a dozen Iraqi air force pilots training in France at the time of the invasion have been ``placed under tight surveillance,'' Dumas said. Four of them tried to escape last week from a military camp where they had been left mostly unguarded. Dumas spoke to the Senate during an extraordinary session of debate about the crisis. France has sent nine warships and 180 ground troops to the region to support the United Nations embargo of Iraq and occupied Kuwait. The aircraft carrier Clemenceau, flagship of French forces in the Persian Gulf, left the Red Sea port of Djibouti for the Gulf of Oman early today, defense sources said. President Francois Mitterrand said Monday that helicopters from the Clemenceau's fleet of 10 transport and 32 attack choppers will be sent to Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Junk Mail Museum in Works, Designed to Counter Negative Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to recast summary line, ``counter'' sted ``enhance.''
DOC.TEXT: Millionaire Warren Meyer is about to realize his decade-old dream of opening a shrine to junk mail. ``There's a lot more to junk mail than Ed McMahon's handsome face,'' said Meyer, known locally as the ``junk mail king.'' His firm Meyer & Son Mailhouse is a leader in direct-mail sales drives. Meyer said he believes junk mail suffers from a negative image, and he hopes his museum will deliver the respect it deserves. The museum will be built in mid-1991 in Los Angeles. ``The museum is a 10-year dream and I am finally seeing it come into fruition,'' Meyer said. He plans to run newspaper advertisements in coming months seeking examples of junk mail ``classics'' for the museum archives. Junk mail serves an honorable purpose, said Meyer, who recently donated his company's services to more than 25 charities and mailed over 1 million pieces of nonprofit and charity direct-mail appeals for them.

DOC.HEAD: Governor's Races in Oklahoma and Alaska Atop Primary Ballots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting with political ``p'' category code.
DOC.TEXT: The governor's race in today's Oklahoma primaries has five Democrats and five Republicans seeking spots in anticipated September runoff elections. The large field of hopefuls developed after Republican Gov. Henry Bellmon declined to seek re-election. In Alaska, a gambling initiative divided a close race for governor between Lt. Gov. Stephen McAlpine and former Anchorage Mayor Tony Knowles going into today's Democratic primary. In the Republican race, state Sen. Arliss Sturgulewski was heavily favored to win her second consecutive nomination. A measure on the November general election that would restore criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana also split the candidates. McAlpine tried to paint Knowles as soft on drugs, because of the former mayor's opposition to the measure. Gov. Steve Cowper, a Democrat, helped lead the campaign against an initiative that would allow local-option casino gambling. There was virtually no campaign for the measure, and a poll last week found voters opposing it by 2-to-1. Knowles recently seized on the measure, which he opposes, after McAlpine said he would vote for it. McAlpine said although he opposes casino gambling he supports letting local voters decide. In the Oklahoma governor's race, the Democrat candidates were U.S. Rep. Wes Watkins, state House Speaker Steve Lewis, businessman David Walters _ the 1986 nominee _ and newcomers John Shorty Barnett and Anne Hartin Langston. Seeking the GOP nomination are restaurant chain owner Vince Orza, former U.S. attorney Bill Price, former state Human Services Commission Chairman Burns Hargis, truck stop operator Jerry Brown and rancher Jerry Hoyt. In other races, U.S. Sen. David Boren, a Democrat, was considered an overwhelming favorite to win his party's nomination. Four congressmen, Republicans James Inhofe and Mickey Edwards and Democrats Dave McCurdy and Glen English are running unopposed in party primaries. Two other congressional seats were contested, with Lt. Gov. Robert S. Kerr III and state Rep. Bill Brewster among four Democrats seeking to succeed Watkins. Six-term incumbent Mike Synar faced a challenge from Broken Arrow attorney Jack Ross. Gambling also figured in a Colorado recall drive to be decided today. Three town council members in Cripple Creek say the recall was triggered by their opposition to a proposed gambling initiative. Recall backers say the drive was launched after the council failed to approve several important projects, such as a fire district, a youth center and a water main renovation plan. A proposed constitutional amendment on the Nov. 6 ballot would legalize limited gambling in the old mining communities of Cripple Creek, Central City and Black Hawk.

DOC.HEAD: Book Advises How To Keep Peace with In-Laws
DOC.TEXT: Want to get along with your in-laws? Learn how and when to say no, an author says. ``You don't have to like (your in-laws),'' said Leah Averick, a social worker and author of ``How In-Laws Relate: It's All Relative.'' ``But you can be very polite to them. Remember, these are important people to your husband or wife.'' Averick writes about how to make a good first impression, how to decide what to call in-laws and how to get along with grandparents, brothers and sisters. The book also discusses several tension points in in-law relations, including weddings, holidays, births and gift-giving occasions. In weddings, for instance, she said parents and other relatives often try to play too large a role selecting the apparel, planning the reception or preparing the guest list. Her advice: the marrying couple should learn how to say ``No'' to in-law help in a nice way.

DOC.HEAD: How Not To Succeed in Business: Change Name to `Treasures of Baghdad'
DOC.TEXT: Morris Dweck was counting on the allure of the Middle East to drum up business when he added a roadside genie and changed the name of his miniature golf course to ``Treasures of Baghdad.'' The changes, made well before the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, have not proved popular in the vicinity of Myrtle Beach Air Force Base. ``We've had this place for eight years, and up to this year, it was known as the Golden Dragon,'' Dweck said of his 36-hole course at a prime location across from a water park. ``Now we don't have anybody at all during the day, and only an occasional person at night, when it's supposed to be the most crowded.'' Dweck spent $15,000 on a fancy ``Treasures of Baghdad'' sign and added a roadside turbaned genie sitting cross-legged with a bobbing head. Around town, one of the hottest-selling souvenirs is a T-shirt featuring a likeness of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein above the line ``Public Enemy Number One.'' The Air Force base sent several A-10 jets to Saudi Arabia. ``It's been tough in a few other ways, too,'' Dweck said. ``A man and his family came by not long ago, got ready to play and asked us which Arabian country we were from. ``I told him we were Jewish and from New York, and he immediately packed his family up and left,'' he said. ``He was from Jordan.''

DOC.HEAD: Advance on Fort Delayed at Damaged Causeway
DOC.TEXT: Sri Lankan troops were held up at a mine-damaged causeway today in their advance to relieve the besieged Jaffna Fort, top defense officials said. As soon as the army can advance from the small islands in Jaffna lagoon across the causeway to the mainland, it intends to clear the Tamil Tiger rebels from a one-mile perimeter around the fort, Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said in an interview. The Tigers have kept the fort under siege for the past 10 weeks. The government assault, now in its seventh day, is the biggest operation against the Tiger's northern stronghold since the current round of fighting erupted June 11. ``We are crossing the causeway now,'' Wijeratne said. ``It's been heavily mined. ... Our troops will repair that and get across.'' However, the defense secretary, Gen. Cyril Ranatunge, indicated the task may be difficult. A 17-foot gap in the 1,500-yard causeway must be repaired, possibly under fire from rebel mortar positions, he told The Associated Press. The star-shaped, 17th-century Dutch colonial fortress dominates Jaffna. The fort is the government's only stronghold in Jaffna town. Jaffna, 185 miles northeast of Colombo, is the headquarters of the rebels seeking Tamil independence from the Sinhalese-dominated government. An army helicopter landed inside the fort on Monday with eight relief soldiers and food and evacuated seven wounded policemen, Wijeratne said. It was only the second time a helicopter reached the fort since the siege began. The 250-man garrison has been supplied by high-altitude air drops, including blocks of ice for drinking water. On Aug. 22 the government launched an offensive to seize three islands west of the fort and open a corridor across the causeway to the outpost. Wijeratne initially predicted the operation would take two or three days. Diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the army had committed two battalions, or about 2,000 troops, to secure the fort area. These sources said the army would have trouble holding the built-up perimeter areas in Jaffna town, which is separated from the fort by 500 yards of no-man's land. ``We have to hold it. Otherwise, the Tigers will come back,'' Wijeratne said. Ranatunge was more cautious, admitting it would take a lot of manpower. ``We'll see how it goes,'' he said. Wijeratne, seated below two pin-studded maps marking troop deployments on this Indian Ocean island, said he would offer civilians in Jaffna a chance to evacuate the line of fire. ``Once we open the corridor, options are there for the civilians _ if they want to escape the onslaught _ there's an escape route for them,'' he said. Despite the delays, he said the rebel resistance was lighter than expected. ``They are cracking up,'' he boasted. ``They are now getting mauled by the Sri Lankan army.'' He said the objective of the operation was to open Jaffna Hospital, which has been closed since the fighting began. Military officials claim more than two Tiger guerrillas have been killed in the weeklong offensive. The Tigers, who rarely admit casualties while battles are in progress, have acknowledged no losses and claim most of the victims were civilians. At least 14,000 people have been killed since Tamil guerrillas embarked on their separatist war in 1983. Militants say they need their own homeland to preserve the culture of their ethnic minority and protect it from discrimination by Sinhalese in jobs and education. Tamils comprise 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, while Sinhalese make up 75 percent. There is also a Moslem minority.

DOC.HEAD: Servicemen Get U.S. Citizenship Before Gulf Duty
DOC.TEXT: Two foreign-born servicemen took the oath of citizenship in a special ceremony arranged to beat an anticipated callup for Middle East duty. ``If something happens and I die, I want to die as an American,'' said Marine Cpl. Keun ``Kevin'' Ho Yook, a Korean immigrant, after Monday's ceremony before U.S. District Judge Dickran Tevrizian. Yook, 24, raised his right hand along with Navy Petty Officer 2nd Class German Oswaldo Acuna, 24, a Guatemalan immigrant. The servicemen, wearing crisp uniforms and crew cuts, promised to defend the Constitution and the laws of the United States. ``At this time you are now citizens of the greatest country of the world, the United States of America,'' said Tevrizian, an American-born son of Armenian immigrants. The pair gave the pledge of allegiance, and after the ceremony were applauded by fellow servicemen, immigration authorities and family members. ``I'm feeling great right now,'' Acuna said. ``This means that I can talk to my shipmates and everyone else I know who's American and say, `Look, I'm an American like you.''' Acuna came to America in 1981 and enlisted in the Navy in 1986. Yook arrived in 1986 and joined the Marines about a year later. The military allows immigrants to enlist as long as they have proper immigration status. The servicemen based at Camp Pendleton had been scheduled to attend naturalization ceremonies on Sept. 24. But the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait changed their plans. The pair asked the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service for a hurry-up ceremony. INS Western Regional Commissioner Ben Davidian said the agency then ``bent a few rules and moved a few things around.'' Military officials have refused to comment on deployments, but Acuna and Yook said they were convinced they would soon be shipped to the Middle East. Marine Capt. David Olsen, Yook's commanding officer, said Yook had always talked about becoming an American citizen. ``To see him become a citizen is just a great inspiration to the rest of us,'' Olsen said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets To Help International Group Learn Wallenberg's Fate
DOC.TEXT: The KGB and other Soviet agencies have for the first time agreed to open their files to help determine whether Raoul Wallenberg really died in a Moscow prison in 1947. A group that believes the Swedish diplomat, who saved tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews at the end of World War II, may still be alive said Monday it had secured the Soviet Union's cooperation in determining his fate. Wallenberg vanished after being arrested by the Soviets in Budapest on spying charges in 1945. Soviet authorities have long maintained he died in the KGB's Lubyanka Prison in 1947, but Wallenberg's relatives say they have received reports he is alive and detained in the Soviet Union. He would now be 77. ``The evidence is incontrovertible that Raoul Wallenberg did not die in 1947, compelling that he was alive in the 50s and 60s, and credible that he was alive thereafter,'' said Irwin Cotler, a Canadian lawyer who has spent 10 years investigating Wallenberg's fate. Cotler told a news conference that an international commission is working on the premise that Wallenberg ``may still be alive, though possibly under another identity, and unknown even to Soviet prison authorities.'' Besides Cotler, commission members include Wallenberg's half-brother, Guy von Dardel; several Soviet journalists and historians; and two former Soviet political prisoners _ Cronid Lubarski, an editor, and Marvin Makinen, chairman of the University of Chicago's biochemistry department. ``What you have here is a joint cooperative initiative, for the first time, that we hope will ultimately discover the fate and whereabouts of Raoul Wallenberg,'' Cotler told reporters at the Swedish Embassy. He said the KGB, the Foreign Ministry and the Interior Ministry had all agreed to help the commission. ``We have been told that we will be given access to all files on the Wallenberg affairs,'' he said. ``Therefore, I interpret all files to include KGB files.'' Cotler said the commission has also asked the KGB for files belonging to SMERSH, a defunct Soviet security agency that killed real, suspected or potential opponents of the Soviet government. Cotler praised the Soviet cooperation as a step forward in glasnost, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of openness. ``The Soviet position has been historically, since 1957, that Raoul Wallenberg died in 1947,'' he said. ``From 1957 to 1987 they basically did not address this issue.'' Cotler said the commission was granted permission to travel Monday to Vladimir Prison, 12 miles outside Moscow, where Wallenberg allegedly has been sighted. Prison officials have agreed to allow commission members to examine their archives _ including 10,000 registration cards _ and interview present and former inmates, guards and administrators, Cotler said. Last October, Soviet officials expressed remorse for the first time over the Stalin-era arrest of Wallenberg, a Lutheran who saved an estimated 20,000 Jews from Nazi gas chambers by sheltering them and issuing them false passports. Wallenberg, a member of a prominent family of bankers and industrialists, repeatedy risked his life by hiding Jews in houses he bought or rented, often with his own money. In the final days before the liberation of Budapest, Wallenberg persuaded the Nazis to cancel a plan to kill 70,000 Jews who were still living in the city's ghetto. Last fall, KGB deputy chief Vladimir Pirozhkov returned Wallenberg's passport, driver's license, address book, calendar and cash to his family, saying they had been found in KGB headquarters the previous month. However, the only proof offered of Wallenberg's death was a doctor's letter, released in 1957, saying Wallenberg suffered a fatal heart attack and was cremated.

DOC.HEAD: Group Rates States in Education; Raps Lack of Parental Participation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf from end to CORRECT one Arkansas to Alaska.
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut and Wyoming got the best grades in a state-by-state report card of educational performance released today by a parents group. The American Association of Parents and Children prepared the report card after an earlier study found nine out of 10 teachers think parents don't care about education. The group's executive director, Scott Stapf, said the reports should be a ``wake-up call'' telling parents they play an important role in education. ``It's a disastrous message to create the impression with parents that when you look at the national education crisis, the only people who need to be concerned are teachers and school administrators and state lawmakers,'' Stapf said. ``Unless you create a picture that includes parents in the equation as well, you're really missing a big part,'' he said. The AAPC, a year-old, independent research group, compiled dozens of studies by the Department of Education, the Carnegie Foundation and others for its report card. The group graded states on their statistical performance in six broad areas: parental apathy, Head Start participation, student-teacher ratios, per-student spending, graduation rates and standardized test scores. It then averaged them for an overall grade. Connecticut and Wyoming were the only states to receive an ``A.'' Hawaii, Texas, South Carolina, Georgia, Tennessee and Louisiana got an ``F.'' Nearly nine out of 10 teachers believe parents are apathetic about education, a Carnegie Foundation study found last this year. The AAPC is trying to remedy that with a pamphlet of 10 simple steps for parents to become more involved with schools, Stapf said. The pamphlet is available by mail from AAPC's Herndon, Va., headquarters. A study for the national Parent Teacher Association earlier this year also found that most parents' involvement in school is low. President Bush noted the study in a speech to the PTA's legislative conference in March. ``Education is a national mission that must include parents,'' he said. But Arnold Fege, the PTA's governmental relations director, on Monday faulted Bush and the nation's governors for not making increased parental involvement an education reform goal. ``Parents are frequently the orphans in education policy,'' he said. Since its study, PTA leaders began developing strategies to increase parents' role, Fege said. He said schools need to create more flexible opportunities for parental participation. ``The schools have to recognize that the families have some unique needs today that they didn't have 10 years ago,'' Fege said. He noted there are more single parents and more families where both parents work now than in 1980. ``At the same time, we recognize that the home frequently makes it easier for the teacher to operate,'' Fege said. The AAPC timed the release of its report card to be near the new school year, Stapf said. Classes in some states began Monday. Many states start school after Labor Day. The AAPC's grades: A _ Connecticut, Wyoming. B _ Kansas, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Minnesota, Vermont, Iowa, Wisconsin, Maryland, Nebraska, Montana, Pennsylvania, North Dakota, South Dakota, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, Maine. C _ Ohio, Illinois, Colorado, Oregon, New York, Missouri, Michigan, West Virginia, Delaware, California, Arkansas, Virginia, Washington, Alaska, Indiana, Nevada, District of Columbia. D _ Oklahoma, Mississippi, Florida, Idaho, Utah, New Mexico, Arizona, Alabama, North Carolina, Kentucky. F _ Hawaii, Texas, South Carolina, Georgia, Tennessee and Louisiana.

DOC.HEAD: 45,000 Public Employees Stage Warning Strikes in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: About 45,000 municipal workers in several East German cities walked off their jobs for a few hours today in warning strikes for better wages and job security in a united Germany. Nurses, secretaries, bus drivers, garbage-haulers and other employees stopped working for up to two hours in at least 10 cities. Demonstrations and rallies were held in a number of cities, with workers demanding job protection and pay increases in a united Germany. There are about 1.6 million municipal workers in East Germany. West Germany is pressuring East Germany to keep costs down as a means of helping bail out the nation from its economic woes. West Germany is already spending billions of dollars to prop up its neighbor as the two countries prepare for political merger on Oct. 3. The workers are demanding compensation for higher prices that have resulted from the two Germanys' July 1 economic merger. They also demand that East German income taxes not be immediately raised to West German levels. Effects from the warning strikes were felt across East Germany. In Potsdam outside Berlin, buses and street cars were idle for two hours, according to the official East German news agency, ADN. Parked streetcars blocked main avenues in Magdeburg, and dozens of garbage trucks hindered access to the city's main department store, ADN said. Operations at Magdeburg's Elbe River harbor were temporarily crippled by the walkout, the news agency said. Short strikes were also staged in Halle, Sonneberg, Schwerin, Frankfurt an der Oder, Chemnitz, Zwickau, Plauen, and Schoenberg. In Bonn, meanwhile, the West German government said Western investors' interest in East Germany is starting to pick up. The West German government had hoped for massive Western investment in East Germany once the two nations merged their economies, but so far interest has been scant. Dieter Vogel, spokesman for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said East German officials reported ``investment readiness ... is increasing noticeably.'' He did not give any figures.

DOC.HEAD: Two Rescued, Three Missing After Ships Collide
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers searched this morning for three crew members of a New Bedford fishing vessel that collided in thick fog with a Greek cargo ship, the Coast Guard said. Two men in the five-member fishing crew were rescued after they were thrown into the Atlantic Ocean in the accident 42 miles east of Nantucket. The 591-foot cargo ship Eurojoy struck the smaller boat, named New England, about 7:30 a.m., officials said. Visibility was a half mile. ``The tanker never saw the fishing boat at all,'' said Lt. Richard Gill, operations center controller. ``There is debris and there is indication that it sank,'' he added. The men who were rescued were picked up by the crew of the Eurojoy, said Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Greg Creedon. Creedon said a Coast Guard helicopter was sent to the scene from Cape Cod and a Coast Guard rescue boat was sent from Nantucket. The Eurojoy was empty and on its way from Boston to Norfolk, Va., Gill said.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Heading Home from Iraq `in Great Shape'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7-12 graf pvs, `There were...of Washington.' to fix typos. Pickup 13th, `About 10...' ^With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dependents of U.S. diplomats in Kuwait seemed ``in good spirits and good health'' when they touched down in Paris today on a stopover on their flight home, a U.S. official said. ``I talked to the doctors. Everyone was in great shape,'' said U.S. Embassy spokesman Paul Kozelka, who met with some of the tired Americans at Charles de Gaulle-Roissy airport. Two American doctors were accompanying the 52 women and children on the flight, which left the NATO base at Incirlik, Turkey, for the United States earlier in the day. The dependents are headed for Andrews Air Force Base in Washington. Their Transcontinental charter flight stopped over for about two hours in Paris to refuel. The flight was unlisted in normal air traffic logs, and the plane kept away from the main airport terminal buildings. Reporters were not given access to passengers on the aircraft or others shuttled to the terminal to use airport facilities. ``They all seemed to be in good spirits and good health ... the kids were playing around like kids do,'' Kozelka said. There were six infants and another dozen or so small children among those permitted to leave Kuwait City by Iraqi troops. The dependents were among about 100 people evacuated from Kuwait when the U.S. Embassy there was reduced to a skeleton staff. Iraq eventually let the women and children in the group leave Baghdad, but detained about 50 diplomats in the party as hostages. Those allowed out traveled from Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, overland through mountains and desert to Turkey, where they boarded a flight for home. ``It was long night's drive and they were disturbed by TV cameras and flashes while they were trying to sleep,'' said Kozelka. When the group reached the Turkish border, three young men in the party were ``forcibly removed'' and taken back to Baghdad. The three, unidentified by name, were sons of U.S. diplomats over the age of 18, U.S. officials said. The ordeal of the dependents _ coupled with Iraqi actions against diplomats remaining in Baghdad and Kuwait City _ have angered the United States. The State Department retaliated by ordering the Iraqi Embassy in Washington to reduce its staff from 55 to 19. Remaining Iraqi diplomats were ordered to stay within a 25-mile radius of Washington. About 10 U.S. diplomats remain in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City, despite an order by Iraq that all embassies in the city must close. Iraq has cut off the electricity, water and phone lines to many of the embassies but so far has not used force to empty and close the missions.

DOC.HEAD: Middle East Tensions Spark Call To Duty For Some
With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States military buildup in Saudi Arabia has brought a rush on some recruiting stations by would-be soldiers, including many too young or too old to fight. Sgt. Bob Armstrong at the Army recruiting center in Rochester, N.Y., said he has seen the number of potential enlistments rise from three or four people a day to five or six since the Persian Gulf crisis began. ``Qualified is another story,'' Armstrong said Monday. ``We got maybe one contract this month out of it.'' Most of the people coming to the recruiting center say they want to serve in the Middle East, but nearly all have been unqualified because they are not high school graduates or have criminal records, he said. Most of the interest seems directed at the Army. Air Force and Navy officials reported little change in the number of would-be recruits since Iraq invaded Kuwait and thousands of U.S. troops were deployed to the Persian Gulf. ``Absolutely we've been getting more calls,'' said Sgt. First Class Rick Henager, an Army recruiter in Hyannis, Mass. ``We're talking about an increase of 1,000 percent on some days.'' Henager took a call from a young man who had won a four-year college scholarship but still wanted to be a medic in the Middle East if war broke out. ``He said, `Look, I'm all set with my education. But if we do go to war I want to be a part of it.' Another kid said, `I've lived in this country 19 years. It's time I started helping with the rent.''' The Army National Guard in Toms River, N.J., is getting a flood of people who have already served their country in battle. ``We have Vietnam vets wanting to go over,'' said Sgt. Carl Tucker. ``Especially since they heard about the reserves being called in, a lot of prior service people are calling us. They figure if they can get in a reserve unit they can get called over.'' Americans are not the only ones gung ho on getting in on the action. Canadians are contacting New York recruiting stations to put in a bid for active duty. ``Just last week alone, it's been about 20 to 25'' Canadians calling, said Sgt. Antony Byrd, an Army recruiter in Niagara Falls. ``Before, in a week's time, we used to get maybe five.'' In order for Canadians to join the U.S. military they must hold green cards or dual citizenship, either through being a member of certain Indian tribes or having a parent who is a U.S. citizen. Officials at the Army recruiting office in Little Rock, Ark., didn't wait for people to come to them. They announced last week that they needed experienced soldiers for re-enlistment. And they got what they asked for. Recruiters said they were seeking re-enlistments, and not fresh-faced first timers, just to speed up the readiness process. ``If you take a young person in now who has never been trained, it's going to be a while before they'll be ready to do anything. ... You're looking at a period of maybe six months down the road,'' said John Moss, chief of advertising and public affairs for the Little Rock office. Still, even those who know they are too young to serve or well beyond the age for military action ``just wanted to know what they could do to help ... and I think that was great,'' Moss said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Criticize U.S. Action Expelling Iraqis
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union criticized the United States today for expelling Iraqi diplomats from Washington and warned that such action could lead to a ``spiral of escalation'' in the conflict. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov also indicated that some of Iraq's Arab neighbors have failed to put enough pressure on Baghdad in response to its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Regarding the nearly 200 military advisers the Soviet Union has in Iraq, Gerasimov said their presence does not violate U.N. sanctions against Iraq but that the Soviet government is looking into the situation. ``Arab countries have to be more energetic in their efforts aimed at eliminating the crisis,'' he told reporters. ``A lot depends on the Arabs themselves ... they can make certain efforts to find a way out of that situation.'' The United States has ordered 36 Iraqi Embassy personnel to leave Washington by Thursday and has imposed travel limits on the 19 envoys allowed to remain. The United States has so far been unable to persuade its allies to expel Iraqi diplomats from other capitals. The move followed Iraqi demands that foreign countries close their embassies in Kuwait. Iraq also had briefly prevented 52 dependents of U.S. personnel from leaving its country. The group eventually was allowed to go to Turkey and were headed home today. Gerasimov said the Soviet Union had no plans to expel Iraqi diplomats from Moscow. ``We would not want any steps that can aggravate the already hot situation in the gulf, which will make difficult the way out of that crisis,'' he said. He was asked whether the United States' action had aggravated the conflict. ``I don't believe that we have to add fuel to the fire in this explosive situation. Of course Iraq's actions to close embassies in Kuwait are illegitimate. But if you use a tit-for-tat policy in this question, you risk falling down the spiral of escalation, and aggravating the situation. ``I believe we have to mostly make use of diplomatic efforts.'' Asked whether the Soviet Union was being more helpful in efforts to resolve the conflict, Gerasimov said: ``Diplomatically, yes, because we talk to Iraq. You don't. But the aim is the same: to stop this aggression, and to punish the aggressor.'' A group of 240 Soviet women and children arrived in Moscow today after being evacuated from Iraq. A second group planned to leave either late today or early Wednesday, and all 983 dependents were to be home by Saturday. The Soviet Union had 7,791 citizens in Iraq, mostly oil workers, diplomats and dependents, officials have said. That number includes 193 military advisers, whom Soviet officials say are under contractual obligation to continue working for Iraq. Gerasimov denied accusations that the Soviet Union had violated U.N. sanctions against Iraq by keeping its military advisers there. The Soviet Union, Iraq's largest arms supplier, cut off weapons shipments after the invasion. Gerasimov said U.N. sanctions did not cover the military experts, who teach Iraqi soldiers to use modern Soviet-built weapons. They also maintain and repair the hardware. ``Legally, there is no problem, but there is a moral aspect to that problem, so we recognize that and will try to resolve it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Continue to Tighten Lending Standards
DOC.TEXT: A Federal Reserve survey shows U.S. banks have continued to tighten their lending standards in the last three months because of a weakening economy and problems in several industries. ``Domestic respondent banks indicated that since May they have further tightened lending standards and terms with respect to non-merger-related business loans,'' according to the survey released Monday. It found that the tighter standards were particularly noticeable for medium-sized firms, but also significant for small and large businesses. The survey polled senior loan officers at 60 domestic banks and 18 branches of foreign institutions. ``Branches and agencies of foreign banks reproted that, on balance, they too have moved to restrict the availability of business credit,'' the survey found. ``By far the most important reasons domestic respondents gave for tightening their credit standards in the last three months were a less favorable eocnomic outlook and industry-specific problems,'' the survey said. Other reasons included more stringent money supplies due to problem loans and regulatory pressures. ``About three-quarters of respondents reported that they had imposed tighter credit standards for applications to finance commercial office buildings in the last three months,'' the survey said. Most banks reported their willingness to make general purpose and consumer installment loans to individuals was unchanged. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan acknowledged in congressional testimony on July 12 that credit problems were emerging. The following day, the central bank lowered the federal funds rate from 8.25 percent to 8 percent in part to offset the tightened credit. The federal funds rate is that charged to banks for overnight loans.

DOC.HEAD: Precede SAUDI ARABIA ^Sen. Nunn Urges Egypt to Send More Troops to Saudi Arabia
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Nunn urging Mubarak to sent more troops to Saudi Arabia. Pickup 11th graf, `About 60,000...' Subs last graf to ADD John Warner. Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Sam Nunn urged Egypt's president today to send more troops to Saudi Arabia to show the world it is with the United States in its showdown with Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sen. Bob Dole, the Senate's top Republican, and six other Republican senators spent 90 minutes with President Hosni Mubarak. The U.S. delegation is touring the Middle East. On Monday they were in Saudi Arabia and met with some of the tens of thousands of U.S. troops arrayed against Iraqi troops across the border in Kuwait. ``Now that we have that deterrent force in place, I think we need to get more Arab forces on the ground. I emphasized that to the president,'' Nunn said of the meeting with Mubarak. ``I think it would help back in the United States with the American people to see that we have more help from Egypt and from other countries on the ground in Saudi Arabia,'' he said. Nunn said that would ``make it clear that it's not the United States vs. Iraq but the Arab world and the world at large vs. Iraq.'' At a news conference after meeting the senators, Mubarak did not mention Nunn's request for additional troops. He has said Egypt has 2,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia, but Egyptian military sources say the figure is closer to 4,000. Mubarak and senior Egyptian officers say they would send more if the Saudis ask for them. About 60,000 U.S. troops are in Saudi Arabia and the gulf region, as well as dozens of fighter planes. Warships from the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and other countries are in the Persian Gulf and Red Sea. U.S. forces deliberately are being kept a good distance behind Saudi and other Arab troops. Support for the deployment in the Arab world might collapse if Americans fired the first shots in the conflict. In addition, U.S. support for the deployment might waver if the first casualties were Americans. Several senators said they came away from the military briefings convinced a formidable deterrent force was in place. ``It's not all in place,'' Nunn said of the continuing U.S. buildup. ``But an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia would be national suicide.'' Several senators conceded Iraq's holding of American hostages complicated U.S. planning but said the hostage situation could not be the driving force behind policy and military decisions. ``You can't run foreign policy on hostages,'' said GOP Sen. Jake Garn of Utah. ``If you did, no American would be safe anywhere in the world.'' Other senators making the trip, all Republicans, were: Don Nickles of Oklahoma, Steve Symms of Idaho, Alfonse D'Amato of New York, Connie Mack of Florida and John Warner of Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Big Five Approve Major U.N. Role in Cambodia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more details on plan adopted by big five, more background on Cambodian conflict. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent Security Council members have agreed on a plan for a truce in Cambodia and U.N. administration of the country, diplomats said today. The plan, which would involve the United Nation's deepest involvement in any regional conflict, was worked out by the American, British, French, Chinese and Soviet envoys in two days of private talks on the details of a transitional administration to guide Cambodia to peace and democracy. ``We have gone as far as we can as the five permanent members,'' said a U.S. diplomat involved in the talks. ``Now it is up to the four Cambodian parties'' _ the Communist Khmer Rouge, its two non-Communist guerrilla allies, and the Hanoi-installed government in Phnom Penh. ``The question is, can the four Cambodian factions agree?'' he said. Those factions are due to meet in Jakarta, Indonesia, in September to indicate whether they will accept the plan. However, the agreement of the five permanent members means that the backers of the warring factions _ the United States, Soviet Union and China _ have reached accord on a peace plan. ``The question now is whether the Soviets and Chinese can bring their people on board,'' said the diplomat. The Khmer Rouge receives its weapons and supplies from China; the Soviets back the current Cambodian government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, which was installed by their ally, Vietnam; and Washington backs the two non-Communist guerrilla factions, led by Prince Sihanouk and former Premier Son Sann. ``The United Nations will have very broad authority to administer and to control Cambodia,'' said the diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``This will be the most significant U.N. involvement in this (regional conflict) that we have ever seen,'' he said, adding that it would far exceed the world body's role in guiding Namibia to independence. The Namibia settlement cost the United Nations over $750 million. The key issues now, he said, were to organize a cease-fire and elections so a new government can be established that is not dominated by the Khmer Rouge or the current pro-Vietnam government. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in December 1978 to oust the Khmer Rouge, who presided over the deaths of up to a million Cambodians from starvation and executions during their brutal rule that began in 1975. The five Security Council members said they approved five documents that would be forwarded to the Cambodian factions by France and Indonesia, the co-chairmen of the Cambodian conference on adopting a peace plan. The Cambodian factions are supposed to meet to form a Supreme National Council to represent Cambodia during the transitional period. However, the respective roles and powers of the Hun Sen government and the Khmer Rouge in the coalition have long been disputed by the parties and their allies. The documents adopted today call for a cease-fire to be in place; for the warring parties to disengage, disarm and settle in U.N.-monitored ``cantonments;'' and for U.N. peacekeepers to take over security on the ground. The United Nations would also organize elections and verify that all Vietnamese forces have left Cambodia, as Hanoi announced they had a year ago. The Cambodian guerrillas claim many Vietnamese troops remained in the uniform of the Cambodian army, or as militias and civilian administrators. The draft documents being sent to the Cambodian parties call for the United Nations to ``supervise and control ... if necessary'' five key Cambodian ministries, various diplomats said. Those are the defense, foreign affairs, finance, public security and information ministries. They would be administered for ``as long as necessary,'' said a British source.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached To End Selma School Protests
DOC.TEXT: Eight months of racial tension, protests, arrests and lawsuits are nearing an end after blacks and whites agreed to rotate control of the troubled Selma school system. ``I think we've got something good worked out,'' said Mayor Joe Smitherman, who has been at the center of the controversy. The compromise announced Monday sets up a school board with 10 voting members, five black and five white, and a white chairman, Carl Barker, who would vote only on litigation involving the board and stemming from the protests. A resolution approved by the City Council on Monday calls for the city to drop about 130 arrest cases against black demonstrators who have camped out at schools and municipal buildings. In exchange, protest leaders would agree to drop lawsuits against the city. Once the legal wrangling is completed, Barker will resign and be replaced by a black _ giving the 11-member board appointed by the City Council its first black majority. From that point on, the school board will be rotated racially, with a black majority one year and a white majority the next. Selma schools reopened Aug. 20 after summer break, with blacks now making up about 80 percent of the student body of 6,000. The city of about 27,000 people is roughly half black and half white. The five black school board members walked out Dec. 21 after the six whites voted to fire the city's first black superintendent, Norward Roussell. The remaining board members continued to meet and hired an interim superintendent, James Carter, who also is black. The five black board members will be on the new panel. One of them, Freeman Walker, said he was looking forward to returning to work. ``The war has been fought and the victors are the boys and girls of our school system,'' said Walker, a teacher in the separate Dallas County school system. ``I personally think the events of the past eight months have strengthened our dedication toward our responsibility.'' Smitherman, who has carried the brunt of criticism by black protesters, announced the school board agreement to a packed City Council chamber that included one of the protest leaders, state Sen. Hank Sanders, whose wife, Rose, was among those faced with criminal charges. ``People have asked me how the board can operate with a five-and-five split. Well, you're going to operate with the art of compromise,'' said Smitherman, flanked by black and white school board members and about 30 members of two black civic clubs that helped negotiate the agreement The City Council approved the resolution by a 7-1 vote. The first full school board meeting is scheduled Sept. 13. Smitherman spent hours over the weekend conferring with white and black school board members, City Council members, black leaders and even Birmingham Mayor Richard Arrington, who called to offer his assistance. Among other results of the racial tension, Gov. Guy Hunt sent in the National Guard and state troopers in February, and about 300 whites transferried to Selma's two all-white private schools or neighboring public systems.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Firepower Reaches Saudi Soil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pentagon ground rules for covering US military operations prohibit the disclosure of the location of U.S. forces.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Army's heaviest ground firepower reached Saudi soil today for deployment behind Arab forces manning the front line in the monthlong standoff with Iraq. Dozens of M1-1P tanks and M2 Bradley armored infantry fighting vehicles, and scores more heavy support vehicles, rolled off two huge transport ships at a port in northeastern Saudi Arabia and were readied for the trip north into the desert. The M1s are by the far the biggest ground weapon in the burgeoning U.S. arsenal in Saudi Arabia, weighing an imposing 60 tons and carrying a 105 mm cannon said to be accurate at 6,600 feet or more. The huge but speedy tanks _ which can travel about 45 mph _ left the 24th Infantry (Mechanized) Division's home in Georgia two weeks ago. The 24th's heavy firepower will be deployed in front of most other U.S ground forces in Saudi Arabia but still a good distance behind the Saudi-led Arab forces, which are just miles from the border with occupied Kuwait. The U.S. buildup _ which could reach 200,000-250,000 ground forces _ is not expected to be completed until October. Transport planes are arriving around the clock, but the M1s and the 24th's other heavy weaponry have been long awaited by U.S. military commanders. Until now, the U.S.-led multinational Saudi defense force has been short on heavy ground firepower. ``This is boss,'' Sgt. Ronald Ruff said as he showed off his M1 to a group of reporters. ``This is the Cadillac model. This is the top of the line.'' Up to now, the only U.S. tanks in Saudi Arabia have been Vietnam era M60s, brought by the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, and even smaller M551 Sheridans. Iraq has a formidable force of Soviet-made tanks, primarily the export versions of its T64 and T72 models. The T64 is comparable in armament and armor to the M1s that arrived today; the T72 is equivalent to the more modern M1, the M1-A1. The U.S. tanks are considered to have superior weapons sighting and guidance systems, and the strategy for any tank war with Iraq is to use the air superiority of the American, Saudi and British forces to inflict heavy early damage on Iraqi tanks. ``There's no doubt in my mind that we'll succeed here if we have to,'' said Lt. Col. Barry Willey. ``Bring them (the Iraqis) on,'' Ruff said. ``We've the training and technology; they've got the numbers. We'll take them out.'' Several M1 crews said they will have to clean and change the M1's filters more often because of the talcum-like sand of the Saudi desert.

DOC.HEAD: Man in Surrogate Custody Battle is Killed
DOC.TEXT: A man awarded custody of a child born to a surrogate mother was found shot inside his ex-wife's apartment, where he had gone to pick up the child, authorities said. Richard Reams died early today after undergoing surgery at a Columbus hospital. His former wife, Beverly Seymour, was in stable condition today at another Columbus hospital because of an overdose of an unknown substance. Reams had been shot once in the abdomen, possibly with a small-caliber handgun, when he was found late Monday afternoon in Ms. Seymour's home, Sheriff Dwight Radcliff said. Earlier Monday, Reams won permanent custody of 5-year-old Tessa Reams, who was the focus of a three-way court battle among Reams, Ms. Seymour and the surrogate mother, Norma Lee Stotsky. Judge Ronald Solove of Franklin County Juvenile Court said Reams was to pick up the child on Monday. Reams had temporary custody before the ruling, and Ms. Seymour had visitation rights. Solove's ruling allowed Ms. Seymour to continue visitation. The child was placed under the care of the Franklin County Children's Services Monday night, said spokeswoman Kay Marshall. Tessa was born Jan. 12, 1985, to Ms. Stotsky, who was paid $10,000 to be a surrogate mother for Reams and Ms. Seymour. Reams and Ms. Seymour were divorced a year later. As Reams and Ms. Seymour fought for custody, Ms. Stotsky decided she wanted the baby back. The biological father of Tessa is not Reams, but a friend of Ms. Stotsky's who did not seek custody. Ms. Stotsky waged a campaign for custody in 1989 when Franklin County Probate Judge Richard Metcalf indicated neither Reams nor Ms. Seymour might be suitable to get custody.

DOC.HEAD: Death Row Inmate Found Dead with Jump Rope Around Neck
DOC.TEXT: A death row inmate has told authorities he helped strangle a fellow convict with a jump rope in a prison recreation yard, a sheriff's department spokesman says. Officials were questioning David Earl Gibbs, 29, convicted of a 1985 rape and murder, in connection with the death of death row inmate Calvin J. Williams, Walker County Sheriff's Deputy Don Hampton said. Williams, 30, was found near death Monday by prison guards at the Ellis I Unit northeast of Huntsville near the end of a scheduled three-hour recreation period. He died later at a hospital. Gibbs and Williams had been isolated in adjacent recreation yards separated by a chain-link fence. ``It was clear from the way the rope was tied off, it was done from Gibbs' side of the fence,'' special prosecutor David Weeks told the Houston Chronicle. He said Gibbs had fresh scratches and rope burns on his hands. Williams' death came one day short of the 10th anniversary of a Harris County jury's decision to sentence him to lethal injection for the rape-slaying of Emily Anderson, 28, the vice president of a Houston travel agency. Williams, who came within 90 minutes of execution in 1988 before winning a Supreme Court stay, had vowed he would never be put to death without a struggle. He had a history of violence during his years in prison. Williams, who was black, was a target of a homemade bomb during a September 1984 attack blamed on prison racial violence. He suffered burns over 17 percent of his body and also was stabbed and one leg was broken. Williams, who said he was one of 19 children in his family, was in the 11th grade when he went to jail on a robbery conviction. He had been out 34 days when Miss Anderson, nicknamed Mimi, was killed. Miss Anderson's sister, Ellen Yarrell, was not upset Monday when told of Williams' death. ``Apparently, he or someone else decided his time was up,'' said Ms. Yarrell, a Houston lawyer. ``I have been upset with the judicial system, even though I'm a lawyer, that his appeal process has gone on so long. I still think he acted as Mimi's judge, jury and executioner.'' Williams acknowledged breaking into the apartment where Miss Anderson was slain, but insisted the burglary occurred a month before the killing. His fingerprints, however, were found in the woman's stolen car, recovered a few blocks from his home. A jury took just six minutes to decide on the death penalty. Prison records showed he was involved in five fights within four years and was cited numerous times for destruction of state property.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Fever Grips Yemeni Dads, News Agency Reports
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some people think one Saddam is enough, but Iraq's news agency says 25 couples in Yemen have named their new babies Saddam since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein sent his army into Kuwait. The state-controlled Iraqi News Agency reported Tuesday that enthusiasm for Saddam Hussein is running high in Yemen, whose government has indicated sympathy for Iraq but maintained a relatively neutral public stance since the Aug. 2 takeover. Yemeni parents' feelings are based on support for Saddam's ``national stand in facing foreign aggression against the Arab nation,'' the news agency said. It did not say if any Yemeni newborns had been named George Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Nurses Go on Vacation, Leave Patient Behind
DOC.TEXT: Two nurses who were to be paid by the government to accompany a mentally disturbed patient on vacation lost the man but went on the holiday anyway, newspapers reported Tuesday. The patient, a 31-year old man being treated at the Beckomberga mental hospital in Stockholm, had paid with his own money to travel to Antalaya in Turkey. The government was to have reimbursed the nurses for the cost of their trip, but officials said they probably won't get the money now. But before the departure Saturday, the nurses lost track of the man at Arlanda international airport, the Dagens Nyheter and Svenska Dagbladet dailies reported. After an hour of searching, the papers said, the nurses decided to leave for the holiday, taking their patient's passport, ticket and money. ``He can cope by himself,'' the papers quoted the nurses as having told worried airport officials before boarding the plane. Arlanda police official Jan Martensson said the man was found at the airport and taken back to the hospital ``in worse psychological condition ... than before.''

DOC.HEAD: Legless Woman Swims English Channel
LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.TEXT: A German woman who lost her lower legs in a childhood accident has swum the English Channel, the Channel Swimming Association said Tuesday. Lucyna Krayfusua, 28, of Dortmund, West Germany, crossed the channel on Monday in 12 hours, 29 minutes, said Ray Scott, chairman of the association. ``It was better than most. It's a very good time,'' said Scott. ``Of course, her arms are very very powerful.'' He said the woman failed on two previous attempts to make the 21-mile crossing to France. The record time of 7 hours, 40 minutes was set by an American swimmer, Penny Dean, in 1978. Ms. Krayfusua was part of a group of six who all completed the crossing. Also in the group was Mosad Saad, 29, of Cairo, who has one leg, Scott said. He finished in 13 hours, 32 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Alabama House Fire Kills Six
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a house where a smoke detector had been installed last weekend, killing six family members and severely injuring a seventh. Firefighter Michael Thompson said nothing could be done to save the victims after the Oneonta Fire Department received the call. ``The house was already on the ground,'' he said. Thompson said fire officials were unsure how the survivor escaped. ``He was pretty badly burned. He was out of the house, probably 200 or so yards away from it.'' State Deputy Fire Marshal James Epperson said he had not determined the cause of the fire, but had ruled out foul play. ``There's not a whole lot left to work with,'' Epperson said. Owner Coy Carruth and his wife, Shirley, had already left for work when the fire started early Monday. ``There was no sign of anything that I saw unusual,'' he said. Carruth said he had installed a smoke detector in the dining room during the weekend and believed it was loud enough to be heard in the bedrooms upstairs. Carruth identified the victims as his son Vincent, 24; his daughter Shari, 19; his son Brian, 9; his daughter-in-law Renae, age unavailable; and her daughters, Christy, 3, and Jennifer, 14 months. Renae Carruth's husband, Royce, 27, was listed in critical condition at University Hospital in Birmingham.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmots to fix category code
DOC.HEAD: Man Faces Charges in Burying Puppies Alive
DOC.TEXT: A man buried six puppies alive in his back yard, which was dug up by a Michigan Humane Society worker who heard whimpers from the dirt, police said Tuesday. A neighbor reported the burial to the society on Saturday.
