One of the mixed-breed puppies died; the others were in good condition, authorities said. ``It's really quite amazing they've survived,'' said Debbie McDonald, manager of the humane society. ``They apparently had been buried for less than an hour.'' McDonald said investigator Mike Killian found the puppies' mother lying over the fresh graves. Killian dug at the spot and found the pups about 18 inches down. ``The owner told him that he had buried the puppies because they had all died, but as they got close to the burial spot, Killian could hear them crying and whimpering under the dirt,'' McDonald said. Richard E. Green, 65, faced arraignment on six misdemeanor counts of animal cruelty, police said. If convicted, he could be jailed for 90 days and fined $500.

DOC.HEAD: Court-Martial of Fort Bragg Soldier Begins with Innocent Plea
DOC.TEXT: A military panel will hear the case of a 19-year soldier charged with unpremeditated murder in the shooting death of a man during the U.S. invasion of Panama. Master Sgt. Roberto Enrique Bryan pleaded innocent as his court-martial began Monday. Unpremeditated murder carries a maximum punishment of life in prison. At Bryan's request, the court-martial will be heard by a panel similar to a jury instead of a military judge. Eight of 12 people questioned were chosen to hear the case. ``I'm feeling good,'' Bryan, 42, said Monday after his court-martial recessed for the day. The Army alleges Bryan shot the Panamanian man without provocation on Dec. 23, 1989 _ three days after the United States launched Operation Just Cause to oust Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. The shooting occurred after a Panamanian tossed a grenade that wounded 10 82nd Airborne soldiers at a roadblock near Madden Dam, authorities said. Bryan, an 82nd Airborne Division paratrooper, has said he was performing his duty in the heat of battle. Defense attorney Mark Waple said publicity about the case is the only reason it has gotten as far as a court-martial. The Army does not want to face ``criticism from the media or Congress in the face of a great deal of publicity'' about the case, he said. A story in the Army Times newspaper quoted unidentified Army sources as saying Bryan turned his M-16 rifle on a Panamanian prisoner attempting to surrender.

DOC.HEAD: LAX Brings in the Feds to Handle Pesky Pigeon Problem
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles International Airport has tried everything from blowhorns to gunfire to get rid of pesky pigeons and sea gulls that occasionally get sucked into jet engines, but nothing seems to work. Now, the airport is calling in the feds. Airport commissioners hired experts from the Department of Agriculture's Animal Damage Control unit _ pigeon killers as they're known by some airport workers _ to eliminate birds of a feather. ``We've run out of solutions. It's time to get some outside assistance,'' said Mario Polselli, the airport's chief of airfield operations. Bird ingestion, as aviators call it, can seriously hurt a plane's machinery, forcing pilots to dump fuel over the ocean and circle back for unscheduled landings. In the last year, three jetliners sucked birds into their engines at the airport, costing the airlines thousands of dollars in wasted fuel and time. Among the solutions being considered by the unit are paving over fields where birds roost, plugging building holes so birds can't make nests and cutting down trees that have seeds that birds like. And if all that doesn't work, the unit might also lay out something called porcupine wire that is covered in needles or play tape recordings of bird distress calls. Wildlife experts, who will spend about a year at the airport, say they have a tough task ahead. ``LAX is going to be a real test because it's located along a bird migratory route, but we should be able to make a dent,'' said biologist Judy Loven.

DOC.HEAD: Police Report Two More Bodies Found in Student Apartments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, ``On the campus ...,'' to CORRECT that Lake City girl was 12 years old, not 14. Note contents of 17th graf, `The Sun...'
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of a man and a woman were found at a student apartment complex today, a day after police said they believed the grisly deaths of three young women were linked. Law enforcement authorities said they didn't know whether the fourth and fifth deaths were related to the earlier slayings. But they said they were investigating the latest deaths as a possible double murder, and state officials braced for that possibility. ``It looks like it's a part of a serial killer,'' state university system Chancellor Charles Reed said today in Tallahassee. ``It's a community problem. It's not just a university problem. We are taking every precaution we possibly can.'' There were no plans to cancel classes, but students were being encouraged to stay on campus, Reed said. ``We think our campus is more secure than the surrounding community right now,'' he said. Gov. Bob Martinez urged that young people avoid staying alone in this college community, where fall classes opened Monday at the University of Florida and nearby Santa Fe Community College. Alachua Sheriff's Lt. Spencer Mann said the bodies of a man and a woman were found together at about 8:30 a.m. at an apartment complex near one where two bodies were found Sunday. Police set up a command post between those sites and the spot about two miles from where a third body was discovered early Monday. Martinez said authorities weren't speculating that a ``Ted Bundy copycat'' serial killer was on the loose, but the governor said the FBI and ``out-of-state experts'' are involved in the investigation. FBI agents joined Gainesville authorities Monday, and Martinez dispatched the state police mobile crime lab to Gainesville. On the campus, the slayings stirred memories of Bundy. He was executed in Florida's electric chair on Jan. 24, 1989, after murdering dozens of young women, including two Florida State University students in Tallahassee in a 1978 rampage he followed with the murder of a 12-year-old schoolgirl in Lake City. ``That's what we're all saying. It's another Ted Bundy on the loose,'' Jana Walters, 18, a freshman from Longwood, Fla., said Monday. ``Some sicko.'' Adding to fears was the mysterious disappearance of Tiffany Sessions, a 20-year-old UF student who vanished after leaving her Gainesville apartment to go jogging on Feb. 9, 1989. Authorities have declined to give details on the bodies and the possible links. The Gainesville Sun, however, reported today that the mutilations of the bodies at the two separate apartments was the apparent connection. Two of the victims, who shared a townhouse apartment, were identified as second-semester freshmen Christina P. Powell, 17, of Jacksonville and Sonya Larson, 18, of Deerfield Beach. Their bodies were found Sunday afternoon. Eight hours later, at another southwest Gainesville apartment about two miles away, Alachua County deputies found the body of Christa L. Hoyt, 18, a student at nearby Santa Fe Community College and a full-time records clerk at the Alachua County Sheriff's Office, the college's President Lawrence Tyree said Monday. ``The two crimes could have been done by the same individual,'' Gainesville Police Chief Wayland Clifton said Monday. ``The method of operation in these cases are similar.'' The Sun quoted unidentified sources as saying that Ms. Hoyt had been decapitated and her breasts mutilated, while at least one of the other victims had her nipples cut off. Police would not confirm the reports but feared more killings were possible because of the gruesomeness of the slayings. ``I don't think it takes a rocket scientist to figure out that anybody that commits homicide using mutilation is a pretty sick individual, and it's somebody we want to get off the streets very badly,'' said Spencer Mann, spokesman for the Alachua County Sheriff's Office. The weekend slayings prompted parents to flood the university and police with worried calls. More than three-fourths of the 34,000 students live off campus. University President John Lombardi and other officials spent Monday trying to soothe the fears of anxious parents. The university, which advised students to make reassuring calls home, established a free phone bank because many students' telephones have not yet been connected. The first two bodies were discovered after the parents of Ms. Powell, trying to contact their daughter before fall classes started Monday, had police open the door. One victim was nude and the other was partly clothed, said Lt. Sadie Darnell, a Gainesville police spokesman. Ms. Powell's body was found in the living room of their apartment, while Ms. Larson's body was found in a second-floor bedroom. The body of Ms. Hoyt was discovered by Alachua County deputies after she failed to show up for work, Mann said. He said there was trauma to the teen-ager's body, but he refused to elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Meteorologist: Hurricane Gustav No Present Threat to Land
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with noon advisories on Gustav, Hortense. Picks up penultimate graf, `Both Gustav...'
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Gustav was taking its 105 mph winds northward into the open Atlantic Ocean today after curving away from the northeastern Caribbean islands, the National Hurricane Center reported. ``Gustav continues moving northward. The only threat to land would be only four days away in Bermuda,'' Ray Fagen, a meteorologist at the center in suburban Coral Gables, said this morning. ``We see a northerly course which would put it within 300 miles of Bermuda in four days.'' ``But it's definitely not a certainty that Bermuda would be hit,'' he added. At noon EDT, Gustav's center was located near 20.8 degrees north latitude and 58.0 degrees west longitude, or about 390 miles northeast of Antigua. It was moving northward at about 15 mph and was expected to hold that course and speed for the next 24 hours. Meteorologists watching Gustav believe it's unlikely the hurricane will turn towards the U.S. East Coast as it makes its way north. ``The chances would be maybe one in 50. It's just the way the steering currents are setting up. It'd be more likely to curve to the northeast than to the northwest,'' Fagen said. Gustav's path skirted the Leeward Islands and hurricane warnings there were dropped by midday Monday. All other storm warnings and watches issued Sunday for the area were later dropped. But islands in the northeastern Caribbean could get rough seas and swells during the day today, forecasters said. Gustav's hurricane-force winds this morning extended 35 miles from its center, with tropical storm-force winds extending outward 175 miles. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Hortense remained about a thousand miles to the east in the mid-Atlantic, a danger only to shipping. At noon Tuesday, Hortense, the eighth named storm of the Atlantic season, had winds of 65 mph. It was moving north northwest at about 10 mph. The storm was centered near 22.6 degrees north latitude and 44.1 degrees west longitude, or about 1,310 miles west-northwest of the Cape Verde islands. Little change in its strength was expected for the next 24 hours. Both Gustav and Hortense were born as tropical depressions near the Cape Verde islands off West Africa, like many of history's worst hurricanes. Tropical depressions become tropical storms when their sustained top winds reach 39 mph. Tropical storms become hurricanes at 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Students Brave Rain To Protest Job Quotas
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of university students danced and clapped to the beat of anti-government slogans in heavy rain Tuesday to protest a proposed job policy they say is discriminatory. In a separate protest, about 500 students from New Delhi's medical colleges marched to Prime Minister V.P. Singh's house and demanded the proposals be withdrawn. Singh announced this month that the government would reserve 27 percent of government jobs for ``socially backward'' castes. On Monday, he said quotas also will be introduced for lower income groups, irrespective of caste. Already, 22.5 percent of the jobs are held for lower castes and tribes. If implemented, the new proposals would raise the percentage of reserved jobs to between 54 percent and 59 percent. The remainder would be awarded on merit. ``This has divided the student community. It has brought the illegal caste system to the fore,'' said Ranjit Manchanda, a student at the All India Institute of Medical Sciences, the country's top medical college. Opponents also say the quota system would lead to the employment and promotion of unqualified people and heighten caste tensions. Discrimination on the basis of caste is illegal. But in practice, the four-tier Hindu caste system, which determines a person's social standing, is widely prevalant in India, especially in villages. The four castes are divided into hundreds of sub-castes. About 85 percent of India's 880 million people are Hindus, and the high castes among the community hold the majority of government jobs. They also are generally richer than the lower castes. Nationwide protests against the new quota proposals started three weeks ago. In New Delhi, students have repeatedly enforced general strikes, blocked traffic and damaged government-run buses during the past week. Tuesday's downpour did not appear to have broken the tempo of the protest. Demonstrations were largely peaceful in the morning. It started raining after noon when the students of the medical colleges and those of the Delhi University began their marches. The students stood in the rain for more than two hours, chanting, ``V.P. Singh down! Down!'' and ``Who acts like Hitler will die like Hitler.'' The protest ended after some protesters commandeered city buses for drenched colleagues. Others walked in the rain, and some forced drivers of private vehicles and motor scooter taxis to take them home. Mounted and riot police watched from a distance. ``Don't worry. We will fight to the last. If the government does not listen to us, we know what to do,'' said a teen-ager, brandishing a stone as he climbed aboard a packed bus.

DOC.HEAD: With Crack in the Spotlight, Gang Made Millions Selling Heroin
DOC.TEXT: Crack gangs waging bloody turf battles held the attention of many law enforcers in the late 1980s, while behind the scenes one violent gang scenes made millions peddling heroin and cocaine, authorities say. Jury selection begins Wednesday in the trial of what prosecutors describe as the one of the city's most lucrative street-level drug gangs. From early in 1986 until his arrest 2{ years later, Ricardo Melendez and his followers built up a network that raked in as much as $8 million to $10 million a month from some of Brooklyn's poorest neighborhoods by selling drugs out of abandoned buildings and storefronts, according to authorities. ``There used to be block-long lines of people waiting to get their hands on this stuff,'' Detective Robert Alongi, an investigator in the case, told the Daily News. When police and federal drug agents raided Melendez' apartment two years ago, money was everywhere, they said _ 6-inch high stacks of $10, $20, $50 and $100 bills spread across the kitchen floor. Some 300 pounds of cash was found in the apartment, totaling $2.38 million. The trial, with some 150 witnesses, is expected to last as long as three months. Melendez, 30, who is being held without bail, and his nine co-defendants are charged with several drug conspiracy counts that incorporate numerous drug-related slayings, kidnapping, tortures and beatings aimed at maintaining discipline in the organization and keeping out competing drug dealers. They face life in prison if convicted. Former Melendez employees and rival drug dealers will take the stand to tell jurors how Melendez and his lieutenants yanked out teeth, cut off fingers or broke bones as punishment for stealing from the organization or selling drugs in its territory, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Peter R. Ginsberg. One witness says Melendez kept a ``souvenir'' jar filled with teeth of victims he had tortured or beaten, authorities said in court Monday. Alleged threats to prosecutors and to the families of anyone who testified against Melendez prompted U.S. District Judge Arthur Spatt to keep secret jurors' first names, addresses and their jobs ``to insulate them from improper influence.'' Security was tight when the defendants, several of whom are free on bail, appeared for final pretrial hearings Monday. Spatt, citing an account of Melendez' drug operation published Monday in the Daily News, imposed a gag order directing prosecutors and defense lawyers to not speak with reporters about the case. Melendez was first arrested on heroin charges in 1985. He jumped $50,000 bail just before the start of his trial and was convicted and sentenced in absentia to 25 years to life in prison. According to court records, his gang employed up to 100 people _ paying hourly wages to some low-level workers _ and his drugs sales paid for luxury clothes, jewelry, gambling trips and Mercedes-Benz cars. Defense lawyer Lawrence Hochheiser said that with the publicity and the public frustration with drugs, defending Melendez would be difficult in a case involving such violent crimes and such hugh sums of money. ``Anyone in a narcotics case already has two strikes against them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 2,600-Acre Blaze That Killed 2 Firefighters Rages Out of Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with acreage downgraded, new containment and control times, other details. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `Sheriff Edd...' Edd is cq.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Indian Firefighters, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A wildfire that killed two firefighters, razed 19 houses and blackened more than 2,600 acres of timber and brush defied control today, although its progress slowed, officials said. Three hundred firefighters used aerial tankers, water-bearing helicopters and bulldozers to cut fire lines in an all-out assault on the blaze, which they expected to contain from spreading by late tonight. Authorities said they hoped to have the fire under control by Wednesday evening. ``Today's the first day we actually have the resources in place to man the whole fire,'' said Gary Laing, the Interagency Fire Management Team's operations manager. ``We don't have a stranglehold on it yet,'' added incident commander John Shive. ``But we're going for its throat.'' After completing an overnight survey of the fire, officials today downgraded its acreage to 2,600 acres from earlier estimates of 3,000 acres. Two firefighters died Sunday night when the blaze exploded in size because of winds gusting to 60 mph. The victims were trapped between advancing flames and a precipice. Wasatch County sheriff's Deputy Blake Wright, 39, and county road crew worker Ralph Broadhead, 65, were found near the bulldozer they had been using to cut a fireline near an area known as Devil's Hole. Hundres of homes in the Wasatch Mountain area were threatened, but the fire had to move downhill to advance, fire spokesman Dick Buehler said. Flames move faster uphill. Smoke hung along the face of the scorched mountains west of Midway this morning, as cool air created an inversion holding the hotter air close to the ground. Afternoon winds were expected to again fan the flames, however. ``It's asleep right now,'' Shive said of the fire. ``It'll explode again. But this time we're waiting for it.'' The cause of the fire was under investigation. State Forester Dick Klason speculated that it was sparked by an ember blown over from a small fire near Cascade Springs. He estimated the cost of fighting and cleaning up after the blaze could exceed $3 million. Sheriff Edd Thacker said the two firefighters who died apparently had tried to cut a buffer between themselves and the fire. Investigators said temperatures rocketed to nearly 1,100 degrees in the area, melting the bulldozer's windows. ``They did what they were supposed to do,'' he said. ``It was a firestorm. The fire was coming at them and they did the best they could.'' Wright was a 10-year law enforcement veteran with six children and Broadhead was within weeks of retirement, Thacker said. ``It's going be hard on everybody,'' he said. ``We've known them both for years. It's just awful.''

DOC.HEAD: President Hooked in the Ear While Fishing with Mulroney
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts new 6-9th grafs bgng ``Bush's press'' to confirm Jeb hooked Bush; picks up 7th graf prvs bgng ``It was''
DOC.TEXT: Someone on a fishing excursion Tuesday with President Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney hooked a big one _ the president himself. Camera crew members in a news boat following close behind said Mulroney appeared to be responsible for the hook that caught Bush's ear, a notion the Canadian prime minister did nothing to dispell. ``It was not a hostile act,'' Mulroney said. However, first lady Barbara Bush, who said her husband ``is fine,'' disputed that Mulroney was the culprit. She summoned son Jeb, who was also on the boat, and commanded him to tell reporters just who had hooked his father. Jeb just grinned sheepishly. Did Mulroney hook Bush? ``That is really not true,'' he said and walked away. Bush's press secretary Marlin Fitzwater later confirmed that Jeb was responsible for accidentally piercing his father's right ear lobe. Bush's physician on an accompanying boat attended to the wound. He snipped the fish hook with wirecutters and pulled the remainder of the hook through the ear, according to Fitzwater. ``The president was strong and courageous throughout this exercise,'' Fitzwater told reporters traveling back to Washington with Bush aboard Air Force One. Fitzwater said the hook passed through the bottom, rounded part of the president's ear lobe. Bush continued to fish for about another hour and later received a tetanus shot. When he boarded Air Force One later in the morning no evidence of a wound or bandage could be seen. It was the second boating mishap involving Bush and Mulroney. On Monday, Bush's boat broke down while the president was taking the Canadian leader and his family for a ride. A small Coast Guard boat was summoned to rescue the party. The boat was fixed over night.

DOC.HEAD: Contacts With Vietnam, Cambodia Urged
DOC.TEXT: It may be time for the United States to open avenues of trade with communist Vietnam and Cambodia as a prelude to United Nations-sponsored elections in Cambodia, Sen. Richard Lugar said Tuesday. ``We ought to sketch conditions for easing restrictions on commerce with Vietnam and Cambodia,'' the Indiana Republican told reporters. Developmental loans for Vietnam could be a first step, he said. Lugar just returned from a two-week, seven-nation trip to East Asia. In Vietnam, he met with foreign minister Nguyen Co Thach, who sought to highlight market reforms made in his country's economy. Thach assured him that all Vietnamese forces have been withdrawn from Cambodia, where they had fought to push the feared Khmer Rouge from power, Lugar said. Vietnam supports current peace efforts by the United Nations, would accept any government installed in Cambodia through free and fair elections, and would agree to continued non-lethal U.S. aid to the non-communist resistance now fighting the Vietnamese-installed regime of Hun Sen in Phnom Penh, he said. Lugar said he found a clear interest among American business interests in Thailand, Hong Kong and Seoul in reopening commerce with the two countries, and said other nations already are quietly doing so.

DOC.HEAD: Venus Mapping Delayed to Late September as Engineers Probe Magellan Woes
DOC.TEXT: Magellan's mission to map the rugged surface of Venus is being delayed again so a team of engineers can figure out why the spacecraft keeps losing contact with Earth, a NASA official said Tuesday. ``We're targeting for the last week in September to start mapping,'' said Tony Spear, Magellan project manager at the space agency's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Spear had said Friday that engineers hoped to fix the problem in time to have Magellan working properly by mid-September. Before Magellan started malfunctioning, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration planned for it to make pictures and maps of Venus on a regular basis starting Sept. 1. The spaceship remained in a protective ``safing mode'' Tuesday, Spear said during an interview. Engineers still haven't figured out why Magellan's radio link to Earth failed for 14 hours starting Aug. 16 and for 17{ hours beginning Aug. 21, he added. So Spear said he organized a ``tiger team'' of 40 engineers from the laboratory and from Martin Marietta Corp., which built Magellan in Denver, to determine what is wrong with the spaceship and fix it. Magellan's $744 million mission is to use radar to peer through Venus' thick clouds and make the best pictures and maps yet of the planet's surface. It was launched from space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989. Pictures made during an Aug. 16 radar test showed extensive ``Venusquake'' faults, vast flows of solidified lava, cinder cones, a lava-filled meteorite impact crater and countless valleys and mountain ridges on the surface of Earth's nearest planetary neighbor. Spear said one major theory is that something went wrong when Magellan entered orbit around Venus on Aug. 10. It functioned almost flawlessly during the 15 months it traveled a looping path of 948 million miles from Earth. Spear ruled out the possibility, raised Friday, that Magellan's braking rocket may have failed to separate from the spacecraft after it went into Venus orbit. Mapping is being delayed not only because time is needed to fix Magellan, but also because the spacecraft's troubles have left engineers ``mentally and physically exhausted,'' Spear said. ``We've decided to give the team three days off around Labor Day.'' Engineers want to make sure Magellan doesn't break down again when mapping is in progress because ``it's not good for people's hearts,'' he added. Spear, fully aware of NASA's problems stemming from temporary grounding of the shuttle fleet and a severe defect on the Hubble Space Telescope, appealed to the public to have patience with Magellan. ``We're going to make it work,'' he pledged. ``Have confidence in us. We have one of the world's best teams working on this problem.'' Spear said the tiger team is divided into four groups. One will try to understand and fix the overall problem. The second will look at the environment around Venus to determine if previously unknown electrical fields or particles are disrupting Magellan's electronics. The third group will examine changes on Magellan as it went into orbit, including the possibility of short circuits in plugs that once connected the braking rocket to the spaceship. The fourth group will study a backup computer that helps point Magellan. Spear said the computer ran amok during both loss-of-contact incidents.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Saddam Visits Western Hostages; Offers Talks with Bush, Thatcher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd, `The White...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with State Department reaction. Pickup 3rd, `Mrs. Thatcher...'
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein today visited foreign families held hostage in Iraq and told them he was willing to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis with President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Saddam said he was ``ready and prepared for direct talks with Mr. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher. ... Let us have the debate between me and them on television for the whole world to see.'' Margaret Tutwiler, a State Department spokeswoman in Washington, quickly dismissed Saddam's offer, saying: ``It's sick, and it doesn't even deserve a response. Come on, there is nothing to debate.'' Mrs. Thatcher was visitng Finland today, but a spokeswomen in Britain said: ``I'm not in a position to give an immediate reaction except to say I don't think the position has changed ... The bottom line is that he (Saddam) has to get out of Kuwait before any discussion can occur.'' The Iraqi president's meeting with several hostage families was shown on Iraqi television and broadcast by Cable News Network. In its report on the meeting, the Iraqi News Agency said Saddam also ordered that one unidentified British family be allowed to return home. It was not immediately clear what countries the foreigners were from, or when and where the meeting occurred. One woman with a British accent asked Saddam why he was using children in ``in something they can't undersand.'' He gave a long answer in which he repeated that his hand was forced by Western troops massing in the region. He also complained that the international trade embargo against Iraq was reducing food and medicine supplies in his country. Saddam said ``children will be undernourished'' and could become ill and die. He said the cutoff of medicine could cause outbreaks of disease. ``When food is cut off from a society then you're actually choking the society to death,'' Saddam told one of the Western hostages. As the broadcast began, Saddam was shown entering a large room and greeting the Western families, shaking hands with men and patting children on the head. Dressed in a brown suit and tie instead of his military uniform, he smiled as he greeted the foreigners. He then sat down to make a statement through a translator at his side. He told the families he knew that they were feeling restricted, and ``If my family were in your place I would have the same feelings.'' But he said, ``Politicians are forced sometimes to take a position that goes beyond what they see directly in front of them. ``If it had to do with human feelings towards you ... then I would immediately say you should leave and go back to your families.'' But he told them that their presence was needed to prevent an attack. It was the second time Saddam visited hostage families in a broadcast intended for Western consumption. He was widely condemned for his first visit last week, which was seen as a crude attempt to gain Western sympathy. In today's broadcast, he told the foreigners that although he understood they were in ``a difficult sort of situation'': ``When we put the issue in a larger context... in the event of a possible military clash (with) the armies that have come to the area ... and if we suppose that your presence here in Iraq for this period would prevent such a clash, then we would find ourselves in a position in which we are forced ... to take the sort of decision that we have taken.'' Saddam has used the same justification in the past for his detention of about 21,000 foreigners, including 3,000 Americans and 3,000 Britons, who were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait at the time of the Aug. 2 invasion. British and U.S. officials say Iraq has moved more than 150 Britons and more than 60 Americans from Kuwait to strategic locations for use as ``human shields'' against a possible attack by the U.S.-led forces. The Iraqi leader made no mention in the broadcast of the British family reportedly being allowed to leave. The Iraqi News Agency said that ``President Saddam Hussein ordered that one of the British families be allowed to return to their country as a generous gesture by his excellency on the occasion of the family celebrating the birthday of its child, Rachel.'' The dispatch did not reveal the family's surname, although it said the family ``expressed its great gratitude and appreciation.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actress Rachel Ward retreated to Australia after the film ``Against All Odds'' and produced two children, giving her the most demanding role of her life. ``There isn't much time for anything other than raising them, is there? That just about takes up all of your time, if you're doing it properly,'' Miss Ward said on a promotion tour for her new movie ``After Dark, My Sweet.'' She said 5-year-old Rosie and 3-year-old Matilda are a handful, but the high-profile life of a celebrity doesn't appeal to her. ``I didn't really feel that that was particularly rewarding,'' she said. ``If you do that you have a chance to be in a lot of movies and stuff. But just being in the movies ultimately isn't enough.'' Last year, she portrayed an overly materialistic wife in ``How to Get Ahead in Advertising.''

Former President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, have returned to Minnesota to undergo routine physical examinations at the Mayo Clinic, where he underwent skull surgery a year earlier. The Reagans arrived at the Rochester airport Monday afternoon on a private plane. Reagan waved to a small group of people gathered at the airport, then police led them to their hotel in a motorcade. Asked how he thought President Bush was handling the Persian Gulf situation, Reagan said: ``Fine.'' Reagan, 79, lives in the Bel-Air section of Los Angeles. ``Both President and Mrs. Reagan are feeling fine, and these examinations have been on their calendar for several months,'' Reagan spokesman Mark Weinberg said in a statement. Reagan was at the Mayo Clinic a year ago for surgery to remove a pool of blood that formed on his brain after a fall from a horse. The surgery was performed Sept. 8 and Reagan left Rochester Sept. 15.

Dr. Thomas E. Starzl, who performed the world's first successful liver transplant, was released from the hospital Tuesday, four days after undergoing heart surgery. Starzl, 64, underwent a coronary artery bypass operation Friday at Presbyterian University Hospital, where he has performed hundreds of transplant operations. ``He's doing very well,'' said Dr. Bruce Wilson, Starzl's cardiologist. ``He walked up and down the halls yesterday.'' Wilson said Starzl probably would rest at home for a couple of weeks before returning to work. In 1967 at the University of Colorado, Starzl performed the first successful liver transplant. In 1981, Starzl began work at Presbyterian University Hospital, which he helped make one of the world's premier transplant centers. Last year, the hospital performed more than 460 liver transplants and 210 kidney transplants.

Japanese director Akira Kurosawa, whose film ``Akira Kurosawa's Dreams'' opened in New York last week to excellent reviews, is at work on his next project, ``Rhapsody in August.'' The film, to be shot on location throughout Japan, tells the story of a family's reconciliation with Japanese-American relatives who have been long out of contact. It is scheduled for release next summer. ``Rhapsody in August'' will feature the 85-year-old Japanese actress Sachiko Murase and will also have American star Richard Gere in a supporting role. Director Martin Scorsese appears as Vincent van Gogh in ``Dreams,'' the 80-year-old Kurosawa's first film in five years. Kurosawa's other movies include ``Seven Sumarai,'' ``Ran'' and ``Rashomon,'' which won the Academy Award for best foreign film in 1951.

Legendary bluesman John Lee Hooker, who has released more than 100 albums in his 60-year career, is the honored guest at an Oct. 16 all-star benefit concert to benefit the Delta Blues Museum. Hooker will play with an assortment of his contemporaries and current performers, including Willie Dixon, Bo Diddley, Greg Allman, Al Kooper and Albert Collins. The show is set for Madison Square Garden. ``If you're feeling low, the blues pick you up like a spirit,'' Hooker said in explaining his longtime appeal. ``The blues are hot. They're being appreciated the way they should have been appreciated a long time ago.'' Hooker, 71, was born in Clarksdale, Miss., which is now the home to the Delta Blues Museum.

DOC.HEAD: Two Rebels Surrender, Taylor Invited To Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Two Liberian rebels surrendered to an African task force and said hundreds more want to give up but fear reprisals from rebel leader Charles Taylor, the Ghana News Agency reported Tuesday. The news agency, which has a reporter with the five-nation force sent to Liberia, said the two rebels handed over their automatic rifles and ammunition Monday. The rebels said other members of Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front were looking for an intermediary to help them surrender. Taylor has opposed the intervention of the African force to end Liberia's 8-month-old civil war. He accuses the force, comprised of 3,000 soldiers from Ghana, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Gambia, of supporting President Samuel Doe of Liberia. Both Doe, and Prince Johnson, leader of another rebel army at odds with Taylor's, have welcomed the task force. Rebels began their armed struggle on Christmas Eve, accusing Doe of corruption and human rights abuses during his 10 years of rule. Representatives of Liberian opposition parties and church groups met Tuesday in the Gambian capital, Banjul, to discuss ways of ending the war, which has killed at least 5,000 people, including many civilians. After meeting for several hours, those attending voted to invite Taylor to come to Banjul for talks. Two months ago, Taylor's rebels appeared on the brink of winning the war, but forces loyal to Doe blocked them on the outskirts of Monrovia. Johnson, who had broken with Taylor, launched a surprise attack on the city and took control of most of it. Doe remains in his heavily fortified mansion. Taylor has sent emissaries to West African capitals to try to arouse opposition to the force's presence in Liberia. Thus far only one country, Burkina Faso, has issued an outright condemnation.

DOC.HEAD: American Dies in Iraq of Apparent Heart Attack
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with new Pentagon cost estimates, more Americans rounded up; picks up 8th graf pvs, In Baghdad...; trims at end to tighten
DOC.TEXT: An unidentified American being held in Iraq has died, the State Department said today, quoting Iraqi authorities. The American was reported to be a man in his mid-50s who died of a heart attack. The department also disclosed that Iraq plans to expel an unspecified number of Americans from the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad in response to the U.S. decision on Monday to order 36 Iraqi envoys out of the United States by Thursday. In addition, the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad was told that unspecified restrictions will be placed on embassy funds, department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. The Pentagon, meanwhile, said Iraq's troop strength in and near Kuwait has increased to 265,000 soldiers. ``There's been a general trend in the past several days of these numbers increasing,'' spokesman Pete Williams said. The Pentagon also estimated the total costs of the Desert Shield operation through the end of September at $2.5 billion, nearly double the previous estimate of $1.3 billion. Williams said the sharply increased costs can be attributed to the expense of calling up reserve and National Guard forces, increased operations for ships and aircraft and to increased fuel costs. As for the dead American, the Iraqi Foreign Ministry said he died in the Iraqi city of Basra and that his body would be turned over to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. The State Department, in a statement released this morning, said it could not confirm the cause of death or the identity of the American. Later, Ms. Tutwiler said the death ``underscores the barbaric nature of Iraqi policy towards foreign nationals in Iraq and Kuwait, and makes a lie of Iraq's claim that they are all well treated and in no danger.'' She said nine Americans have been taken into custody by Iraqi authorities since Monday, bringing the total to 70 _ 48 in Iraq and 22 in Kuwait. She said reports have been received that more Americans have escaped from the two countries but she had no further details. In Baghdad, the press attache at the U.S. Embassy, Stephen Thibeault, said that according to the Iraqis an American had died in Basra, a southern port in Iraq. He said the 56-year-old man apparently died of a heart attack, and was believed one of those who had been detained by the Iraqis. Thibeault, in a telephone interview from Baghdad, said there was no positive identification on the American ``because we have not been given access to the American citizen yet. The Iraqi authorities have said that they would allow us to participate in any autopsy.'' CNN said the man was one of the 63 Americans being held hostage as ``human shields'' against any U.S. attack. It quoted U.S. charge d'affaires Joseph Wilson as saying the man had been taken from Kuwait to a strategic site in Basra. Meanwhile, 36 Iraqi envoys face a Thursday deadline to leave the country, targets of what the State Department calls a measured response to almost a month of ``blatant'' Iraqi misbehavior. A U.S. diplomatic message was delivered to Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat on Monday afternoon, serving notice that the affected diplomats must be gone within 72 hours. The move was in retaliation for a series of Iraqi actions, especially the ``illegal order'' for the closure of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, Ms. Tutwiler said. The department also restricted the remaining Iraqi diplomats here to a radius of 25 miles from the Iraqi Embassy in Washington. It said all Iraqi diplomatic visas will be switched to single entry from multiple entry. Procedures for approving visa applications from private Iraqi citizens also will be tightened. The 19 Iraqi diplomats permitted to remain in the United States, including Al-Mashat, reflect the number of Americans accredited to the U.S. embassies in Iraq and Kuwait. At a news conference at his Maine vacation home, President Bush said the United States was ``trying to keep a reasonable parallel in terms of numbers.'' Ms. Tutwiler said the ``measured'' steps were being taken in response to the ``blatant disregard'' Iraq has shown for international law, in particular the moves against the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Al-Mashat said outside the embassay that the expulsion order was ``unfair and unjustified.'' ``We feel we have been victimized once more,'' he said. Among the Iraqis expelled are seven accredited diplomats, including all those who deal with commercial affairs. Those diplomats became expendable after Bush suspended all commercial transactions with Iraq following its invasion of Kuwait. Iraq had ordered all embassies in Kuwait to shut down by last Friday, but the United States and a number of other countries have defied the order. Since then, Iraqi authorities have cut off water and electricity at the U.S. Embassy and are restricting all personnel to the embassy grounds. Ms. Tutwiler said the reduced U.S. embassy staff in Kuwait has enough food and water only to last several more days. Power is being supplied by a generator. The United States has refused to close its embassy in Kuwait because it does not want to lend legitimacy to Iraq's conquest and subsequent annexation of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Need for Repeat Cesarean Deliveries Questioned
DOC.TEXT: A survey released Tuesday casts new doubt on the old notion that women who have given birth by cesarean section must always deliver that way. The survey of 2,213 physicians by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists found that 63 percent of women who attempt vaginal delivery after a previous cesarean section succeed. ``Strides certainly have been made'' to convince women and their physicians that vaginal deliveries are safe and successful alternatives to repeat cesareans, said Dr. Mary Jo O'Sullivan, secretary of the organization. But she said since about 42 percent of the patients in the survey chose to have another cesarean, ``there is a need to further educate women'' about the benefits of vaginal deliveries. Vaginal deliveries are less risky than cesarean sections mainly because the latter is a surgical procedure, said O'Sullivan, associate chairwoman of obstetrics at the University of Miami in Florida. Also, vaginal births are less expensive and the patient spends less time in the hospital _ an average of $4,334 and two or three days compared with $7,186 and four or five days for a cesarean, according to 1989 data from the Health Insurance Association of America. The rate of cesarean deliveries rose from 5.5 percent of all U.S. births in 1970 to 24.7 percent in 1988. But O'Sullivan noted that the increase from 1986-87 and from 1987-88 was 0.3 percent, the smallest rise in five years. Also, the rate of vaginal births after cesareans rose from 2.2 percent in 1970 to 12.6 percent in 1988, she said. O'Sullivan said the rate of repeat cesareans appears to be tied to the age of the physician. Ninety-eight percent of physicians under 40 said they encourage their cesarean patients to have vaginal deliveries for subsequent births, compared to 84 percent of physicians over 55. ``It takes a long time to change your practice pattern,'' O'Sullivan said, noting that some smaller hospitals still do not offer the option of vaginal delivery to women with a previous cesarean. As recently as 15 years ago vaginal birth after a cesarean was not considered good medicine in the United States, though a standard practice for years in many other countries. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the largest professional organization for physicians in those specialties, recommends that women who have had a low transverse incision in a previous delivery and have no medical complications should be encouraged to attempt labor and vaginal delivery in their current pregnancy. A low transverse incision, which cuts into a non-contracting portion of the uterus, is most commonly used in cesareans today. It largely replaced what is called the classical incision in which the contracting muscles of the uterus are cut and are more likely to rupture in a subsequent labor.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Slip In Early Domestic Trading; Dollar, Oil Prices Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with later stock trading. Picks up 4th graf, `Tokyo's major...' Version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were mixed on Wall Street today after rallying in Tokyo and London, while oil prices were mixed in early New York trading. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 10.64 to 2,600.99 as of 2 p.m. on Wall Street after having changed direction several times. But the broader market was moderately higher. Advancing issues were ahead of decliners by a margin of about 7 to 6, with 769 stocks rising, 661 falling and 489 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Stock prices rose in cautious, light trading in London, where the financial markets were closed Monday for a bank holiday. The broad-based Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed up 39.7 points, or 1.9 percent. Tokyo's major index, the Nikkei Stock Average, gained 569.00 points, or 2.26 percent, following increases of 976 points Monday and 428.13 Friday. Since the Middle East crisis erupted after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Nikkei index had lost a total of 6,239.87 points, or 20.23 percent, through Thursday. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the October-delivery price of light, sweet crude oil was up 24 cents in midmorning trading to $27.15 a barrel. But the prices of later contract months dropped. On Monday, the October contract dropped $4 to close at $26.91 a barrel. Oil prices were bid down on the assumption that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting in Vienna would agree to boost output to offset the shortages left by the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The dollar, meanwhile, tumbled against the Japanese yen but was higher against most major currencies. In midmorning New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 143.53 yen, down 0.70 from Monday's New York close. But it was up slightly against the German mark and British pound. In London, the dollar was quoted at 143.10 yen and it was slightly lower against the pound. But the dollar edged higher against the mark, Swiss franc and most other currencies in Europe. Earlier, the dollar fell to 143.20 yen in Japan, down 1.60 yen from Monday's close. Currency dealers said the dollar's weakness in Japan carried over from a drop Monday in New York. Dealers said Japanese investors were selling the dollar to buy the yen based on an optimistic view of the chances for a negotiated settlement to the Gulf crisis. ``Investors think there will be no war at least until Thursday,'' when United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar reportedly meets with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, said Akiko Baba, a Bank of Tokyo dealer.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Criticize U.S. Action Expelling Iraqis
DOC.TEXT: The explusion of some Iraqi diplomats from Washington could raise Persian Gulf tensions, the Soviet Union warned Tuesday in the latest indication of the nation's reluctance to match harsh U.S. measures. ``I don't believe that we have to add fuel to the fire in this explosive situation,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov. ``Of course Iraq's actions to close embassies in Kuwait are illegitimate,'' he added. ``But if you use a tit-for-tat policy in this question, you risk falling down the spiral of escalation and aggravating the situation.'' The United States has ordered 36 Iraqi Embassy personnel to leave Washington by Thursday and imposed travel limits on the 19 envoys allowed to remain. It has been unable to persuade its allies to expel Iraqi diplomats from other capitals. The move followed Iraqi demands that foreign countries close their embassies in Kuwait. The United States and several other nations have defied the order. But the Soviet Union pulled its diplomats from Kuwait, citing security reasons. Gerasimov said the Soviet Union had no plans to expel Iraqi diplomats. ``We want to move with caution ... We have to be real delicate,'' he said. Although the Soviet Union has joined the near universal condemnation of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, it has urged less confrontational measures against its longtime ally. The Soviet Union was Iraq's top arms supplier prior to the invasion, but has since cut off weapons shipments. The Soviet Union supported United Nations Security Council economic sanctions against Iraq. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze also joined U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III in an unusual joint statement denouncing the invasion. But the Soviets _ acting on a request from Iraq _ then delayed a security council vote to authorize a naval blockade to enforce the embargo. They also said they preferred diplomatic, rather than military, efforts to resolve the crisis. Yet last week, the Soviets voted along with other members of the Security Council to authorize the use of military force. ``We gave additional time for Iraq to have second thoughts,'' said Gerasimov. ``It was in vain, and so we decided not to prolong it again.'' Gerasimov also suggested some of Iraq's Arab neighbors have failed to put enough pressure on Iraq. ``A lot depends on the Arabs themselves ... They can make certain efforts to find a way out of that situation,'' he said. A group of 240 Soviet women and children arrived in Moscow on Tuesday after being evacuated from Iraq. A second group planned to leave either late Tuesday or early Wednesday, and all 983 dependents were scheduled to be home by Saturday. The Soviet Union had 7,791 citizens in Iraq, mostly oil workers, diplomats and dependents, officials have said. That number also includes 193 military advisers, who Soviet officials say are under contractual obligation to continue working for Iraq. Gerasimov denied accusations the Soviet Union had violated U.N. sanctions by keeping military advisers in Iraq. He said the sanctions do not cover the military experts, who teach Iraqi soldiers to use modern Soviet-built weapons. They also maintain and repair the hardware. ``Legally, there is no problem, but there is a moral aspect to that problem, so we recognize that and will try to resolve it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Praise Owl Plan Bush Administration Opposes
DOC.TEXT: Independent scientists praised a plan to protect the spotted owl Tuesday that the Bush administration has resisted accepting. Three of the scientists said they told a government task force examining the plan that it is one of the best issued on a threatened or endangered species. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. appointed the task force in June after the Fish and Wildlife Service declared the owl to be a threatened species throughout Oregon, Washington and northern California. They asked the panel to examine alternatives to the plan authored by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas and other government experts because they feared it would ban logging on millions of acres of old-growth forests and cost thousands of timber jobs by the end of the decade. ``They (the task force) asked us our opinion of the Jack Ward Thomas report, whether we thought it was a sound piece of work, and we said it had our unequivocal support,'' said Malcolm Hunter, a University of Maine biologist and author of a book on forestry. John Teer, a former Texas A&M biologist who heads the Welder Wildlife Federation in Texas, said to further compromise the Thomas committee's recommendations ``would be a travesty.'' ``It is one of the best reports on an environmental issue that has ever been issued _ much better than the average environmental impact statement required by the Environmental Protection Agency,'' he said. Hunter, Teer and North Carolina State forestry professor Richard Lancia said they told the task force about three weeks ago that the Thomas recommendations are the minimum necessary to protect the rare owl. The fourth scientist who appeared before the task force, Jim Carr of Virginia Polytechnic Institute, could not be reached for comment on Tuesday, but the other three said he agreed with them. ``This is a precedent-setting report in that the Thomas committee has in effect been able, or been willing, to sacrifice about half of the habitat to preserve the other half,'' said Teer, past president of the Wildlife Society, a 9,000-member association of professional biologists. The task force is scheduled to announce on Saturday its recommendations to protect the rare owl while minimizing the economic impact on the Northwest's timber industry.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Department Doubles Estimated Cost of Desert Shield
With PM-US-Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department has nearly doubled the estimated cost of the Desert Shield deployment of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, putting it at $2.5 billion, a spokesman said today. The sharply increased costs, up from an earlier estimate of $1.3 billion, can be attributed to the expense of calling up reserve and National Guard forces, increased operations for ships and aircraft and increased fuel costs, said Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. Other factors include increases in the number of C-130 aircraft in the gulf region and an increases in the number of aircraft carrier battle groups deployed there, Williams said. The cost estimate includes $1.13 billion for the Army, $494 million for the Navy, $556 million for defense agencies and $300 million to account for the increased fuel prices.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Cites Police Inaction in Blaze at Socialist Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: Premier Andrei Lukanov on Tuesday assailed police idleness at a fire that gutted the ruling Socialist Party headquarters but said it may be ``the price we have to pay'' for avoiding clashes with protesters. ``There is no justification for me for this lack of efficiency or passivity that was demonstrated by the forces of order,'' said Lukanov, who has demanded a government probe of the Sunday night blaze. Witnesses said police stood by for the first hour of the fire, started by a small group of demonstrators who broke away from a larger protest. Police eventually cleared a path for firefighters, who found that many of their hoses had been cut. The fire has been condemned by both anti-communist leaders and officials at the Socialist Party, the name adopted last year by the former Communist Party. But the two groups traded charges about who was responsible. Lukanov said the blaze would be investigated by police authorities while a a separate probe is conducted by the National Assembly. He said the government's ``policy of great restraint'' since a November 1989 party coup could explain some of the inaction by police at the fire scene. ``For a long time it worked,'' he said. On Nov. 10, 1989, longtime Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov was toppled in a party unheaval reportedly led by Lukanov; former President Petar Mladenov; and Defense Minister Dobri Dzhurov. The headquarters fire ``is the price we have to pay for the policy of avoiding open physical clashes between civilians and the militia,'' Lukanov said. The Socialist Party won national elections two months ago, but its popularity has fallen because of Bulgaria's deteriorating economy. Many items are rationed or in short supply. On Monday, Socialist Party chief Alexander Lilov blamed the fire on extremists among the political opposition. Addressing the National Assembly on Tuesday, Lilov said he detected the ``beginning of neo-fascism'' and predicted political extremism ``may throw the country into civil war.'' The Union of Democratic Forces, a 16-party opposition alliance, denied responsibility. Some opposition figures have suggested the Socialists could have started the fire in an attempt to discredit the protesters. Filip Bokov, a member of the Socialist Party's Supreme Council, termed the allegation ``preposterous.'' UDF officials said they would look into reports that Konstantin Trenchev, leader of the opposition Podkrepa labor federation, issued an ultimatum before the fire for the removal of the red star, the symbol of communist power, from atop the headquarters. ``If facts prove that Trenchev _ or in fact any other person _ contributed to Sunday night's events, we are of the opinion that such a person has no place in the UDF,'' spokesman Stoyan Ganev said.

DOC.HEAD: Medicare Paperwork To Become Physician's Burden
DOC.TEXT: The burden of Medicare reimbursement paperwork will shift next week from patients to physicians. Many physicians who don't already submit reimbursement claims for their elderly and disabled patients on Medicare see a clerical nightmare ahead. But advocates for the elderly see the change as needed relief from confusing and time-consuming paperwork that so confounds some Medicare beneficiaries that they don't file for benefits they are owed. ``The paperwork burden on Medicare beneficiaries has been tremendous,'' said Horace Deets, executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons. ``Now Medicare beneficiaries will receive the benefits to which they are entitled without having to deal with burdensome paperwork.'' A Physician Payment Review Commission poll in 1988 found nearly one in 10 Medicare beneficiaries did not file a Medicare claim for at least one bill they paid that year. Most often they said the forms were too complicated. These unfiled claims amounted to between $90 million and $130 million, the commission estimated. Most of the estimated 450 million Medicare Part B claims expected to be filed this fiscal year will have been submitted by physicians or medical suppliers, said Barbara Gagel, the government official responsible for implementing the new provision. About 10 percent of the bills are submitted by patients themselves, but Medicare officials do not know how many physicians this represents. Congress approved the change in filing requirements last year without much discussion, and some lawmakers now say it wasn't a wise idea. Rep. Joe Kolter, D-Pa., who introduced a bill last May to repeal the filing change, has received many letters from Medicare recipients as well as physicians who oppose the change. ``We think it's an unnecessary burden on physicians,'' said Bob Powers, Kolter's senior legislative assistant. ``We've gotten a lot of mail from Medicare recipients who are insulted'' because they feel the provision implies that they can't fill out the forms themselves, Powers said. ``They want to do it themselves,'' usually because they can do it faster than a physician's office staff can. Physicians will have up to a year to file claims, less than half the time now allowed. Failure to file would mean $1,000 fine for each violation. Doctors and suppliers cannot charge Medicare patients for preparing and filing claim forms. But, as is the case now, they can require payment from the patient at the time of service. Physicians generally don't foresee lengthy filing delays, although they expect the added work will increase their costs, forcing them to hire extra clerical help or buy computers to handle the chore. ``This is one of those instances where someone is trying to fix something that wasn't broken in the first place,'' said Dr. Joseph F. Boyle, executive vice president of the American Society of Internal Medicine. Dr. Norton J. Greenberger, president of the American College of Physicians, the largest professional organization of internists, said the change has a ``desirable goal'' of easing the paperwork burden on patients. It also will encourage electronic billing and could speed payments, he said. But some physicians see the change as ``further intrusion by the government into their office practices,'' he said. Initially at least, the government will accept a bill filed by a Medicare patient. When the beneficiary is paid, Medicare officials will inform him or her that the physician is supposed to file claims, said Gagel, an official of the Department of Health and Human Services. The impact on physicians will vary from state to state. An informal sampling by insurance carriers that process Medicare claims suggests it will have the most impact in Oregon, where the proportion of doctors who don't file patient claims was estimated at about 30 percent, she said. Indiana and Colorado were next with 13 percent and 12 percent, respectively. At the other end was Massachusetts, where nearly all physicians already file Medicare forms for their patients, Gagel said.

DOC.HEAD: Quarterly Trade Gap Down; Analysts Forecasts Widening Deficits
DOC.TEXT: The United States recorded its smallest quarterly trade deficit in 6{ years in the spring, the government reported Tuesday, but analysts forecast widening deficits in coming months as the Persian Gulf crisis boosts America's foreign oil bill. The Commerce Department said the trade gap from April through June narrowed a sharp 14.1 percent, to $22.6 billion, reflecting a big drop in oil prices and a record level for U.S. exports sales. America's trade performance has been the one bright spot in a generally lackluster economy this year and the Bush administration had been counting on further trade gains to keep the country out of a recession. However, since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, many private economists fear that an economic slump is imminent as an already weak U.S. economy succumbs to an oil-price shock that sends inflation surging and reverses the trade improvement. David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, said he believed a mild recession would begin in the October-December quarter and last for two quarters. He forecast that the U.S. trade deficit would widen sharply in the current quarter and the final three months of the year, reflecting higher oil prices. ``The problems in the Middle East just added to the other problems the economy was facing,'' Wyss said. ``Trade is going to get worse before it starts getting better again.'' Even though oil prices retreated somewhat Monday, the price of a 42-gallon barrel of crude on the world market still stands about 35 percent higher than it did Aug. 1, the day before Iraq's invasion. David Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, predicted that the increase in oil prices would add between $6 billion and $7.5 billion to the quarterly deficit figure. Steinberg said it was too soon to predict whether the oil runup will be enough to trigger a recession or simply leave economic growth at a near standstill. ``Although this event is smaller than oil shocks in the past, it comes at a time when the economy was already quite weak,'' Steinberg said. The $22.6 billion trade deficit in the third quarter was down $3.7 billion from a first quarter gap of $26.3 billion. It was the lowest quarterly imbalance since a $21.3 billion shortfall in the last three months of 1983. In the second quarter, U.S. imports fell 2.6 percent to $119.32 billion, an improvement of $3.2 billion, with a big $3.5 billion drop in the foreign oil bill being partially offset by a $300 million rise in non-oil imports. U.S. exports were up $480 million to a record level of $96.7 billion, besting the old mark of $96.3 billion set in the first three months this year. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports. Tuesday's report on merchandise trade calculated on a balance-of-payments basis confirmed trends noted in the department's monthly trade reports, although the figures were slightly different because the quarterly report excludes military sales by the U.S. government and makes other minor adjustments. Petroleum imports, which had risen sharply in the first quarter, fell by 22 percent, to $12.1 billion. The average price per barrel decreased to $15.81, down from $19.47 in the first quarter. The import volume decreased as well in the second quarter to 8.41 million barrels, down from 8.9 million barrels in the first quarter. While the price of oil surged to nearly $32 per barrel last week, it was trading at around $27 per barrel Tuesday. The small rise in U.S. export sales came from higher manufacturing exports offsetting a drop in farm sales. Non-farm exports rose by $1.1 billion with increases recorded for automotive products, consumer goods and civilian aircraft. Agricultural exports fell 6 percent, to $10.3 billion, with wheat, corn, soybeans and cotton sales all declining. As usual, the biggest imbalance occurred with Japan, a deficit of $10.4 billion, up slightly from a $10.3 billion first quarter deficit. The United States posted a rare $1.5 billion second quarter surplus with Western Europe, up from a $400 million surplus in the first quarter. Analysts predicted the surpluses with Western Europe would continue, in part because the U.S. dollar has been declining in value in relation to the West German mark. A weaker dollar makes U.S. products more competitive.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Names New Press Spokesman
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev beefed up his press office Tuesday by naming a well-respected Soviet magazine editor as his personal assistant and chief spokesman. Vitaly N. Ignatenko was slated to give his first press briefing in the newly influential post Wednesday. He is editor of the New Times magazine, which under his stewardship has played a significant role in Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness. Ignatenko is expected to play a larger role in policy-making than either his predecessor, Arkady Maslennikov, or his American counterpart, Marlin Fitzwater. Ignatenko, 49, who speaks some English, is one of a handful of top Soviet journalists who reputedly have enjoyed regular access to Gorbachev and gained his confidence. One sign of his influence is his title: assistant to the president and head of the presidential press service. The assistant to the president designation is new. Maslennikov, whose performance was widely viewed as lackluster, has returned to his former position as press aide to the chairman of the Supreme Soviet legislature. He was on vacation and could not be reached for comment. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov, who announced the changes at a news conference, said Maslennikov would begin working for Anatoly Lukyanov, Gorbachev's successor as Supreme Soviet chairman. Gerasimov himself was the top Soviet spokesman until he was pushed out of the limelight when Gorbachev elevated Maslennikov. Maslennikov developed a reputation among both Soviet and foreign reporters in Moscow for being difficult to reach and not returning phone calls. He also made some high profile mistakes _ such as failing to put down a rumor about Gorbachev's health during his June summit meeting with President Bush. Asked at a press conference in Washington whether it was true Gorbachev planned to undergo testing for diabetes in Minnesota, Maslennikov replied that there were many scientific experts in Minnesota with whom the Soviet leader might consult. His answer allowed the rumor to live for several hours before being firmly denied by other Soviet officials. Ignatenko has a reputation for accessibility and clarity. ``He is easygoing, with a very good sense of humor,'' said his deputy at Novoye Vremya (New Times), Aleksandr Pumpyansky. ``But he's also a professional journalist whose language is very precise _ he knows all the nuances.'' Born in the Black Sea resort of Sochi, Ignatenko graduated from the journalism department of Moscow State University and worked for 15 years at Komsolskaya Pravda, the Communist Youth League newspaper, rising from cub reporter to deputy editor in chief. In 1975, he switched to Tass, the official Soviet new agency, where he served as deputy general director 1978. He then worked for the Communist Party Central Committee, serving as deputy chief of its international information department until being named editor of New Times four years ago. The weekly magazine, which is published in Russian and several other languages, including English, has published articles critical of the Soviet military and some of its allies, such as Cuba. This summer it carried a revisionist history of the Korean War, laying considerable blame on the North Korean side for the first time.

DOC.HEAD: Now Cowboys, Golfers, Bicyclists Can Call With Ease
DOC.TEXT: Cowboys and golfers can phone home these days without getting off their horses or out of their golf carts. And the convenience will be extended soon to bikers and boaters. It's all part of a program launched by Southwestern Bell Telephone Co. this summer to make things easier for people on the go. For starters, the company has installed three pay telephones, 80 inches off the ground, at the Lazy E Arena near Guthrie, the world's largest, privately owned indoor rodeo arena. The height is perfect for mounted cowboys, who are beckoned by ``Phone From Horse'' signs. At Westwood Park Golf Course in Norman, golfers can drive right up to a phone near the 15th tee to take or make calls. That phone is 50 inches off the ground _ just right for someone seated in a golf cart. The state's first Phone From Bike will be installed next week along the Arkansas River in Tulsa, phone company officials said. Bikers can talk in comfort on the 50-inch high phone without resorting to a kickstand. In addition, the company plans to install 36-inch high phones soon at docks at one or two Oklahoma lakes so boaters can make calls without disembarking. The phone company has long been offering roadside telephones suited for people seated in their cars, but the new phones for sporting people are unique to Oklahoma for now, said Dennis Smiley, a Southwestern Bell spokesman. ``It's kind of what you call grass roots ingenuity or employee innovation. This is where the idea originated so this is where it's starting,'' Smiley said, adding that other state divisions of St. Louis-based Southwestern Bell could adopt the program if they like it. ``It comes down to basic customer interest and economy. If people start using phones from cars and boats and golf carts ... I guarantee it will spread,'' he said. Sue Ball, the phone company's marketing manager, predicts the best success from the golf course telephones. ``I really expect it to take off big. And I really wouldn't be surprised if the Phone From Boat isn't popular, too,'' she said. The first phones for people on the go were at the horse arena and were installed at the suggestion of a contractor. ``It went over so big we started thinking of all kinds of transportation people have, and tried to adapt our signs,'' Ms. Ball said. She expects to hear any day now from Oklahoma City officials about permission for the first Phone From Boat installation at Lake Hefner. If that works, she plans a second one at Grand Lake in northeastern Oklahoma. ``Obviously Oklahoma has people on the move. People don't sit around with their feet up all weekend. A lot of the times they spend that time mobile, pursuing recreational interests. But they want to have access,'' Smiley said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Bar Rally; Activists Allege Harassment
DOC.TEXT: Pro-democracy activists accused the ruling party Tuesday of harassment after police refused to give them permission to hold a mass rally this weekend. Vernon Mwaanga, a spokesman for pro-democracy campaigners, charged that ruling party officials have intimidated opposition supporters. He said ``thugs and hooligans'' tore down posters announcing upcoming rallies. Mwaanga described the postponement of Saturday's rally as an attempt to frustrate the opposition campaign for a multiparty democracy in this one-party state. The rally was rescheduled Sept. 8. Mwaanga said heads of the Frontline African states bordering South Africa are to meet in Lusaka on Saturday and police said they did not have the manpower to supervise both events simultaneously. ``It has been a consistent feature of our campaign that the authorities have frustrated our efforts to hold meetings,'' Mwaanga said. In a separate press statement Tuesday, Arthur Wina, chairman of the National Interim Committee for Multiparty Democracy, said he was disappointed that the government ``continued to operate on the basis of giving priority to foreign and international images rather than domestic affairs and national welfare.'' Earlier Tuesday, a longtime political associate of President Kenneth Kaunda said he would aggressively campaign to end one-party rule. Legislator Humphrey Mulemba, a former ruling party secretary-general, told reporters in Lusaka the scrapping of the one-party system was vital for the future well-being of Zambia, one of Africa's poorest nations. ``It is time we had political structural changes by removing one-party and introduce multiparty politics in Zambia,'' he said. As secretary-general of the ruling party for four years, Mulemba was No. 2 in the party hierarchy after Kaunda. He is the second ruling party legislator to openly attack one-party rule. ``With immediate effect I am going public and I am appealing to all Zambians for support,'' he said. Kaunda imposed a one-party system in 1973, when his ruling United National Independence Party became the only legal political organization in Zambia. Mulemba blamed one-party rule for ``inertia, corruption and lack of competition.'' On Monday, Frederick Chiluba, head of the powerful Zambia Congress of Trade Unions made his strongest attack yet against the ruling party. Addressing pro-democracy supporters, Chiluba accused Kaunda of being a dictator and criticized the ruling party for being out of touch with the people. A referendum on the political future of Zambia is scheduled Aug. 13, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Crisis Threatens USDA Workers
DOC.TEXT: Most Agriculture Department workers would be laid off if Congress and the White House fail to solve the government's budget problems, a report showed Tuesday. There would be lower subsidies for major commodities, and needy farmers would have less of a chance to get housing and operating loans, the report said. Perhaps as many as 90,000 employees, roughly 90 percent of the department's permanent work force, would be affected one way or another by the layoffs. It would affect chicken inspectors and economists, scientists and file clerks, highly paid executives and those at the bottom of the scale, the report warned. Layoff notices have been sent out to 2.4 million federal employees in case Congress and the Bush administration don't come up with an 11th-hour rescue for the fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1. Under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law, an across-the-board cut of federal spending has been ordered by the White House to begin Oct. 15 if no budget agreement is reached. About $22.9 billion of USDA's projected outlays would be affected. Food stamps and child nutrition programs generally are exempt from the cuts. The USDA study anticipates cuts of 31.9 percent, or $7.3 billion from affected programs. ``Farm price support payments and many other USDA loan and grant programs would be severely reduced,'' the report said. The report added: ``The necessity to lay off employees would disrupt USDA services throughout the world and especially at USDA county offices throughout rural America. Producers and industries dependent on the availability of USDA programs and services would be severely affected.'' For example, so-called deficiency payments to farmers for next year have been projected at about $3 billion, and a 31.9 percent cut would be more than $900 million. Dairy farmers would be assessed approximately 8.7 percent per 100 pounds of milk marketed, which would reduce cash receipts by nearly $130 million. In state and county offices of the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, where the programs are administered, salaries and expenses would be reduced by the same percentage. More than 20,300 employees of the county offices would be furloughed. Offices would be closed Mondays and Fridays. Stephen B. Dewhurst, the department's budget director, said he and others in the office had received letters that they would be furloughed three days out of every 10. ``You can get a 50-50 bet, I suppose, from people who think it won't happen at all and those who think (cuts) will be 40 percent,'' Dewhurst said. The Office of Management and Budget has already boosted its estimate of spending cuts to 32.4 percent, and Dewhurst said that could balloon further. Only about $600 million of the $23 billion in food programs would be subject to the cuts. Food stamps alone account for around $16 billion or so. But the current food stamp law runs out in 1991. ``If, as everybody expects, the food stamp program is reauthorized, it will drive federal spending up,'' Dewhurst said. ``You'd see the (cuts) go to somewhere between 38 and 40 percent.'' That would put a further bite on commodity price support operations, the Farmers Home Administration, food aid to foreign countries, conservation, research and the other eligible programs.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Proposed in Lawsuits Against Microwave Oven Maker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS graf with info on how customers will be notified; Version moved on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people who bought Magic Chef microwave ovens, thinking they were new, would collect $35 each under a proposed settlement of three lawsuits against the manufacturer. Since January 1987, Maytag Corp.'s Anniston plant repackaged or reconditioned ovens that customers had returned. The company then sold the ovens as new for $80 to $160. Maytag denied any liability in the settlement proposal filed Monday, but agreed to halt the practice and offer refunds to the 45,000 to 50,000 customers nationwide who bought the ovens. The refunds would be cash payments of $25 and a $10 certificate toward the purchase of a Magic Chef product. Maytag also agreed to pay up to $300,000 to the parties filing the suits: the Alabama attorney general's office and a Birmingham law firm. U.S. District Court Judge Robert B. Propst gave initial approval to the terms and set a hearing for Oct. 19 to allow any of the oven buyers to voice objections. Dennis Wright, chief of the attorney general's consumer protection division, said Maytag will send notices to customers who mailed in their warranty cards and will purchase ads in newspapers in cities where the ovens were sold.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Saddam Says All Foreign Women and Children Can Leave Iraq
