DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with INA reporting that Saddam changed his mind about holding the foreign children and women because of a comment made at his meeting Tuesday with foreign families. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein announced today that all women and children foreigners in Iraq are free to leave the country on Wednesday, the Iraqi News Agency said. In a decree issued Tuesday, Saddam said ``that all women and children who are foreigners in Iraq are allowed to move freely in Iraq or to travel whenever they want starting tomorrow, including the families Iraq is hosting,'' according to the news agency. The report was monitored in Nicosia. It was not immediately clear how many women and children there are among the 500 American hostages in Iraq. It also was not known if the decree would apply to the 2,500 American hostages in Kuwait. Baghdad, whose troops overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, now considers its oil-rich neighbor part of Iraq. The announcement followed a televised meeting Saddam held with a group of foreign families earlier Tuesday. During the meeting, a woman with a British accent asked Saddam why he was using foreign children ``in something they can't understand.'' The Iraqi president gave a long answer in which he repeated that his hand was being forced by the Western troops massing in the region. Iraq has moved some of the hostages to military sites to prevent an attack on them. But the Iraqi News Agency report on Saddam's decree said it was issued because of the concern expressed by the foreign families about their children during the meeting Tuesday with the foreign hostages. The report said the fate of the foreign women and children is now a humane issue that transcends the earlier reason for holding them as hostages. During the meeting with the foreign families, Saddam also said he was willing to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis with President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Saddam said he was ``ready and prepared for direct talks with Mr. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher. ... Let us have the debate between me and them on television for the whole world to see.'' The United States quickly rejected the offer. A spokeswoman for Mrs. Thatcher repeated the firm policy of Britain and the United States that Iraq must withdraw its troops from Kuwait before talks can begin.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says Women, Children Foreigners Can Leave Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with four grafs to UPDATE with Sadam saying women and children hostages can leave Iraq. Picks up 3rd graf, `Saddam offered....'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein today said women and children foreigners can leave the country and he was ready for direct talks with President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. In other developments, Baghdad tightened its grip on Kuwait by declaring it a 19th province and an American civilian died in Iraq, apparently one of 63 Americans who were rounded up for use as human shields against attack. Saddam issued a decree ``that all women and children who are foreigners in Iraq are allowed to move freely in Iraq or to travel whenever they want starting tomorrow, including the families Iraq is hosting,'' the Iraqi News Agency said, in a report monitored in Nicosia. About 500 Americans are being held captive in Iraq. It was not know if the decree applied to the 2,500 American hostages in Kuwait. Baghdad, whose troops overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, now considers its oil-rich neighbor part of Iraq. Saddam offered to meet with Bush and Mrs. Thatcher while visiting with several foreign families held hostage in Iraq. The meeting was shown on state-run Iraqi TV and was Saddam's second televised meeting with hostages. The Iraqi president said he was ``ready and prepared for direct talks with Mr. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher. ... Let us have the debate between me and them on television for the whole world to see.'' In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler quickly dismissed Saddam's offer, saying: ``It's sick, and it doesn't even deserve a response. Come on, there is nothing to debate.'' A spokeswoman for Mrs. Thatcher said Britain was unlikely to agree to talks unless Iraq withdraws its troops from Kuwait. The nationalities of the foreigners shown with Saddam today were not known. One woman who asked a question spoke with a British accent and another indicated he was from France. It also was know known when or where the meeting occurred, but the Iraqi News Agency said Saddam used the meeting to free one British family and order that it be sent home. Saddam said he understood the families felt restricted, but that Iraq needed to hold them to prevent an attack by U.S.-led forces sent to the gulf to prevent Iraqi troops that overran Kuwait from invading Saudi Arabia. Last week, Saddam was shown meeting with foreign hostages on Iraqi television, patting the heads of small boys and posing for a group photograph. The broadcast was sharply criticized by world leaders who demanded that he let the foreigners go and stop using them for propaganda purposes. Earlier today, shipping sources said U.S. Navy warships enforcing the U.N. embargo against Iraq stopped two cargo ships and crewmen boarded one in the Gulf of Aqaba before allowing them to proceed to Jordan. It was believed to be the first time a ship was boarded and inspected by the U.S. Navy since the embargo began shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Also today, the Soviet Union criticized the United States for expelling Iraqi diplomats from Washington, and warned that such action could lead to a ``spiral of escalation'' in the conflict. But Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov also indicated that some of Iraq's Arab neighbors have failed to put enough pressure on Baghdad in response to its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The developments came as U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said he was intervening with Iraq to try to defuse the gulf crisis. President Bush said he was pessimistic about the U.N. initiative. The peace effort, however, was enough to make stock markets rally in Tokyo and London. Stock prices slipped slightly on Wall Street. Gold, whose value increases in times of turmoil, plunged about $19 to $392.55 an ounce today on London's gold exchange. Oil prices also fell. In Vienna, 10 of the 13 OPEC ministers tentatively backed a deal that would permit increased oil production by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and some other nations to help offset losses arising from the gulf crisis. But the ministers delayed until Wednesday a formal meeting expected to give final approval to the agreement until messages had been sent to Iraq and Libya, whose representatives did not attend the meeting. In Baghdad, the press attache at the U.S. Embassy, Stephen Thibeault, said that according to the Iraqis an American had died in Basra, a southern port in Iraq. He said the 56-year-old man apparently died of a heart attack, and was believed one of those who had been detained by the Iraqis. Saddam has said he is rounding up Westerners and placing them at key military and civilian installations as protection against an attack by the U.S.-led multinational force deploying in the gulf region. Thibeault, in a telephone interview from Baghdad, said there was no positive identification on the American ``because we have not been given access to the American citizen yet. The Iraqi authorities have said that they would allow us to participate in any autopsy.'' Asked about life in Baghdad, Thibeault said: ``The American diplomats here, as of this moment, are being accorded the same diplomatic priviliges that we've had over the last few months.'' Asked if the atmosphere in Iraq worries him, he said: ``Nothing specific other than being in a country where people are not allowed to travel freely and leave the country. I think that any thinking person would be concerned about those circumstances.'' Meanwhile, 52 dependents of U.S. diplomats who were evacuated from the American Embassy in Kuwait arrived in Paris today on their way home from Turkey. Three young men from the group were not allowed to leave Iraq. A furious United States, saying Iraq had ``once again reneged on its pledge'' that all the dependents could go free, swiftly ordered 36 Iraqi Embassy staff members in Washington expelled from the United States and imposed travel limits on the 19 envoys allowed to remain. ``I talked to the doctors. Everyone was in great shape,'' said U.S. Embassy spokesman Paul Kozelka, who met with some of the tired Americans at Charles de Gaulle-Roissy airport before the plane continued on to the United States. The State Department said Monday it could not confirm U.S. media reports that Iraqi ship captains had been ordered not to resist if their vessels are stopped and searched by warships enforcing the U.N. embargo. But Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohammed Sadiq al-Mashat, seemed to confirm the reports in an interview on ABC's Nightline. ``We are doing our best ourselves to defuse the tension _ I mean, the order that we have given to the captains of the ship not to resist...'' he said. The London-based Lloyd's shipping agency, which monitors maritime traffic worldwide, said the U.S. Navy boarded the Greek-owned container ship Zorba Express and stopped the Indian owned vessel Kalidas on Monday near the mouth to the Gulf of Aqaba. Both ships were allowed to proceed when the Navy determined the cargoes were not bound for Iraq. Diplomats and shipping executives said that previously, the U.S. Navy simply radioed ships demanding to know their nationality, cargo and destination. However, the U.S. Navy also fired warning shots across the bows of two Iraqi tankers early in the crisis. Both refused to stop. Lloyd's also said that on Sunday the U.S. Navy denied the French container ship Paris entry into the Gulf of Aqaba. Iraqi newspapers today published Saddam's decree turning Kuwait into an Iraqi province. The newspapers did not say when he issued the decree, which created the province of Kuwait. Iraq's longstanding claim to Kuwait is based on the fact that during the Ottoman Empire Kuwait was part of the Basra governate and the British split it up after World War I. In Washington, the White House condemned Iraq for making Kuwait a province. ``The reaction is quite obvious,'' said spokesman Roman Popadiuk. ``The annexation is null and void. The whole United Nations has spoken on it. And that's it.''

DOC.HEAD: Picking Up the Pieces: Middle East Escapees Rebuild Their Lives
DOC.TEXT: After five years in Kuwait, Ray Shoopman had finally glimpsed the day when every spare penny wouldn't have to be reinvested in his fledgling construction company. What he didn't see was Iraq's Saddam Hussein on the horizon. ``Within a matter of a few hours, it all changed,'' Shoopman said Tuesday. ``We had no intentions of leaving when we did. (But) when you're in a position like that ... you're ready to leave everything behind.'' For the American families who abandoned their adoptive homes in the Middle East, the past weeks are frighteningly fresh and the immediate future painfully uncertain. They are feeling their way tentatively beyond disorientation. Instead of building up his business, Shoopman is picking up the pieces. In the scramble to escape occupied Kuwait, the 50-year-old instructed his family to pack only essentials: water, a change of clothes, birth certificates. He, his wife, daughter and two grandchildren arrived in Alabama on Aug. 24 with little more than a suitcase each _ and 60 days to repay a $10,000 emergency loan from the U.S. government. ``Repatriation loans are made to destitute Americans ... for a one-way ticket home,'' said Aleta Wenger, a State Department spokeswoman in Washington, D.C. ``Arrangements are made to pay that amount of support back ... and until they complain that they can't pay it back within 60 days, there's no real reason to be flexible,'' she said. ``It's a wait-and-see kind of thing.'' Shoopman had no choice but to borrow the money when his family, shaken and weary, crossed into Saudi Arabia. They needed a place to bathe and a flight home. The hotel and airfare costs mounted quickly. ``We asked if we can make a payment schedule, but they said they'll charge an interest rate,'' Shoopman said. Still, he didn't think twice about taking the financial aid. ``You don't think about materialistic things when you're in a position like that,'' Shoopman said. ``We didn't have time to think about it.'' But with time to reflect, reality has begun catching up. Shoopman thinks of the fax machine, computer and business files ditched along with the rest of the family's possessions. He imagines Iraqi troops using the crane and front-end loaders his employees had to abandon in the invasion. ``We had signed contracts to export cement from Iraq,'' he said. ``We're talking about 600,000 tons of cement and five-year contracts. It looked like everything was going to turn out real nice, and then this happened.'' Now it's catch as catch can. Shoopman is looking up old friends in Decatur, Ala., in the hopes of finding a job. He and his family are also remembering their desert journey, the gunfire and Bedouin friends who led them to safety. Scores of Americans hit the ground running after Saddam invaded Aug. 2. Now some are trying to outrun a new set of problems. Stephanie Atieh spent part of Monday standing in line for aid from family services. She has three young children, is six months pregnant and worried half-sick about the safety of her Jordanian husband and his family in Kuwait. The couple's comfortable four-bedroom life on the fringe of Kuwait City disappeared without warning, before they had a chance to prepare. ``We went to sleep on a Wednesday night and by Thursday our whole world was destroyed,'' Mrs. Atieh said Tuesday from Stewartsville, Texas. ``We didn't have any money except what was in our pockets because the banks closed down immediately.'' Mrs. Atieh, her mother and children reached the Jordanian border via a backroads route through Iraq. But once there, they found themselves temporarily at a deadend. ``It took us a week to get money for one-way tickets (back to the United States) and the papers say you have to pay it back in 60 days, which is impossible right now,'' Mrs. Atieh said. ``I owe the government $4,000 and my mother owes a little more than $1,000,'' Mrs. Atieh said. ``They want us to pay back the money. (But) we're refugees. We had some money, but now it's gone.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush: `Let No One Doubt Our ... Staying Power'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New material top 9 grafs; picks up 1st Add a0621, bgng, Earlier, in...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told an unusual gathering of lawmakers today that steps were under way to make the sanctions against Iraq ``as watertight as possible,'' and warned Baghdad: ``Let no one abroad doubt our national unity or our staying power.'' It was Bush's first meeting with members of Congress since American troops were deployed to Saudi Arabia in a crisis triggered Aug. 2 when Iraq invaded the the neighboring oil-rich emirate of Kuwait. As White House aides scoffed at Baghdad's declaration that Kuwait had been incorporated as a province of Iraq, Bush reiterated his demand that Iraq withdraw and reinstate the Kuwaiti government to power. Bush hailed the tightening of the United Nations embargo against Iraq as further evidence that Iraq ``cannot benefit from this illegal occupation.'' ``Iraqi oil no longer flows through pipelines in Turkey and Saudi Arabia,'' the president said. ``Today, reports indicate that traffic through Aqaba (Jordan) has come virtually to a halt, and U.S. naval forces sail with navies of many other states to make these sanctions as water tight as possible.'' With many thousands of American soldiers now deployed in Saudi Arabia, Bush said Iraq would ``pay a stiff price by trying to hold on, and an even stiffer price by widening the conflict.'' He also repeated that he would hold Iraq responsible for the safety of Americans it has taken hostage in Kuwait and Iraq. With that, Bush ended brief public remarks and went into ``executive session'' to brief lawmakers privately, and field their questions. The ranking Democrat, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., was asked whether Congress supports Bush's Middle East policy, and answered, ``Yes.'' Interrupting his vacation in Maine, Bush returned to the White House and met in the Cabinet Room with top congressional leaders before addressing a larger gathering of about 150 lawmakers _ returned from vacations of their own. Earlier, in Maine, Saddam Hussein's decree turning Kuwait into Iraq's 19th province was dismissed by White House aides. ``The reaction is quite obvious,'' said presidential spokesman Roman Popadiuk. ``The annexation is null and void. The whole United Nations has spoken on it. And that's it.'' The president, who has bristled at criticism that he should be spending more time in Washington during the crisis, planned to stay in the nation's capital until late Thursday before resuming his vacation. He denied that his trip to Washington was a response to that criticism _ or that his time spent in Maine fishing, playing golf and boating was detracting from his ability to deal with the Iraqi crisis. ``I've been able to keep in very close touch,'' he said Monday during a joint news conference with Canadian Prime Minister Bryan Mulroney outside his oceanfront vacation home. ``We're making a lot of international phone calls that you wouldn't normally expect at the time of a vacation.'' He cited the time he spends with key aides and meetings like those with Mulroney and a session last week with Jordan's King Hussein. ``We're on top of the situation. I think the American people understand that,'' Bush said. This afternoon, Bush met first with top House and Senate leaders, then with members of the House and Senate Armed Services, Foreign Affairs, Appropriations and Intelligence committees. ``It is most understandable that they want to know what is going on and get up to speed on things,'' Bush said. ``So I welcome this.'' Also briefing the members were Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, CIA Director William Webster, Secretary of State James A. Baker III _ who cut short a Wyoming vacation _ and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Colin Powell. In advance of today's meeting with Bush, Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said public support for keeping U.S. troops in the inhospitable Saudi desert might evaporate ``if the United States is the only country willing to put at risk a sizable ground force to defend the entire world's interests.'' ``That is not a sustainable condition,'' Pell wrote in a weekend newspaper column. And Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., among a group of senators that visited Saudi Arabia earlier this week, said, ``At some point we have to realize the waiting game works against us ... I don't think the American public is going to stand for waiting six or seven months.'' Lawmakers return to Washington early next month. Hearings on various aspects of the crisis are certain.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Increases Estimates for Operation Desert Shield
DOC.TEXT: Operation Desert Shield will cost an estimated $2.5 billion through the end of September _ nearly double the earlier estimate of $1.3 billion, the Pentagon said Tuesday. The sharply higher costs are attributed to the expense of calling up reserve and National Guard forces, increased operations for ships and aircraft and increased fuel costs, said spokesman Pete Williams. Other factors include increases in the number of C-130 aircraft in the Persian Gulf region and increases in the number of aircraft carrier battle groups deployed there, Williams said. The cost estimate includes $1.13 billion for the Army, $494 million for the Navy, $556 million for the Air Force, $20 million for defense agencies and $300 million for increased fuel prices. Reporting on its reserve call up, the Pentagon said that by the end of the month it will have activated 14,129 people in hundreds of Army, Air Force, Navy and Coast Guard units across the country. The total includes: _Air Force: 7,386, including 616 from Air Force Reserve units, 386 from the Air National Guard and 6,384 Air Force reservists who weren't formally activated but who volunteered for duty in the Gulf crisis. _Navy: 2,236 sailors from 127 units will be activated by month's end. _Army: 4,236 soldiers activated so far, including 542 National Guardsmen from 19 units and 3,694 Army reservists from 34 units. _Coast Guard: 271 personnel. The Pentagon said additional expenses include the cost of calling up reservists, up to a total of 48,200. The cost of the call up, the operations of the reserve forces and their subsistence is estimated at $347 million through September, it said. It pegged at $175 million the cost incurred due to the increased tempo of flying time and ship use. The Pentagon noted that the number of deployed carrier battle groups in the area of the Arabian peninsula will increase to three from 1{. The Pentagon also said the 51 C-130 transport planes in use in the crisis will more than double, to 112 aircraft, by the end of September. Deployment of U.S. forces is proving costly, the Pentagon said: _Eight Fast Sealift SL-7 ships with crews and equipment: $34 million. _Sixteen Roll-on Roll-off ships and 20 cargo ships moved out of the ready reserve fleet to active operations: $95 million. _The use of commercial and government cargo aircraft: $484 million. _The deploying of two Navy prepositioned ships for aviation logistics support: $9 million. _One-time costs at various military installations to prepare units for deployment: $135 million. The Pentagon said two hospital ships had been equipped and deployed at a cost of $10 million, and that it has spent $30 million for medical supplies and $85 million for chemical protective clothing, camouflage uniforms, nets and chemical-agent resistant paint. Support for water, equipment, sanitation, supplies and other consumables has cost $250 million, it said. The Pentagon said that while its operating costs are increasing dramatically because of the Desert Shield operation, it faces a 35 percent reduction in operating appropriations if Congress and the White House fail to reach a budget agreement by Oct. 1, thereby avoiding the automatic cuts required by the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction act.

DOC.HEAD: Plaster Cast of Pre-Historic Fossil Opened
DOC.TEXT: The most complete Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton ever found is beginning to emerge as a museum's crew cuts away plaster casts covering the fossil of the largest carnivore to roam the Earth. ``This is it,'' the Museum of the Rockies' Pat Leiggi said Monday as he tore a brittle piece from a 2-ton block of plaster and bone. ``This is a lot of animal.'' His work was just the beginning of cutting and research planned on the T-Rex skeleton, only the eighth ever found. The T-rex, buried for 65 million years, was discovered in 1988 by a farm couple, Tom and Kathy Wankel of Angela, in the badlands of eastern Montana. They brought an exposed foreleg to paleontologist Jack Horner at the Bozeman museum, who immediately recognized it as a T-rex. Museum workers excavated the skeleton during the next two years, finally packing the fossils in plaster to protect them during transport to the museum. Museum crews are now working in public view in the museum's Dinosaur Hall, going over the eight large chunks of bones and plaster ``little by little,'' Leiggi said. The skeleton is made up of eight separate pieces of plaster containing the hip, the back, the head, a shin, the right foot, the left foot's toes, a section of the tail alone and a section of the tail containing the lower jaw. The bones are so spread apart because water separated the bones over time, Leiggi said. The museum's Phyllis B. Berger Dinosaur Hall is to officially open to the public on Sept. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Promises East German Prosperity; Workers Stage Walkouts
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl tried to woo East German voters with promises of jobs and prosperity Tuesday as a work stoppage over unification fears brought some municipal services to a halt. Kohl's campaign speech received mostly cheers, but a group of leftist protesters responded by hurling tomatoes and peaches. Earlier, about 45,000 workers across East Germany staged warning strikes to demand better wages and job security in a united Germany. Kohl told a crowd of nearly 5,000 in Halle, about 125 miles southwest of Berlin, that the legacy left by 40 years of Communist rule was a ``sad thing'' and ``it is our goal that this economy becomes a blossoming landscape.'' It was Kohl's first appearance at an East German rally since the setting of the Oct. 3 date for unification. It also marked the start of his campaigning in East Germany for the leadership of a united Germany. During the appearance, several hundred supporters of the now-dissolved Communist Party repeatedly interrupted Kohl, who came to this industrial city of 400,000 residents to open a training program for young workers. As Kohl took to the podium, leftists tossed tomatoes and peaches over the metal barrier separating the crowd from the chancellor. The food splattered at the foot of the platform. Kohl, tanned after an Alpine vacation, criticized the demonstrators, saying the issues of unity ``will not be decided on the street.'' Kohl told the crowd he was optimistic agreement could be reached by the end of the week on the so-called ``unity treaty.'' Dispute over abortion rules has delayed ratification of the treaty, which covers a host of unification issues like tax revenues and property claims. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere also appealed to his countrymen to rebuild their country. ``We should lose no time. We have it easier than our eastern neighbors. If we remain plucky and show the courage to act responsibly, we'll be out of the woods soon. Our chances are good,'' said de Maiziere. Kohl and de Maiziere hope to attract support for the Dec. 2 all-German elections and for East Germany's Oct. 14 state elections. The warning strikes were staged in Halle and at least nine other cities. Nurses, secretaries, bus drivers, garbage-haulers and other municipal employees stopped working for up to two hours. The workers demanded compensation for higher prices that have resulted from the July 1 economic merger. They also demand that East German income taxes not be immediately raised to West German levels. There are about 1.6 million municipal workers in East Germany. Effects from the warning strikes were felt across the country. In Potsdam outside Berlin, buses and street cars stood still for two hours, reported the official East German news agency ADN. Parked streetcars blocked key streets in Magdeburg and dozens of garbage trucks hindered access to the city's main department store, ADN said. Operations at Magdeburg's Elbe River harbor were temporarily crippled by the walkout, said ADN. East German Health Minister Juergen Kleditzsch said more than 350,000 people are without work and indicated more than 900,000 are working reduced hours.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Overturns Decision To Free Ceausescu's Son
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Tuesday overturned a lower court decision to free the youngest son of ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu because of failing health. A military court in the southern Transylvanian town of Sibiu decided last week to set Nicu Ceausescu free pending a verdict because of his poor health. However, he remained in prison pending the Supreme Court decision on the prosecution's appeal. The Supreme Court decided that Ceausescu, who is suffering from advanced cirrhosis of the liver, may receive special treatment from Health Ministry doctors, replacing prison doctors. Ceausescu is formally charged with ``complicity to genocide.'' He pleaded innocent but admitted to the lesser charge of illegal possession of firearms and ammunition. The verdict is to be rendered on Sept. 21 in Bucharest. Ceausescu was a leader of the former Communist Youth League until 1987, when he became party secretary in Sibiu.

DOC.HEAD: Once-Broke District Now Pays Students To Go to College
DOC.TEXT: A tiny school district once so broke it gave teachers IOUs instead of paychecks is now so flush it gives $1,000 to each college-bound student. ``This district was down and out. ... But we came back when everybody gave up on us,'' said Peter Corona, superintendent of the 525-student Emery Unified School District. ``We showed that success begins at home _ the good old ethic of hard work, dedication, commitment and the will and desire to succeed and overcome all odds.'' The scholarship, believed to be the first of its kind in the country, helps make college possible for students in this low-income district between Berkeley and Oakland. The gifts, first provided to the class of 1989, are just one example of the district's remarkable recovery from financial adversity. Eight years ago, Emery Unified had a 24 percent budget deficit _ the largest ever of any district in California _ that threatened its very existence. The district in this bayside industrial town of 4,800 was once wealthy. But a 1972 change in the way state property tax is allocated left Emery Unified with less money, and the district got into trouble because over 10 years it didn't cut spending, Corona said. Corona discovered a $600,000 shortfall 10 days after coming to the district as business manager in 1982. He boasts that Emery Unified now enjoys a $1.5 million reserve _ 35 percent of its $4.3 million budget _ significantly higher test scores and improved morale. But the rehabilitation took several years and had its price _ including a state loan, teacher layoffs and deep cuts in programs. ``The children have made sacrifices, our staff has made sacrifices, and our community has had to make sacrifices,'' Corona said. The district borrowed $600,000 from the state, laid off 60 percent of the staff, postponed raises and sent principals back to the classroom. It cut classes in art, music, homemaking, French and shop and reduced such basics as English, math, social studies and physical education. Teachers doubled as custodians, mowing lawns and fixing plumbing at the district's two schools. Corona became superintendent at the start of the 1982-83 school year, remained business manager and served as principal of a high school. For several months in 1983, the district was so strapped that it gave its teachers IOUs, the first time a public agency in the state had done so since the Depression. Some educators and parents suggested the district join one of its larger neighbors, but Emery Unified began to recover, paying back the state loan in three years, two years early. It rehired some teachers, gave raises, restored some cut programs and added new ones. Even today, the district, which employed 45 teachers before dropping to 17 in the 1983-84 school year, only has 25 classroom teachers. Meanwhile, test scores, traditionally at the bottom, have made big gains. For example, on the state achievement tests taken by eighth-graders, reading scores rose from 194 in the 1983-84 school year to 251 last year; math scores jumped from 190 to 402; and history scores increased from 184 to 367. And the dropout rate has fallen to near zero. Emery Unified has been commended by U.S. Secretary of Education Lauro Cavazos, state and county education officials and school and taxpayers' groups. ``Some of the accomplishments here, I feel pretty proud of them,'' said Tom Phan, 17, a junior who worked on the high school's first hardcover yearbook in nearly a decade. ``I'm glad I'm involved.'' Corona introduced the scholarship program during the 1988-89 school year. Eleven of the 22 students in last year's graduating class took the scholarship money. ``These are families who are struggling to make ends meet, usually not highly educated but who really want and expect a good education for their children. And they should,'' Corona said. Natasha Winfrey, an 18-year-old sophomore at the University of California, Davis, said she and her family would have found a way to get her to college somehow, but the district's gift helped eased her anxiety about money. ``I was afraid I wouldn't be able to go to college,'' she said. ``So it made a difference, if only to inspire me to get other things.''

DOC.HEAD: Book Returned 50 Years, Six Days Overdue
DOC.TEXT: An anthology of English poetry has been returned to the library _ 50 years and six days overdue. The copy of W.H. Auden's ``The Oxford Book of Light Verse'' was returned Monday, said Gloria Garcia, automation coordinator for the Corpus Christi Public Library. ``We were in shock,'' Ms. Garcia said. The date-due card was stamped Aug. 21, 1940. It had been checked out from the old La Retama Library, which was the city's central library for 75 years until 1986, when the Corpus Christi Public Library opened. The tattered book was returned by an unidentified man, described by a library worker as in his 30s. ``He just said that he and his wife had been going through some stuff and found the book,'' said Joan Roith, a city reference librarian. ``I teasingly asked if he'd like to pay the fine and he just laughed.'' The book was so ``old and moldy,'' Ms. Roith said the library probably won't put it back on the shelves, let alone levy a fine. The maximum fine would only have amounted to $4.47, or half the book's current $8.95 purchase price, said Mark Gretchen, the library's reference services manager. ``The maximum fine we ever charge is half the price of the book because we don't want to discourage people from returning overdue books,'' Gretchen said. Since the library didn't retain its old records when it converted to a computerized checkout system two years ago, the borrower's identity probably will remain a mystery. ``Even if we could identify him, we couldn't divulge the name. All of that is confidential,'' Gretchen said.

DOC.HEAD: Ridiculed Sculpture May Return From Forced Exile
DOC.TEXT: After more than five years of obscurity in a state storage yard, Alaska's most slandered sculpture may be returned from exile and again placed on display in front of a state building. ``Nimbus,'' a 16-foot, 5-ton, blue-green hunk of steel is either an ``unusually interesting piece'' or an eyesore representing the worst in state spending. Those of the eyesore opinion succeeded in getting the sculpture removed from the plaza in front of the State Capitol complex in late 1984. Now fans of the sculpture want to put it back together and relocate it on a lawn in front of the Alaska State Museum several blocks away. ``Friends of Nimbus'' is asking the City Assembly to donate a truck and crew to move the sculpture. Mark Daughhetee, the museum's exhibits coordinator, organized the group to find a way to prevent Nimbus from rusting away unappreciated. ``It's the most famous piece of sculpture in the state,'' he said. Nimbus, the work of New York City artist Robert Murray, was installed in 1978. It was commissioned at a cost of $40,000, with half the money coming from the National Endowment for the Arts and the other half from the state. Critics in the Alaska Legislature succeeded in passing a resolution in 1984 suggesting Nimbus be replaced with a veterans' memorial. That led to its removal, but it was never replaced. Retired state judge Thomas Stewart supports the group's efforts to find Nimbus a new home. ``It was a crying shame that it was misunderstood by the general public,'' Stewart said. ``To me it has always been an unusually interesting piece of abstract art.''

DOC.HEAD: Rates on Two-Year Notes Rise to Highest Level in Two Months
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes rose in Tuesday's auction to the highest level in two months. The average yield was 8.19 percent, up from 8.07 percent at the last comparable auction on July 25. It was the highest rate since two-year notes averaged 8.41 percent on June 26. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8[ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,988.20. A total of $11.56 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $28.55 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Court Overturns Eyeglass Ruling
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Tuesday overturned a Federal Trade Commission ruling that would have prevented states from banning such operations as shopping mall stores that combine optometric practice with eyeglass sales. ``An agency may not exercise authority over states as sovereigns unless that authority has been unambiguously granted to it,'' wrote Circuit Judge James Buckley of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. The FTC ``acted beyond its statutory authority'' in its so-called Eyeglasses II ruling last year, he wrote in an opinion agreed to by Chief Judge Patricia Wald and Circuit Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg. If the court were to ``uphold Eyeglasses II in the face of congressional silence, we would short-circuit the protections offered states by the political process,'' Buckley wrote. FTC attorney Lawrence DeMille-Wagman said no decision had yet been reached on whether the commission would appeal. The fact that the decision was unanimous is ``certainly a factor we'll have to take into account,'' he said. While DeMille-Wagman said he was not surprised by the ruling, California Deputy Attorney General Thomas S. Lazar, who argued the case for the states, sounded both stunned and ecstatic when he heard the news. ``No kidding! We won the case,'' he shouted to co-workers in his San Diego office. ``Oh, how excellent, how excellent. I spent two years working on this case, around the clock.'' The FTC's ruling of March 1989 never took effect because the California State Board of Optometry and others sought and received a stay from the appellate court moments after the ruling would have become effective last Sept. 1, Lazar said. The states had imposed restrictions that, in the words of the court decision, ``tended to discourage the `commercial practice' of optometry _ such as partnerships between optometrists and laymen, use of trade names, and chain operations combining the practice of optometry with the sale of eyeglasses in shopping centers _ in favor of `traditional optometric practice' typified by sole practitioners operating in professional office buildings under their own names.'' The FTC started investigating the state-imposed restrictions in the mid-1970s. The commission's findings, published in 1980, ``indicated that these restrictions resulted in higher prices and reduced the quality of eye care available to the public,'' Buckley's opinion noted. Nine years later, the FTC voted for Eyeglasses II even though FTC Chairman Daniel Oliver voted against it ``based on principles of federalism and his view that the FTC was without authority to promulgate it.'' The state optometry boards agreed with Oliver. Lazar said he argued that the FTC action was circumventing the national political process: ``In other words, `FTC, if you want to have this authority, go across the street and get it from Congress.''' Lazar, who was the main attorney working on the appeal, said California and 44 other states that imposed restrictions on optometric practices never moved against the type of eyeglass stores that exist in malls everywhere. ``There's nothing wrong with them,'' Lazar said. ``You walk in there with your prescription and you walk out with your glasses in an hour. ``They're opticians, not optometrists,'' he said. ``They're just people who dispense glasses after a prescription has been written by an optometrist.'' What the states opposed was such practices as storefront operations in which non-optometrists were writing and filling the prescriptions or where optometrists had an economic interest in selling eyeglasses.

DOC.HEAD: Food Exports Are Steady
DOC.TEXT: The projected value of U.S. farm exports is holding steady at $40 billion despite a decline in the volume of wheat shipments, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. At $40 billion, the value of agricultural exports for the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1 is up slightly from $39.6 billion in 1988-89. The department's Economic Research Service said total export quantity is expected to be 148.5 million metric tons. Officials said that while the tonnage will be up from last year it is expected to be down from the 150 million tons forecast in May. The new forecast is down ``because weaker prospects for wheat more than offset expected gains in corn, soybeans and soybean meal,'' the agency said in its report. ``Larger prospective crops in several major importing countries, increased competitor supplies (especially Canada), and buyers' anticipation of even lower prices have led to sluggish U.S. wheat and flour sales,'' the report said. But stronger demand for coarse grains by Asian countries and Mexico has boosted the export forecast for those commodities, led by corn.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says Women, Children to Go Free, Offers to Talk
LaserPhotos DAH1,2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD details of Saddam's decree and U.S. reax, American among foreigners shown on television, other details. Splits into two takes.
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq mingled with foreign hostages Tuesday and then decreed that the women and children held captive in his country were free to leave. A statement from the Revolutionary Command Council said the decision was made ``to preserve the image of Arabs,'' the official Iraqi News agency said. The agency, monitored, in Nicosia, Cyprus, said the foreigners could leave starting Wednesday. It was not known how many women and children were among the hostages in Iraq or whether the decree also applies to foreigners in Kuwait. There are 500 Americans trapped in Iraq and 2,500 in Kuwait. The Iraqi news agency said Saddam made his decision after foreigners expressed concern about their children. During Tuesday's televised encounter, a woman with a British accent asked Saddam why he was using foreign children ``in something they can't understand.'' At the same meeting, Saddam told the foreigners he was willing to talk to President Bush and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on television about ending the Persian Gulf crisis. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler, asked about Saddam's suggestion, said: ``It's sick, and it doesn't even deserve a response.'' Another department spokesman, Mark Dillen, said the U.S. government had received no official word of the planned release of women and children. ``We hope it's true, but we have seen promises and statements by Iraq in the past that have proven false,'' Dillen said. Despite Saddam's conciliatory gestures, Baghdad hardened its position on Kuwait, declaring it a 19th province of Iraq. The White House condemned the move. Also Tuesday, U.S. officials said an American civilian died of a heart attack in Iraq. The 56-year-old man, who was not identified, was believed to be one of 63 Americans rounded up and taken to strategic sites in Iraq for use as human shields against attack. Ms. Tutwiler said the death ``underscores the barbaric nature of Iraqi policy toward foreign nationals in Iraq and Kuwait, and makes a lie of Iraq's claim that they are all well treated and in no danger.'' In other developments: _Shipping sources said U.S. Navy warships stopped Greek and Indian cargo ships in the Gulf of Aqaba in the Persian Gulf, and U.S. crewmen boarded one before the ships were allowed to proceed to Jordan. It was believed to be the first time a ship was boarded and inspected by the U.S. Navy since a U.N. embargo began shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. _The Soviet government said Washington's expulsion of Iraqi diplomats could increase tensions in the conflict. _President Bush headed back to Washington from his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine, to brief Congress on the gulf crisis. He reiterated his demand that Saddam withdraw from Kuwait. _Most OPEC ministers tentatively backed a deal that would permit increased oil production by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and some other nations to help offset losses arising from the conflict. The ministers delayed until Wednesday a formal meeting to approve the agreement. _Stock markets rallied in Tokyo and London in response to an announcement by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar that he would meet Thursday with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. Stock prices slipped slightly on Wall Street. _The U.S. Army's heaviest ground firepower reached Saudi Arabia, including dozens of M1-1P tanks and M2 Bradley armored infantry fighting vehicles. _Sen. Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, urged Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak to send more troops to Saudi Arabia to show solidarity with the United States. Saddam's televised visit with foreigners was his second such appearance and apparently intended to convince Western viewers that he is taking a reasonable stand in the crisis. He was widely condemned for his first visit last week, which was seen as a crude attempt to use the detainees for propaganda purposes. The meeting was shown on Iraqi television and broadcast by Cable News Network. One of the hostages shown was American Kevin Bazner, according to his sister, Patricia Heath of Farmington Hills, Mich. Bazner, his wife, Dawn, and their two children were stranded after their plane stopped in Kuwait to refuel during the Aug. 2 invasion. ``I'm glad I got to see my brother. I'm glad he's safe. I hope Dawn and the kids are safe, too,'' Ms. Heath told CNN. It was not immediately clear what countries the other foreigners were from, or when and where the meeting occurred. One woman who asked a question spoke with a British accent. Another indicated he was from France. The families appeared uncomfortable as they listened to Saddam's rambling statement through a translator. Saddam said he was ``ready and prepared for direct talks with Mr. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher. . . . Let us have the debate between me and them on television for the whole world to see.'' Both the U.S. and British governments have said Iraq must pull out of Kuwait before negotiations take place.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: take place.
DOC.TEXT: In its report on Saddam's meeting with foreigners, the Iraqi News Agency said the president ordered that one British family be allowed to return home on the occasion of a child's birthday. There was no mention of that in the TV broadcast. Saddam was shown entering a large room and greeting families, shaking hands with men and patting children on the head. Dressed in a brown suit and tie instead of his military uniform, he smiled as he approached. He told them he knew they were feeling restricted. ``If my family were in your place I would have the same feelings,'' he said. But Saddam added, ``Politicians are forced sometimes to take a position that goes beyond what they see directly in front of them. ``If it had to do with human feelings toward you ... then I would immediately say you should leave and go back to your families.'' But he told them that their presence was needed to prevent an attack. Saddam has used the same justification in the past for his detention of about 21,000 foreigners, including 3,000 Americans and 3,000 Britons, who were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the Aug. 2 invasion. British and U.S. officials say Iraq has moved more than 150 Britons and more than 60 Americans from Kuwait to strategic locations for use as human shields against a possible attack. Iraqi newspapers published Saddam's decree turning Kuwait into an Iraqi province. Iraq's longstanding claim to Kuwait dates back to the time of the Ottoman Empire. Meanwhile, the press attache at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, Stephen Thibeault, said that according to the Iraqis, the American died in the southern port city of Basra. He said the man apparently died of a heart attack. Thibeault, speaking in a telephone interview, said Iraqi authorities said they would allow U.S. officials to participate in an autopsy. Asked if the atmosphere in Iraq worried him, he said: ``Nothing specific other than being in a country where people are not allowed to travel freely and leave the country. I think that any thinking person would be concerned about those circumstances.''

DOC.HEAD: Need for Repeat Caesarean Deliveries Questioned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Caesarean to capitalize, to conform to AP style throughout
DOC.TEXT: A survey released Tuesday casts new doubt on the old notion that women who have given birth by Caesarean section must always deliver that way. The survey of 2,213 physicians by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists found that 63 percent of women who attempt vaginal delivery after a previous Caesarean section succeed. ``Strides certainly have been made'' to convince women and their physicians that vaginal deliveries are safe and successful alternatives to repeat Caesareans, said Dr. Mary Jo O'Sullivan, secretary of the organization. But she said since about 42 percent of the patients in the survey chose to have another Caesarean, ``there is a need to further educate women'' about the benefits of vaginal deliveries. Vaginal deliveries are less risky than Caesarean sections mainly because the latter is a surgical procedure, said O'Sullivan, associate chairwoman of obstetrics at the University of Miami in Florida. Also, vaginal births are less expensive and the patient spends less time in the hospital _ an average of $4,334 and two or three days compared with $7,186 and four or five days for a Caesarean, according to 1989 data from the Health Insurance Association of America. The rate of Caesarean deliveries rose from 5.5 percent of all U.S. births in 1970 to 24.7 percent in 1988. But O'Sullivan noted that the increase from 1986-87 and from 1987-88 was 0.3 percent, the smallest rise in five years. Also, the rate of vaginal births after Caesareans rose from 2.2 percent in 1970 to 12.6 percent in 1988, she said. O'Sullivan said the rate of repeat Caesareans appears to be tied to the age of the physician. Ninety-eight percent of physicians under 40 said they encourage their Caesarean patients to have vaginal deliveries for subsequent births, compared with 84 percent of physicians over 55. ``It takes a long time to change your practice pattern,'' O'Sullivan said, noting that some smaller hospitals still do not offer the option of vaginal delivery to women with a previous Caesarean. As recently as 15 years ago vaginal birth after a Caesarean was not considered good medicine in the United States, though a standard practice for years in many other countries. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the largest professional organization for physicians in those specialties, recommends that women who have had a low transverse incision in a previous delivery and have no medical complications should be encouraged to attempt labor and vaginal delivery in their current pregnancy. A low transverse incision, which cuts into a non-contracting portion of the uterus, is most commonly used in Caesareans today. It largely replaced what is called the classical incision in which the contracting muscles of the uterus are cut and are more likely to rupture in a subsequent labor.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Defy Order Outlawing Demonstrations in Heart of Capital
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Tuesday outlawed demonstrations in central Bucharest after six days of sometimes violent anti-government rallies, but protesters defied the order. About 100 demonstrators gathered in central University Square for the seventh day, continuing a week of rallies against President Ion Iliescu. They did not, however, block traffic or provoke a massive police response. Earlier Tuesday, the municipality issued a decree saying Bucharest's six main squares ``and their surrounding areas'' were off-limits to demonstrations. That effectively made protests illegal in the entire downtown area. The clampdown follows a series of turbulent protests in central University Square along the capital's main boulevard. Anti-government demonstrators had been gathering daily since Wednesday, blocking traffic and shouting slogans against Iliescu. On Friday, Saturday and Sunday, police clashed with demonstrators in and around the square. The worst violence broke out Saturday night, when about 2,000 anti-riot troops and military police were sent in. Demonstrators threw petrol bombs, bottles and rocks at the police, and 80 people were arrested. At least two people two were reported hospitalized. The new measures are similar to a national decree issued January, which required special municipal authorizations for rallies, and recommended they be held in parks. The January order was widely disobeyed, and protestors held frequent rallies in front of government headquarters in Victory Square during January and February. Bucharest municipal authorities said under the new rules, arrangements would be made to allow demonstrations to be held in four city parks and in stadiums. But posters and slogans throughout the city _ referring to the popular uprising that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in December _ said: ``The revolution was made in the streets, not in parks.'' University Square was the site of a 53-day anti-government protest in June that sparked several days of violence in the capital when the government cracked down on the demonstrators. That rally was organized by students and anti-Communists who accuse Iliescu and his associates _ who won free elections in May _ of continuing Ceausescu's policy. This week's rallies, however, appeared to be motivated by the deteriorating economy and attracted mostly lower-income workers. The governing National Salvation Front charged Tuesday that the demonstrators were harming Romania's image and creating ``a collective feeling of insecurity.'' The army called for ``an atmosphere of calm and order in Bucharest.''

DOC.HEAD: Threat Of Severe Weather In Upper Midwest, Hot Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms developed over the north-central part of the nation for a second day Tuesday, and a heat wave that is forcing some schools to close early continued east of the Rockies. Thunderstorms developing along a cold front over north-central states produced hail as big as golf ball at Lantry, S.D. The weather system also spun off a tornado southwest of Rockford, Ill., the National Weather Service reported. Thunderstorms posed the threat of more severe weather from the middle Missouri Valley through the middle Mississippi Valley to New York state and Pennsylvania. A severe thunderstorm swept through northwestern Pennsylvania early Tuesday, downing power lines and leaving about 11,000 people without electricity. Tree limbs blocked several highways, and police in Oil City said a large tree crashed through the roof of a home. No one was injured. Showers and thunderstorms developed over much of the Gulf Coast region during the afternoon, producing 0.95 of an inch of rain at Brownsville, Texas, during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT. Unseasonably hot weather continued east of the Rockies, with readings mostly in the 90s from the southern and central Plains to the southern and middle Atlantic Coast. Temperatures were above 100 over parts of central Kansas, northern Oklahoma, north-central Texas, western Tennessee and northern Alabama. Some eastern Nebraska schools said they'll close early the rest of this week and high school football coaches planned to rest their players and work out in the morning as a heat wave with temperatures mostly in the 90s entered its sixth day Tuesday. Public schools in Lincoln, Neb., maintained normal hours Monday when it hit 100 but monitored classrooms and decided to shut down an hour early for the rest of the week. ``They felt that as the afternoon went on, it got worse,'' said Meg Lauerman, spokeswoman for the school district. Alabama's hot, dry weather prompted state health officials to issue a critical heat alert Tuesday. Farmers worried that their cotton crops could be cut in half and that they would have to buy feed for livestock lacking hay. ``The cotton is about knee-high to a duck,'' Madison County agent Robert Burton said Tuesday. In Birmingham, Ala., school officials sent some 42,000 students home about two hours early because of the lack of air-conditioning in classrooms at about 30 schools. Tulsa, Okla., cooled down to an overnight low of just 82, and St. Louis, Mo., reported a low of 80. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 34 at Craig, Colo., and West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Authorities Find Two More Bodies; Fear Sweeps University Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with authorities linking five slayings; editing to conform; picks up 16th graf pvs, `State officials ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Two more bodies were discovered Tuesday in this university city, and police linked them to the mutilations of three women students whose deaths set off a wave of fear at the start of the school year. ``It's clear this part of the country has some maniac on the loose,'' University of Florida President John Lombardi said during a staff meeting. ``It reminds us of a natural catastrophe. The killer is selecting victims by criteria that are not clear to us.'' The bodies of a man and a woman were found together Tuesday morning at a student apartment complex near one where two bodies were discovered Sunday, said Alachua County Sheriff's Lt. Spencer Mann. Police set up a command post between those off-campus sites and about two miles from the apartment where a third body was discovered early Monday. The two latest victims were identified as Tracy Inez Paules and a 23-year-old friend, Manuel R. Tobada, both graduates of American High School in Miami. Tobada had just been accepted at nearby Santa Fe Community College and was planning to study architecture, said a friend, Eric Dunham, 22, of Sarasota. Ms. Paules, whose age was not available, reportedly was pursuing a law degree. Gainesville Police Chief Wayland Clifton said ``all five victims are probably connected to one suspect or two suspects'' because the methods of the killer appeared similar. He did not elaborate. The Gainesville Sun, however, reported Tuesday that mutilation of the first three bodies found was the apparent connection. ``I don't think it takes a rocket scientist to figure out that anybody that commits homicide using mutilation is a pretty sick individual, and it's somebody we want to get off the streets very badly,'' said Mann, the Alachua County sheriff's spokesman. ``It looks like it's a part of a serial killer,'' State Chancellor Charles Reed said earlier in Tallahassee. Some students fled home, while others' parents rushed here to guard their children. Some students said the slayings were reminiscent of those by executed serial killer Ted Bundy. Gov. Bob Martinez ordered 50 state troopers and Florida Department Law Enforcement agents and two crime labs to Gainesville. Reed warned other Florida colleges to step up security. FBI agents also joined the investigators. State officials and police urged students not to go out alone, to keep doors locked and use dead-bolt locks, and to keep in touch with their worried parents. Three University of Florida students who live across the street from the apartment complex where the two bodies were found Tuesday said they were going home to Key West. ``We're horrified, we're scared, and we're going home at least temporarily until this thing blows over,'' said Lydia Blanco, 22, who lives with her sister Ileana Blanco, 20, and Lauren Bacle, 19. Joe Colucci said he made the five-hour drive here from his home in Davi to stay with his daughter Jennifer, an 18-year-old freshman. ``I came here to be with my child and protect her as much as possible. If they don't catch someone by this weekend, I'm taking her home,'' he said. In Tallahassee, the governor played down speculation about a Bundy ``copycat,'' even though experts on serial killers were being consulted. Bundy was executed in Florida's electric chair on Jan. 24, 1989, after murdering dozens of young women, including two Florida State University sorority sisters in Tallahassee in a 1978 rampage he followed with the murder of a 12-year-old girl in Lake City. The Florida State Prison where he died is about 25 miles from here. ``That's what we're all saying. It's another Ted Bundy on the loose,'' said Jana Walters, 18, a freshman from Longwood. Dave Krupezaki, 21, a UF student from Miami, said ``with what happened last year with Tiffany Sessions, everybody is afraid.'' Ms. Sessions, a 20-year-old UF student, vanished Feb. 9, 1989, after leaving her apartment to go jogging. No trace of her has been found. On Sunday, authorities found two victims _ freshmen Christina P. Powell, 17, of Jacksonville and Sonya Larson, 18, of Deerfield Beach, who had shared a townhouse apartment. One victim was nude and the other was partially clothed, said police Lt. Sadie Darnell. Eight hours later, deputies found the body of Christa L. Hoyt, 18, a student at Santa Fe Community College and a records clerk at the sheriff's office. Deputies checked on her when she failed to report for her midnight shift. More than three-fourths of all 34,000 UF students live off campus, but 95 percent of the 3,000 freshmen live in dormitories, a school spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Minister Says Peaceful Gulf Solution Widely Favored
DOC.TEXT: Australia's foreign minister said Tuesday the United States and other countries opposed to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait regard military force as a last resort to end the Persian Gulf crisis. ``I am very much more comfortable that the military option has been put very much on the back burner,'' Foreign Minister Gareth Evans told reporters after discussing the crisis with U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III. ``There is ... solid and universal international support for the sanctions strategy ... and that's got every chance of success.'' Earlier, Evans told a news conference, ``it doesn't do any harm to make it very clear that at the end of the day, if this thing is not resolved in any other way, the military option will be further considered ... to make it very clear that you have the clout and are prepared to see all hell break loose ... if there is going to be any more (Iraqi) aggressive action, or if a hair in the head of any hostage is harmed.'' Evans met Baker, Pentagon officials and the news media near the end of a six-day, round-the-world trip discussing the crisis with policymakers and diplomats of European and Arab countries, the United Nations and United States. He planned to fly home via Los Angeles Tuesday night, reporting his findings Thursday to Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke and Parliament. ``The policy of economic sanctions against Iraq is going to have to be in place for some time ... before we can expect a sensible response from the Iraqis, but I am rather more confident than before I embarked that non-military options will prevail ...'' Evans said. Describing both world unity and Iraq's isolation as unprecedented, he said, ``It is appropriate that all policies right now be based on the sanctions route, and I am clear that is the thinking of this (U.S.) administration, certainly the thinking of the Europeans, certainly the thinking of the Arab nations.'' Evans said he met Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in Cairo, officials of the West European community _ currently headed by Italy _ in Venice and Geneva and U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Arab and European U.N. representatives in New York. ``It is absolutely crucial,'' he said, ``that all of us in the international community ... be prepared to sit this out for as long as it takes. Whether the end game involves overthrow (of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein), capitulation without a political package to go with it or whether it does involve some ladders for the Iraqis to climb down remains to be seen,'' Evans said. The important thing is that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait, restore the Kuwaiti government and release foreign nationals desiring to leave, he said. The sanctions could cost Australia $1 billion, including $400 million in annual sales of wheat, meat and dairy products and another $600 million in accumulated debts, Australian officials said. But Australia backs them as the first post-cold war test of the international community's ability to manage regional conflicts by refusing to appease any country believing that might makes right, said the foreign minister. Australia is rushing two heavily armed frigates and a supply ship to the gulf, Evans said.

DOC.HEAD: Hostages' Families Cheered but Still Cautious About Promise of Freedom
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's vow to set women and children free eased some of the tension Tuesday for thousands of families keeping a month-long vigil for loved ones trapped in the Middle East. But their cheers were restrained. ``I don't want to be a downer, but he's said things before ... he said he was going to let all the diplomats go,'' said Pauline Gerard of New Harmony, Ind. ``Everything hinges on this ... and I don't want to be crushed.'' Mrs. Gerard's pregnant sister got trapped in Kuwait when a visit with in-laws collided with Iraq's invasion Aug. 2. Since that day, the family has been waiting for news like this. But when it finally came the Gerards, like many of the hostages' families, reined in their emotions. ``We've been waiting for this almost a month now,'' Mrs. Gerard said. ``I don't want to get my hopes up too much because I don't want to fall down too far if it doesn't work out.'' ``I'll believe it when I see them home in this state,'' said Margaret Nuzum of Hutchinson, Kan. Her daughter, son-in-law and two young children last got a call through from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait on Aug. 19. ``Until them I'm just praying.'' The Coming Home Committee's founder was more effusive. ``It's just an excellent sign,'' said Michael Saba, a Champaign, Ill., businessman who escaped Iraq shortly after the invasion. ``Whether the men are soon to follow or whether that's something that has to be worked out isn't clear, but I'd say the signs are good,'' he said. ``I think we're seeing some signs that say there's some ... interest in de-escalating the situation.'' Saddam's decree, broadcast by the Iraqi news agency, followed a meeting Tuesday with hostages in which he agreed to talk to President Bush and Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher about ending the Persian Gulf crisis. But despite the conciliatory gestures, Baghdad hardened its position on Kuwait, declaring it a 19th province of Iraq. This stand is one that concerns Jo Ellen Buehler, whose sister is married to a Kuwaiti air force officer. ``I'm going to stay excited and keep everyone's spirits as high as I can because that's all we have to clutch onto,'' Buehler said from Memphis, Tenn. ``(But) I don't want to jump the gun.'' Saddam decreed that ``all women and children who are foreigners in Iraq are allowed to move freely in Iraq or to travel whenever they want starting tomorrow, including the families Iraq is hosting,'' the Iraqi News Agency said, in a report monitored in Nicosia. But Buehler said she's worried Saddam means only to free the estimated 500 Americans trapped in Iraq. ``He didn't say anything about Kuwait,'' said Buehler, whose sister and three young nephews are among about 2,500 Americans stuck in the annexed country. ``What about Kuwait?'' Or, worse still, ``what if this is a way of gathering up and carting them off to another place in a larger mass?'' Buehler, who hasn't heard from her sister since Aug. 3, was not alone in her trepidation. Families around the country said they were trying to blot out thoughts of an elaborate, hope-crushing scheme. ``You don't know what they're going to do,'' said Eleanor Gicking of Arlington, Tenn. ``They might even have a trap for them.'' But, in her heart of hearts, Mrs. Gicking said, she can't believe that. She choked up at hearing her baby grandson and daughter, who is married to a Kuwaiti, could be freed Wednesday. ``They're going to get out,'' she said, her voice straining against tears. ``They have to get out.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says Foreign Women and Children Can Leave
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto AX5
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein, in what Baghdad said was a sympathetic response to hostages' pleas for their children's safety, announced Tuesday that foreign women and children would be allowed to leave Iraq. The dramatic announcement came hours after the Iraq president met with a group of foreigners who were trapped by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The official Iraqi News Agency, which carried the announcement, said Saddam was moved by the foreign families' fears over their children's plight. ``We hope it's true,'' State Department spokesman Mark Dillen said of the announcement. But, he noted, ``We have seen promises and statements by Iraq in the past that have proven false.'' He said the department had received no official word of the Iraqi decision and was seeking more information through its embassy in Baghdad. Britain's Foreign Office, too, said it was seeking official confirmation that women and children would be freed. ``We would love to hear it,'' said a spokesman, who by custom was not identified. About 3,000 Americans and 3,300 Britons are among the 21,000 trapped Westerners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Saddam has vowed to use them as human shields against attacks on Iraqi installations. British and U.S. officials say Iraq has moved more than 150 Britons and more than 60 Americans from Kuwait to strategic locations. A statement from the Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council said the decision was made ``to preserve the Arab humanitarian image,'' the official Iraqi News Agency said. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the Iraqi president decreed ``that all women and children who are foreigners in Iraq are allowed to move freely in Iraq or to travel whenever they want starting tomorrow, including the families Iraq is hosting.'' Saddam has consistently referred to the captive foreigners as guests, not hostages, and has told them their presence would help prevent all-out war from erupting. The news agency repeated that view, saying the foreigners were ``prevented from traveling on humanitarian grounds aimed at fending off the fires of war and deterring those seeking to start it.'' But, it said: ``We opted to preserve the Arab humanitarian image'' by freeing the women and children. Western nations have denounced the detentions as hostage-holding. The news agency said the decision was effective Wednesday. It was not clear whether it included foreigner women and children trapped in Kuwait, which Baghdad now considers part of Iraq. It was also not known how many of the trapped foreigners are women and children. In the televised meeting with Western captives at an undisclosed location, Saddam told the group: ``I appreciate your feelings, which probably make you feel restricted because you are not allowed to go.'' ``If I were in your place or my family was in your place, I'd have the same feelings,'' said Saddam, shown wearing a light-colored double-breasted suit, sitting in an armchair beside a coffee table laden with flowers. Some of the foreigners were allowed to ask questions, and they expressed concern about children being held. One of the hostages shown was American Kevin Bazner, according to his sister, Patricia Heath of Farmington Hills, Mich. Bazner, his British wife, Dawn, and their two children were stranded when the plane they were aboard made a refueling stop in Kuwait during the invasion. ``I'm glad I got to see my brother. I'm glad he's safe. I hope Dawn and the kids are safe, too,'' Ms. Heath told Cable News Network. The Iraqi president's meeting with the foreigners was broadcast by CNN. One woman with a British accent asked Saddam why he was using children as leverage ``in something they can't undersand.'' He gave a long answer in which he repeated that he was forced to act because of Western troops massing in the region. A young Frenchman asked if he and his wife could return to France, saying they could then explain to the French people that Iraq had humane intentions. In the broadcast, Saddam complained that the international trade embargo against Iraq was reducing supplies of food and medicine, saying ``children will be undernourished,'' and the cutoff of medicine could cause outbreaks of disease. ``When food is cut off from a society, then you're actually choking the society to death,'' he told the Western hostages. As the broadcast began, Saddam was shown entering a large room and greeting the Western families, shaking hands with men and patting children on the head. It was the second time Saddam visited hostage families in a broadcast intended for Western viewers. He was widely condemned for his first visit last week, which was seen as a crude attempt to gain Western sympathy.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, One Injured in Bank Shootings
DOC.TEXT: A bank employee and customer were shot and killed and another employee was wounded Tuesday during an attempted bank robbery, a sheriff said. A 17-year-old boy was in custody, said Miami County Sheriff Charles Cox. He refused to release the suspect's name. Cox said police received a call after noon from a person who found the doors of the Fifth Third Bank locked. He said deputies kicked in the doors and found the victims, all shot with a handgun, he said. Cox said the victims had multiple gunshot wounds. ``I'm sure the people would have willingly given him the money,'' Cox said. ``But to execute them _ that's senseless.'' There was no immediate word how much money was taken, but Cox said it was recovered in a wastebasket found in the bank parking lot. He said a packet of paint pellets placed in the money had exploded as intended. Such booby traps are intended to startle and mark bank robbers with paint; there was no immediate word if anyone was splattered with paint from that packet. Cox said the suspect was identified by the wounded bank employee. The teen-ager was taken into custody at his home about about one and a half hours later. He said no money was found on the suspect and police were still searching for a weapon. The wounded employee was taken to Miami Valley Hospital in Dayton. A nursing supervisor who refused to give her name said the woman was in critical condition.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Officials Could Be Furloughed, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department's soldiers in the war on crime would have to take time out from the battle if Congress and the Bush administration don't agree on spending cuts, officials said Tuesday. FBI agents, federal prosecutors and other law enforcement officials would be furloughed in the coming fiscal year if a deficit-reduction package is not enacted into law, the officials said. The Justice Department began sending out notices to tell its 80,000 employees they could be furloughed for up to 22 days in the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. The furloughs would be spread out over the 12-month period. A 32 percent spending cut in government agencies will be implemented unless Congress and the White House agree by the end of September on other ways of reducing spending, or raising revenue, to meet the deficit targets in the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law. The notices held out the possibility of longer furloughs if the deficit-reduction package is not approved by Congress. A copy of a budget memo sent to Justice Management Division employees said it would be necessary to impose 70-day furloughs for the entire fiscal year if a budget agreement is not reached during the 1991 fiscal year. Special arrangements will have to be made so that prosecutors who are in the middle of trying crimimal cases in court are not furloughed, officials said. There are about 3,800 federal prosecutors assigned to 94 U.S. attorneys offices nationwide. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, U.S. attorneys and other presidential appointees, such as assistant attorneys general, would not be furloughed. At the FBI, no decision has been made yet whether furloughs would apply to undercover agents, said spokesman Carlos H. Fernandez. But the furloughs would apply to all other FBI employees, including the agents assigned to foreign counterintelligence, Fernandez said. ``We will try to do our duty as best we can, but to say it won't affect operations would be a mistake,'' he said. The FBI employs 9,800 agents and 12,910 support personnel. The Drug Enforcement Administration said it has no plans to furlough its 3,000 agents but will impose a hiring freeze and stop paying overtime to meet the deficit-reduction targets. DEA also will eliminate ``all but essential operational travel, all equipment purchases and repairs and all in-service training,'' said spokesman Bill Ruzzamenti. But the Bureau of Prisons, which houses 57,600 federal inmates in overcrowded prisons, sent furlough notices Tuesday to its 18,500 employees. Each employee would be furloughed for 3 1@2 days per two-week pay period, said Douglas Lansing, assistant director for human resources. Furloughs would make the job of running federal prisons ``incredibly challenging,'' Lansing said. ``That's a euphemism.'' ``We don't think we could do it,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Chief Sounds Warning in Mexican Doctor Case
DOC.TEXT: The new head of the Drug Enforcement Administration said Tuesday the war on drugs may be harmed by a judge's order that could free a Mexican doctor from U.S. prosecution in the murder of a DEA agent. Foreign suspects should not be allowed to leave the country merely because their own governments protest, suggested Robert C. Bonner, who resigned a federal judgeship in Los Angeles to take the DEA job. ``The implications of the case are that anyone who can get a foreign government to issue a note of protest may have a ticket out of prosecution and conviction and sentence in the United States,'' he said. The case concerns Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, wanted in the 1985 kidnapping, torture and murder of DEA Agent Enrique Camarena in Mexico. DEA agents made $20,000 in payments to Mexicans who brought the physician across the border to Texas, where he was arrested by DEA agents in early April and transported to Los Angeles to stand trial. The Mexican government protested the action, saying it violated Mexican sovereignty, and has sought the extradition of a DEA agent and a DEA informant to stand trial on kidnapping charges. U.S. District Court Judge Edward Rafeedie _ until recently a colleague of Bonner _ ordered the physician returned to Mexico, saying the extradition treaty between the two countries was violated. The U.S. Court of Appeals in San Francisco granted a stay of that order, and Rafeedie has denied bail while the appeal is pursued. Bonner said he urged the Justice Department to appeal Rafeedie's decision. The DEA did nothing wrong in bringing Alvarez to the United States, he said. Bonner is a former U.S. attorney in Los Angeles who pushed prosecution of those involved in the Camarena slaying. He said he is committed to pursuing the investigation of the Camarena killing: ``There is no statute of limitations on the murder of a federal agent.'' On another issue, Bonner said he disagrees with recent pronouncements by drug director William Bennett and Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., said that success in curbing cocaine supplies led to increased violence on America's streets this summer.
