If the nation achieves the ultimate objective _ a substantial reduction in the availability and use of illegal drugs _ ``you will have a dramatic and substantial reduction in violent crime in the United States,'' he said. Bonner acknowledged that he was unsure what the interim period might bring in terms of violence. In June, Bennett said increases in the wholesale price of cocaine in several cities around the country indicated that ``we are beginning to have a positive effect on the flow of cocaine into this country.'' Although he had long cited a need to get rid of drugs to help cut down the violence connected to drug-trafficking in the cities, he said disruption of the cocaine flow would have the opposite effect. ``In some of our communities where there is a shortage of cocaine, there will be violence as a result of that,'' Bennett said. ``There will be the same number of dogs fighting over a smaller number of bones.'' Biden said, ``Drug violence is on the rise as the quality of crack cocaine drops and gangs battle for turf.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Security Council Members Approve Major U.N. Role In Cambodia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with cost, U.S. policy change background. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent Security Council members agreed Tuesday on plans for a truce in Cambodia and U.N. administration of the country until a new government is elected. It would be an ``unprecedented'' U.N. operation to solve a regional conflict, one U.S. diplomat said _ costing $3 billion to $5 billion over one or two years, and involving up to 10,000 peacekeeping troops and 10,000 civilian personnel. The five _ the United States, Britain, France, China and the Soviet Union _ ended two days of private talks on details of a transitional administration to guide Cambodia to peace and democracy. ``We have gone as far as we can as the five permanent members,'' said a U.S. diplomat involved in the talks.``Now it is up to the four Cambodian parties. The question is, can the four Cambodian factions agree?'' The diplomat was referring to the Khmer Rouge, its two non-communist guerrilla allies, and the Vietnam-installed government in Cambodia. The diplomat and several other sources spoke on the condition of anonymity. The Cambodian factions are to meet in Indonesia in September. The U.S. diplomat said, ``We think there are grounds, if not for wild optimism, at least for strong confidence'' all parties will agree. A Western ambassador close to the talks said he thought the chances were better than even. On Aug. 22, he said, the three resistance factions issued a communique expressing support for the work of the five permanent Security Council members and willingness to accept military and administrative arrangements, which were worked out earlier. Tuesday's accord means the backers of the warring factions _ the United States, Soviet Union and China _ agree on a peace plan. The Khmer Rouge gets its weapons and supplies from China; the Soviets back the current Cambodian government of Prime Minister Hun Sen; the United States backs the two non-communist guerrilla factions. The Western ambassador said if all goes well, a truce could take effect by November. The U.S. diplomat said the agreement would give the United Nations ``very broad authority to administer and to control Cambodia.'' Its significance regarding U.N. involvement in a regional conflict would far exceed the U.N. role in guiding Namibia to independence from South Africa, which cost more than $750 million. The United States pays 30 percent of all peacekeeping costs. The key issues now, the diplomat said, are organizing a cease-fire and elections so that a new government can be established that is not dominated by the Khmer Rouge or the current pro-Vietnam government. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in December 1978 to oust the Khmer Rouge, who presided over the deaths of up to a million Cambodians from starvation and executions during their brutal rule that began in 1975. For a decade, America followed the position taken by the United Nations and most of the world, of recognizing the three-party guerrilla alliance, including the Khmer Rouge, as Cambodia's legitimate government. After Hanoi announced last year that all its troops had been withdrawn, and the Khmer Rouge began scoring impressive battlefield gains, Washington policymakers fretted more about a possible return to power by the Khmer Rouge than about Vietnam's invasion. In July, Secretary of State James A. Baker III announced Washington was ending its recognition of the guerrilla alliance and would open talks with Hanoi on ending the war. America has not announced any cut-off of aid for Prince Sihanouk's or Son Sann's factions, however. The U.S. diplomats and others involved in the talks said the participants approved five documents to be sent on to the Cambodian factions and others concerned. According to an official statement, these cover ``transitional arrangements regarding the administration of Cambodia during the pre-election period; military arrangements during the transitional period; elections under United Nations auspices; human rights protection; (and) international guarantees'' that Cambodia will be non-aligned, neutral and democratic. They call for a cease-fire; for warring parties to disengage, disarm and settle in U.N.-monitored ``cantonments;'' and for U.N. peacekeepers to move in. The United Nations would organize elections and verify that all Vietnamese forces have indeed left Cambodia. Cambodian guerrillas claim many Vietnamese troops remain in Cambodia in disguise. Western officials believe once the truce takes effect, it would take about a year to get ready for elections. The draft documents call for the United Nations to ``supervise and control . . . if necessary'' five key Cambodian ministries _ defense, foreign affairs, finance, public security and information, various diplomats said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Top East German Communist Arrested In West Germany
DOC.TEXT: West German police on Tuesday arrested a former senior Communist Party official who served under ousted East German leader Erich Honecker. Arrested was Wolfgang Biermann, a former member of Honecker's Communist Party Central Committee and one-time manager of the Carl Zeiss combine in the East German city of Jena. Biermann, 62, who resettled in Saarbruecken in February, was sought by the East German district prosecutor in Gera for allegedly misappropriating property belonging to the Carl Zeiss Institute museum, the Saarbruecker Zeitung newspaper said. The newspaper said East German investigators estimate the value of the museum property at $180,600. The report was provided in advance to other news media and will appear in the newspaper's Wednesday editions. Police in Saarbruecken said Biermann had been arrested but declined to elaborate. Biermann has denied any wrongdoing. The Carl-Zeiss combine is known for producing finely tuned optical equipment among other technical products. Following the collapse of East Germany's hard-line Communist government last year, Honecker and most of his leading lieutenants were arrested for investigation of corruption and abuse of power.

DOC.HEAD: Journalistic Question Raised Again: Do You Edit Saddam Hussein?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pati Heath is cq in 7th graf.
DOC.TEXT: CNN's broadcast Tuesday of Saddam Hussein's latest meeting with Western hostages raised the question: Should news operations give the Iraqi leader live access to U.S. television? ``We would not do that under any circumstances,'' said Bob McFarland, deputy director of news at NBC. ``We made that decision the first day they pumped it out. We decided it was pure propaganda.'' None of the big three American networks _ NBC, ABC and CBS _ carried the Iraqi satellite transmission live on Tuesday, as the Cable News Network did. Instead, they showed portions somewhat later. But CNN management defended its practice, saying the meeting was deemed of sufficient importance to air immediately. ``We make these decisions on a case-by-case basis,'' CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said at the network's Atlanta headquarters. In Tuesday's case, he said, CNN understood that Saddam would be speaking with American hostages. ``There was no question in our minds this would be newsworthy,'' Haworth said. After the coverage, Pati Heath of Detroit, the sister of an American hostage, called CNN to say she had seen her brother on TV. CNN put her on television, too. She wasn't troubled by the dispute over CNN's programming decision. ``I'm just happy to be able to see my brother's face,'' she said. ``I hope Hussein sees me talking right now.' CNN noted that it was relaying an Iraqi TV feed. Afterward, the network aired a debate on the wisdom of its decisions. It is, by all accounts, a somewhat sticky question. ``Wherever there is a hostage videotape, a captive videotape, it's a decision we don't take lightly,'' said Sherrie Rollins, director of news information for ABC in New York. The president of ABC News has to approve the use of such video, she said. When Saddam appeared on television Thursday with Western hostages, ABC broadcast the Iraqi satellite feed for a few moments after first viewing the transmission to gauge its content. ``We did air the material; we did feel it was newsworthy,'' Ms. Rollins said. But when Saddam appeared with hostages again Tuesday, ABC taped the material and showed only a brief portion during a special report, she said. NBC regards the question of whether to air Iraqi feeds as a cut-and-dried journalistic issue, McFarland said from NBC's New York headquarters. ``We would not put Iraqi TV on the air without first knowing what it was,'' he said. ``We took every frame of it into the house, looked at it, and then selected two or three bites.'' CBS officials didn't respond Tuesday to a request for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Key Government Witness Testifies to Open Trial
DOC.TEXT: The chief witness against a paratrooper accused of murder in last year's invasion of Panama acknowledged Tuesday that he shot an unarmed Panamanian in the back during the operation. 1st Lt. Brandon Thomas, the first witness at the court-martial of Master Sgt. Roberto Bryan, said under cross-examination that he had taken the Panamanian prisoner and was searching him when he ran away. ``He seemed to me at the time a potential threat,'' Thomas testified. Thomas said he didn't know the man was unarmed until after he shot him. Bryan, an 82nd Airborne Division paratrooper with a distinguished 19-year record, is accused of shooting another Panamanian without provocation on Dec. 23, three days after the United States invaded Panama to oust dictator Manuel Noriega. He doesn't deny killing the man, but maintains the shooting was justified. If convicted of unpremeditated murder, the military equivalent of second-degree murder, Bryan, 42, could be sentenced to life in prison. The shooting by Bryan occurred after a Panamanian tossed a grenade that wounded 10 soldiers of the 82nd Airborne at a roadblock, authorities said. Thomas said he went up to Bryan, grabbed his M-16 rifle and said, ``... What the hell are you doing? He was almost dead anyway. You didn't have to empty a magazine into him.'' The lieutenant testified that Bryan stepped back with a startled look on his face and said, ```He injured my people.'' Thomas, who helped the Army bring the charge against Bryan and said he hadn't been granted immunity from prosecution, made at least three statements on the Bryan shooting at military hearings. Capt. Steve Lamb, a military attorney representing Bryan, spent most of his cross-examination asking Thomas about discrepancies in his statements. In opening arguments, Capt. Charles Luckey, one of two Army prosecutors, said the case is one of justification and whether Bryan ``did it out of revenge.'' ``The United States of America submits to you that this is a simple case _ not an easy one,'' he said. ``There is no lipstick on the glass, no fingerprints on the windowsill ... but I do have American soldiers to testify about that they saw.'' Bryan's attorney, Mark Waple, said evidence would show that most of the witnesses being called by the prosecution were biased against Bryan. An eight-member military panel, similar to a civilian jury, will decide the case.

DOC.HEAD: Family Settles Lawsuit for $1.7 Million Over Police Custody Death
DOC.TEXT: The family of a young graffiti artist who died after his 1983 arrest in a subway station in what critics said was police brutality reached a $1.7 million settlement Tuesday with the city and the Transit Authority. Leaders in the black community charged that Michael Stewart was a victim of a beating at the hands of white police. Six of the 11 transit police officers involved in his arrest were acquitted of criminal charges in 1985. The agreement, which ends a 4-year-old wrongful death lawsuit, was approved by U.S. District Judge Miriam Cedarbaum. ``I certainly hope justice is done,'' he said. Neither the city nor the Transit Authority admitted liability for Stewart's death. ``There is no admission of any wrongdoing by any transit police officer in the settlement,'' said Barry Agulnick, an attorney representing one of the 11 officers who also were defendants in the lawsuit. The family's lawyers and supporters disagreed. ``There is, as reflected in the size of the settlement, a clear acknowledgement by the defendant parties ... of their responsibility for the wrongful death and subsequent cover-up that occurred in this case,'' said Hazel Dukes, president of the New York state chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``However the defendant parties might wish to put a spin on the closure of this litigation, no amount of words can deny that reality and the vindication encompassed therein,'' Dukes said in a statement. ``Michael Stewart's death was a tragedy. No amount of money can compensate a mother or a father, a sister or a brother for such a loss,'' Mayor David Dinkins said in a statement. ``But I hope this settlement helps members of his family to continue rebuilding their lives.'' Stewart, 25, was arrested Sept. 15, 1983, on charges that he had spray-painted graffiti on the walls of the subway station. Transit police later took him, bruised and unconscious, to Bellevue Hospital, where he died 13 days later. The lawsuit charged that Stewart was beaten by police after his arrest and that the officers concealed their alleged involvement in his death. The family accused the Transit Authority of failing to adequately investigate and discipline the officers involved. In addition, the lawsuit alleged that former city Medical Examiner Elliot Gross obstructed justice by failing to make a proper diagnosis of the cause of death and failing to classify the death as a homicide. Three transit policemen were indicted on charges of manslaughter, criminally negligent homicide, hindering prosecution, reckless endangerment, assault and official misconduct. The indictments were later struck down because one grand juror pursued his own independent investigation. In February 1985, six transit police officers were indicted, three of them for the second time. All six were acquitted of all charges on Nov. 24, 1985. A 1987 report by a special counsel appointed to investigate Stewart's death concluded that excessive restraint was used in his arrest. The special counsel also found that the arresting officer lied about Stewart's condition and was derelict in his duty, and that the investigation of the death by the Transit Authority Police Department was inadequate. Under the settlement, lawyers said, Stewart's parents and brother and sister will receive $920,000. The remaining $780,000 will pay for expenses and lawyers fees.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Force Closing of Statue of Liberty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 7th & 8th grafs, ``Strump said,'' with 2 grafs to raise reference to island closing and update with tickets issued.
DOC.TEXT: Black activists Tuesday pitched tents on Liberty Island, forcing the closing of the Statue of Liberty, to mark the anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s ``I Have a Dream'' speech. They also said they want to rename the city for the slain civil rights leader. Separately, black construction workers drove a honking caravan of trucks and backhoes to City Hall in a demand for more jobs. The Rev. Al Sharpton, a flamboyant and controversial activist, and Lenora Fulani, who is running for governor on the New Alliance Party ticket, led about 100 people from City Hall down Broadway to Battery Park City, a skyscraper development at the lower tip of Manhattan. ``We want to rename New York City, Martin Luther King City,'' Fulani said at a rally at Battery Park City. ``We want to reclaim the city for our people.'' They later headed out to Liberty Island, where Sharpton and an estimated 40 to 80 supporters forced the closing of the Statue of Liberty, said spokesman Manny Strump of the National Park Service. The demonstrators pitched tents there in support of the homeless, said Sharpton ally C. Vernon Mason. Strump said the island was closed at 2 p.m. for the remainder of the day _ it normally closes at 5 p.m. Tourists were taken off the island, he said. At about 5:15 p.m., 14 of the demonstrators, including Sharpton, were ticketed for demonstrating without a permit, said Strumpf. The 14, who face $50 fines, then left the island peacefully on a park service boat, Strumpf said. The rest of the demonstrators had left on their own before the tickets were issued. On Aug. 28, 1963, King gave his ``I Have a Dream'' speech before 200,000 people in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: State's Assault on Encephalitis-Bearing Mosquito Could Be Killing Fish
DOC.TEXT: A $1 million spraying campaign to kill mosquitoes that carry encephalitis also may be killing thousands of tiny fish, but it's nothing to worry about, the state's expert on fish kills said Tuesday. By Tuesday, the dawn and dusk spraying of 700,000 acres in southeastern Massachusetts with malathion that began Monday was more than half completed. The campaign's target is the adult mosquito that carries the sometimes fatal Eastern equine encephalitis virus. The state has monitored the mosquitoes for the virus since the 1930s. The last time anyone in Massachusetts died of the disease was in 1984. If there is a connection between the spraying and fish deaths, it won't harm the food chain and it's no disaster, said Richard Keller, a biologist at the Westboro headquarters of the Division of Fisheries and Wildlife. ``It's not good news,'' Keller said of the dead fish. ``But weighted against the eastern encephalitis (virus), it's something we're going to obviously have to accept. It's certainly not catastrophic.'' The health department said people still need to protect themselves against the mosquito's bite once the spraying ends. The mosquitoes that carry the virus favor the state's swampy southeastern corner. The state is spraying 3 ounces of malathion per acre as long as the temperature is over 62 degrees, the wind is no faster than 10 mph and it doesn't rain. Officials have said the pesticide does no serious harm. They argue that the risk of encephalitis, which causes swelling of the brain and kills 30 percent of its victims, is greater than any that malathion may pose. A 7-year-old boy from Marshfield is the only confirmed case of encephalitis this year. He was in fair condition Tuesday at Floating Hospital in Boston. Four suspected cases are being tested. It will be a few days at least before scientists know whether the spraying program eradicated the mosquitoes it was aimed at. Even then, officials said, it is expected to wipe out only 90 percent to 95 percent of the insects. ``You are reducing the risk substantially, but we don't want people to think there is zero risk,'' said Department of Public Health spokeswoman Mary Ann Hart. ``There will be some mosquitoes around. People should still take precautions.'' Descriptions of dead and sick fish and eyewitness reports ``leads us to believe these are related to the malathion spraying,'' said Keller. But he said results of tests on the fish won't be available for another couple of days. ``It's circumstantial,'' said Keller. ``However, personnel in the field say the fish they have examined exhibit the symptoms of pesticide poisoning, nervous tremors associated with pesticide-related kills.'' Fish kills usually occur at the rate of one or two a week, he said. Since Monday, he has heard of 14 or 15. The dead fish were largely of the minnow-like killifish species, which is around 1 to 1{ inches long and feeds near the water's surface. They were turning up dead in coastal estuaries. Keller said malathion breaks down fast and doesn't accumulate in the food chain.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela Is Already Pumping More Oil
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Venezuela is already pumping more oil to help make up the shortage following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, President Carlos Andres Perez announced Tuesday. Earlier Tuesday, the nation's defense minister announced Venezuela is preparing to step up security at its oil installations against possible sabotage. Perez's statement was Venezuela's first official admission that it was already pumping more oil to help fill Iraq and Kuwait's embargoed supply. ``Our country is already producing additional oil for inventories to be sold to our clients, particularly those in Latin America,'' Perez was quoted as saying in a news release. Perez on Tuesday did not not disclose how much extra oil Venezuela is pumping, but said the nation can increase its output by 400,000 to 500,000 barrels per day. Venezuela joined nine other OPEC nations in supporting in principle an agreement to produce more oil. Perez said an OPEC announcement on the issue was expected Wednesday in Vienna, where cartel officials were meeting. Defense Minister Hector Jurado Toro said Tuesday that the National Guard is ready to move on the operation if the Iraq-Kuwait conflict escalates. ``This is a good idea even for routine situations, and more so in this situation, in which at any moment someone, for whatever reasion, could decide to take an act of sabotage against some of the installations,'' he said in a statement transmitted by the government news agency Venpres. Jurado Toro avoided mentioning Iraq, which vehemently opposes increasing oil production to cover the blockaded supply. Venezuela has been one of the staunchest proponents in the 13-member cartel of increased oil output. Venezuela usually produces about 2 million barrels per day, in compliance with its quota in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Industry sources warned Tuesday that it would take about three months for Venezuela to reach 500,000 barrels of extra daily output.

DOC.HEAD: Fish Species Returning Up Cleaner Ohio River
DOC.TEXT: The paddlefish _ a primitive, long-snouted source of $50-a-pound caviar _ is swimming farther up the Ohio River as pollution is reduced and water quality improves. Biologists are finding the paddlefish and other pollution-sensitive species in the upper Ohio, which had been shunned by such fishes until the 1980s. ``The passport has been cleaner waters,'' Ronald Preston, an aquatic biologist at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Wheeling, W.Va., field office, said Tuesday. Preston plans to present his findings Thursday at a meeting of the American Fisheries Society. About 900 fishery managers, biologists and scientists are attending the four-day meeting, which began Monday in Pittsburgh. Many species of fish disappeared from the river during the first half of the century when industry polluted the water, said William Pearson, fishery biology professor at the University of Louisville. In the past decade, waste has been treated more thoroughly before being discharged. Still, industries, municipalities and government regulators are not off the hook, fish experts cautioned. ``We still have a legacy of pollution,'' Preston said. ``While we've cleaned up the easy things to clean up, we've got a ways to go.'' He said efforts must now focus on runoff from agricultural pesticides and construction sites, storm discharge and cargo spillage. Other species returning to the upper third of the Ohio River are the mooneye and the slenderhead darter. Both are food for other fishes, not humans. ``Their value is in what they represent, cleaner water,'' Preston said. The paddlefish, though, is a highly commercialized fish prized especially for its roe, which can fetch $50 a pound. A single female paddlefish may produce 10 pounds of roe. Having moved south to escape pollution, the paddlefish limited itself to Louisville and points south until the past few years. Now it's being found as far north as Cincinnati, more than 100 miles upstream from Louisville. The paddlefish is expanding its river habitat by about 20 miles a year, Pearson said. Large-mouth bass, crappie and walleye never left the upper Ohio completely and now are thriving in numbers to attract aficionados of sport fishing. Bass even have moved into the Allegheny and Monongahela rivers, which merge to form the Ohio at Pittsburgh. The fish may not be good to eat because of continued pollution from PCBs and chlordane. The two toxic substances are present in fishes in many western Pennsylvania rivers and are eliminated from the body slowly, if at all. States regularly issue public warnings about what is and isn't edible. So the Ohio isn't likely to return to the pristine conditions of the early 1800s, when ichthyologists first documented its diversity of fish. Some species won't be seen again without being artificially re-introduced. ``Some of them got pushed over the edge and can't be brought back without extra measures,'' Pearson said.

DOC.HEAD: Student Opposed To Cat Dissection To Learn Anatomy With Human Cadaver
DOC.TEXT: A community college nursing student who refused to dissect a cat for religious reasons said Tuesday she had resolved her dispute by agreeing to watch the dissection of a human cadaver at another school. ``The difference is the person died of natural causes and donated their body to science,'' said Roseann Charron, 31. ``They do not raise people and kill them and sell them to universities. ``Perfectly good cats are raised specifically for that purpose, stolen and killed and sold,'' she said. Charron's dispute with the Community College of Rhode Island began in June 1989, when school officials told Charron she couldn't complete her licensed practical nursing program unless she passed the anatomy class, which requires dissecting a cat. Charron, a vegetarian and owner of two cats, filed a complaint claiming that breeding animals for laboratory experiments violates the Ten Commandments. Charron asked school officials to substitute a computer simulation or a model instead of a cat. The two sides reached an agreement in July 1989, but it fell through and she eventually hired an attorney. ``This squares with her conscientious beliefs and is more pertinent to her studies as well,'' said Charron's lawyer, Stephen J. Fortunato. Charron said she received final confirmation Friday that she could get credit for taking an anatomy class at the University of Rhode Island in which students watch a human dissection. Charron said she ``really didn't think'' she would have to cut open the cadaver at the university, but wasn't sure. Charron only took one class at the community college last year, and is set for the university anatomy class and three nursing classes there this semester. ``I'm actually very pleased with the alternative,'' Charron said. ``It's certainly a good teaching technique.'' College spokeswoman Lee Chartier said the school had no problem with Charron's arrangement. ``This kind of thing will be handled on a case-by-case basis should it come up again,'' Chartier said. University spokeswoman Linda Acciardo said Tuesday that Charron had registered for the course. Classes start Sept. 5.

DOC.HEAD: Partly Recover From Sharp Slide
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rebounded Tuesday from a slide a day earlier, jumping almost $1 per barrel as traders speculated on diplomatic efforts to resolve the Middle East crisis. Traders also were monitoring OPEC discussions that could lead to boosts in crude oil production, offsetting the shortfall caused by the international boycott of Iraq and Kuwait. Overall, however, market strategists saw no news that could push it wildly in either direction. ``It was such a collapse yesterday that it's getting its breath,'' said Philip L. Dodge, an oil analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. ``OPEC has postponed their meeting, maybe suggesting to some that they're not agreeing on ways to increase production.'' In Vienna, ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries delayed formal endorsement of a plan for production increases to give them more time to hear from absent members Iraq and Libya. The price of light sweet crude, the benchmark grade of oil, rose 97 cents to $27.88 per barrel for October contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Wholesale unleaded gasoline rose .97 cent to 88.53 cents per gallon for September delivery, while home heating oil rose 1.42 cents to 79.52 cents per gallon on September contracts. Natural gas barely budged, closing at $1.500 per 1,000 cubic feet, compared with Monday's close of $1.502 on October contracts. Without cataclysmic news coming from the Persian Gulf, traders pondered the diplomatic nuances and reports of prospects for peace in the region, a crucial provider of petroleum to the United States and other developed nations. By some reckonings, 4 million barrels of oil a day has been removed from the market because of a U.S.-led boycott of crude from Iraq and Iraq-occupied Kuwait. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar planned to meet Thursday with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to discuss the turmoil that has developed since Iraq seized Kuwait Aug. 2. Earlier speculation about a nonviolent solution to the crisis was a partial cause of Monday's $4-per-barrel drop in the price of crude, but some petroleum strategists said Tuesday the market may have overreacted. ``It's almost as if the market has declared peace, but in reality we're still missing 4 million barrels a day of oil,'' said Stephen Smith, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. Others predicted prices would fluctuate, pending outcome of Perez de Cuellar's mission. ``It's just a very choppy market at this point,'' said Ed Kevelson, of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``I think it will chop around for a couple of days. You'll probably see a lot of emphasis put on that meeting.'' After the market closed, the American Petroleum Institute released figures showing that the U.S. stockpile and imports of gasoline declined sharply as the Persian Gulf crisis turned 3 weeks old, while the stockpile and imports of crude oil were slightly higher. Gasoline imports dropped from 545,000 barrels per day to 287,000 barrels per day for the week ending Aug. 24, compared with imports of 515,000 barrels per day a year earlier, API said. The nation's stockpile of gasoline was 210.9 million barrels for the week ending Aug. 24, vs. 214.0 million barrels a week earlier and 223.5 million barrels a year earlier, the trade group said in its weekly report. Analysts following oil prices had predicted supplies of gasoline would tighten because of the loss of three modern Kuwaiti refineries. Other refineries that can boost output are unable to produce gasoline that meets U.S. standards, they said. The nation's crude oil stocks rose slightly, from 375.7 million barrels to 376.6 million barrels, up from 337.3 million barrels a year earlier, API said. Crude oil imports were up to 6.6 million barrels per day, compared with a rate of 6.5 million barrels per day a week earlier and a year earlier. API said the nation's refineries were running at 92.4 percent of capacity, up from 92.3 percent a week earlier and 91.2 percent a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Halts, Boards Cargo Ships Near Jordan
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Navy warships enforcing the U.N. embargo against Iraq stopped two cargo ships and crewmen boarded one in the Gulf of Aqaba before allowing them to proceed to Jordan, shipping sources said Tuesday. In Washington, the Pentagon said the American naval flotilla operating in the waters around the Arabian Peninsula to enforce economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations has brought shipping to and from Iraq ``virtually to a halt.'' Since the Navy put itself into position to enforce the U.N. sanctions in the Persian Gulf, the Red Sea and elsewhere, about 170 ships have been ``intercepted,'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said. Williams said this total includes ships identified or signalled to, or whose intent and cargo has been learned. He told reporters ``only a handful of ships have actually been boarded,'' defining that as less than 10. On Aug. 18, two Navy frigates fired warning shots across the bows of two Iraqi tankers, but both ships refused to stop. The London-based Lloyd's shipping agency, which monitors maritime traffic worldwide, said the Navy boarded the Greek-owned container ship Zorba Express and stopped the Indian-owned vessel Kalidas on Monday near the mouth to the Gulf of Aqaba. Both ships were allowed to proceed when the Navy determined the cargoes were not bound for Iraq. The agency also said that on Sunday, the U.S. Navy denied the French container ship Paris entry into the Gulf of Aqaba. It did not give details. U.S. media reports said Monday that Iraq has issued new orders to its ships, telling them to stop if challenged and not to defy U.S. warships. The Iraqi ambassador to Washington, Mohammed Sadiq al-Mashat, appeared to confirm the report on ABC TV's ``Nightline.'' ``We are doing our best ourselves to defuse the tension _ I mean, the order that we have given to the captains of the ship not to resist...,'' he said. A Western diplomat in the gulf, without giving specifics, said the Iraqis did seem to be folowing that order. However, gulf-based shipping executives, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were unaware of any Iraqi-flagged ships currently at sea in either the Persian Gulf or the Red Sea. The United Nations ordered the embargo on trade with Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait. The U.N. Security Council agreed Saturday that military force could be used to uphold the sanctions against Iraq. Jordan's port of Aqaba, once a main trading point for Iraqi goods, has been brought to a near standstill by the U.N. sanctions. Lloyd's said the port is almost empty and that the trucking fleets operating out of the port are almost idle. It said Jordan has ordered all shipping agents not to transit Iraqi cargoes through Aqaba with the exception of food, pharmaceuticals and medical products. About 70 warships from Western countries are participating in the multinational force in the gulf, the Red Sea and the Mediterranean.

DOC.HEAD: Sununu Meets With Shevardnadze
DOC.TEXT: John Sununu, President Bush's chief of staff, shared his experience in managing the White House bureaucracy with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Tuesday, Soviet media reported. Sununu is in Moscow this week at the invitation of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to help Kremlin leaders improve their office procedures and tame the huge Soviet bureaucracy. The U.S. Embassy said the meetings would be closed to American reporters, and that neither Sununu nor members of his entourage would be available to the press. But the Soviet press agency Tass said Sununu and Shevardnadze ``discussed exchanges of experience in organizing the work of state agencies, which is another vivid confirmation of growing trust between the two countries.'' Tass said U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock also took part in the discussions.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Trustee Orders Closing of 101-Year-Old Hotel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT year to 1889 sted 1899.
DOC.TEXT: A court-appointed bankruptcy trustee has ordered the closing of the 101-year-old Hotel Barre, which catered to three presidents but has been operating under Chapter 11 protection since February 1989. Trustee David M. Nickless ordered the shutdown Monday, saying he saw little chance of the stately hotel reopening during the liquidation. ``It sounds like they would continue to lose money and that would put the creditors further in the hole,'' Nickless said. Built in 1889 in a style that suggested a Mississippi River steamboat, the three-story hotel had 36 guest rooms, 11 fireplaces and an elegant dining room. Guests included Theodore Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson and Calvin Coolidge. It was sold in 1985 for $265,000 to new owners who recreated its lavish Victorian atmosphere. The hotel has been listed for sale since 1987 for $2.6 million unfurnished, or $3.6 million furnished.

DOC.HEAD: Judge OKs Exhumation of Proposed Saint's Body
DOC.TEXT: A judge Tuesday gave the Roman Catholic Church permission to exhume the remains of a former Haitian slave proposed for canonization as the United States' first black saint, nearly weeping as she read her ruling. The Archdiocese of New York wants to exhume Pierre Toussaint's remains for identification by a pathologist and church officials, said Monsignor Robert O'Connell, who heads the cause for Toussaint's canonization. Church records show that Toussaint, who died a free man in New York in 1853 at age 87, was buried at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral on Mulberry Street in what is now Little Italy. O'Connell said Toussaint's remains eventually will be buried beneath the altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth Avenue, where all New York archbishops and Bishop Fulton J. Sheen are interred. Acting state Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob granted permission to exhume Toussaint's body. ``It is rare that this court has an opportunity to participate in such a historic event, if only tangentially,'' Gangel-Jacob said. Court papers referred to Toussaint as ``a model of charity'' who is considered the founder of Catholic Charities because he helped the needy for 66 years before formal systems of assistance existed. Gangel-Jacob said Toussaint had lived ``a long and apparently virtuous life,'' giving money to the poor and nursing the ill during yellow fever plagues that swept New York City. ``In those times the only consolation may have been the miracles of faith and trust,'' Gangel-Jacob said, struggling to keep from weeping. After pausing as her voice broke, Gangel-Jacob said, ``Indeed, for the thousands of victims of the scourge of AIDS, Alzheimer's disease, melanoma and other currently incurable diseases, the same may be true today.'' The judge refused to tell reporters what had moved her as she read her decision. O'Connell said the church is investigating two miracles attributed to Toussaint. One involves a Haitian man who claimed he was cured of lung and stomach cancers by praying to Toussaint. The second is claimed by a Miami woman who said Toussaint cured her breast cancer. According to a church brochure, Toussaint was born into slavery in Haiti in 1766. At 21, he was brought to New York by John Berard du Pithon and his family, for whom he worked as a slave. He was apprenticed to a women's hairdresser. After Pithon died, his family fell into poverty. Toussaint secretly supported them for 20 years until the widow, Marie, remarried. She repaid him by arranging for his freedom. Toussaint then bought the freedom of several other slaves, including Juliette Noel, whom he married in 1811. O'Connell said canonization by the Congregation for the Causes of Saints in Rome could take years, and will involve lengthy investigations and hearings.

DOC.HEAD: Some 80,000 Soviet Jews Arrive So Far This Year
DOC.TEXT: About 80,000 Soviet Jews have arrived in Israel so far in 1990, Israel Television reported Tuesday. A government official said the influx this month is expected to be the largest in more than three decades. The number of Soviet immigrants has reached 16,000 so far this month, the state-run television said. Gad Ben-Ari, a spokesman for the quasi-government Jewish Agency that helps handle immigration, said the August total is expected to reach some 17,000 to 18,000, a record monthly figure since the 1950s. Israeli officials expect a total of some 150,000 Soviet Jews to immigrate by the end of the year. Ben-Ari said the Soviet immigration rate does not appear to be affected by the Persian Gulf crisis. Under Mikhail S. Gorbachev's loosening of emigration, the Soviet Union has issued visas for 234,000 people to emigrate during the first seven months of 1990, more than twice as many as in the same period last year, Soviet officials said Tuesday. Most of the Soviet visas _ 132,400 _ were issued to people wanting to go to Israel. The second largest number, 73,400, went to West Germany. About 16,800 left for Greece, and 5,300 for the United States, according to figures released by the Soviet Interior Ministry's visa office. Rudolf Kuznetsov, head of the visa office, complained at a news conference in Moscow that the office has run short of blank passports to issue to Soviet citizens wishing to travel abroad. He said the Soviet enterprise Goznak can supply only one-fifth the required number of blanks, and the state would have to allocate $16 million to solve the problem. Permission to travel abroad, and particularly to the West, used to be very difficult for ordinary Soviet citizens to obtain. Under Gorbachev's reforms, increasing numbers of people have been able to see the world.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Says Eastern Europe Must Work To Overcome Ethnic Strife
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel warned Tuesday it will take vigilance and care to keep the ethnic minorities of Central Europe from turning on each other as ``proxies for the totalitarian system.'' Some groups are seeking a focus for their anger after discovering the extent of ``the awful legacy left us'' by decades of Communist rule, Havel said during a debate about ethnic conflicts at a conference in Norway's capital. The four-day seminar, which began Sunday, was called by 1986 Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel to explore the roots of ethnic, religious and political hatred and how to overcome it. About 70 world leaders, Nobel laureates and activists were attending the gathering. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, who wants to lead his Baltic republic out of the Soviet Union, agreed that long-suppressed ethnic conflicts have boiled to the surface in countries where democracy is taking hold. ``Maybe this is why Western Europe, even now ... strangely interprets Eastern Europe's spring as a winter of frightening instability,'' Landsbergis said. French President Francois Mitterrand said in order to maintain peace, the world must cooperate to enforce international law. He had a timely example to offer _ the Persian Gulf crisis. ``This is an appeal for courage,'' Mitterrand said, reminding listeners of Nazi expansionism in World War II. ``We must refuse from the outset (Iraq's) use of force.'' He said France is fully committed _ with air, sea and land forces _ to countering Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of neighboring Kuwait and threats to foreigners trapped in the two countries. ``International law must prevail over force, over antagonism,'' he said. He pointed out that Western Europe, despite two conflagrations this century, had found peace through economic cooperation. ``We could call it a victory over hate,'' Mitterrand said. Mitterrand urged the eventual inclusion in the European Community of East Bloc nations that have abandoned authoritarian Communist systems. Havel said he was optimistic that the ethnic groups of Eastern Europe could eventually live in peace. ``If I speak of the nationalist hatred in Central and Eastern Europe, I am not talking about it as our certain future but as a potential threat,'' he said. After four decades spent in the Communist mold, ethnic groups are rediscovering their individuality, he said. ``After all they have gone through, they feel a natural need to make their existence quickly visible,'' he said. Havel said it will take care to keep the ethnic groups from turning on each other as ``proxies for the totalitarian system.''

DOC.HEAD: Many a Slip Twixt a Horn and a Record
DOC.TEXT: A neighbor complained, the police were unsympathetic, and finally a sore gum stopped Liam Kite's pursuit of a world record for playing the French horn. It's something he wouldn't try again, he said Tuesday _ ``not in the foreseeable future.'' The stunt was organized to raise money for the Skegness junior band, which has more members than instruments, Kite said. The 25-year-old optician began his pursuit of the record of 32 hours at 11 a.m. Saturday, playing ``All Through the Night'' from one of his pile of hymn books and attended by the required number of witnesses. At about 7 p.m., he said, a neighbor had wearied of the music _ Kite had reached ``Praise, My Soul, the King of Heaven'' _ and called the police, who ordered him to move on. During his permitted five-minute break, the only venue he could find was a toilet in a nearby amusement arcade. Kite, his time-keeper, his two official witnesses and the keeper of his three horns selected cubicles and pressed on until they could move to a theater he had hired for 10 p.m. Meanwhile, he said, he cut his gum. It didn't bother him at first, he said, but it started to throb overnight. ``It was very painful indeed,'' he said. At 4:30 a.m. Sunday, after playing ``Nearer My God to Thee,'' Kite gave up _ more than 15 hours short of his goal. The record would have been unofficial. The Guinness Book of Records has entries for longest performances on an accordion (85 hours), bagpipes (120 hours), flute (61 hours), guitar (300 hours) and electric organ (440 hours), but nothing for the horn. For the Skegness junior band, however, it paid off. ``We think it looks in the region of 600 to 700 pounds ($1,200-$1,400), so that's going to be quite nice,'' Kite said.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Promises Inquiry Into Claims of Police Involvement in Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UDPATE with Mandela comment. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Government officials..'
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk told church leaders Tuesday he would investigate charges that police sided against supporters of the African National Congress in recent township violence. Black leaders have blamed police for fueling the two weeks of savage street fights in black townships around Johannesburg that killed more than 500 people. Police said two black men were killed in unrest Tuesday, but the townships were peaceful for a fourth straight day following a government crackdown. Also Tuesday, police raided the headquarters of South Africa's largest labor federation and arrested its secretary general, Jay Naidoo, and two others. The three were charged with kidnapping, robbery and assault. All three were later released on bail, and Naidoo denied the charges. The raid followed a news conference at Naidoo's Congress of South African Trade Unions, where officials presented a man they said had been spying for the police, the independent South African Press Association reported. A delegation of church leaders, including Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu and the Rev. Frank Chikane, head of the South African Council of Churches, met in Pretoria with de Klerk and Adriaan Vlok, the law and order minister. After the two-hour meeting, Chikane told journalists the president had pledged to investigate charges that police aided Zulu-based Inkatha supporters in the fighting against Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the African National Congress. ANC leader Nelson Mandela, Tutu and other anti-apartheid figures have said police bias toward Inkatha inflamed the situation. They accused police of disarming and scattering ANC supporters while allowing Zulus to weapons. Mandela on Tuesday renewed charges that the government was not moving to settle weeks of bloody unrest. ``The police are inflaming the conflict,'' the ANC leader said after arriving in the Algerian capital for meetings with President Chadli Bendjedid and other officials. Government officials have denied the charges. De Klerk has previously said individual officers may have acted improperly, but the police force as a whole followed orders to be impartial. The fighting erupted Aug. 12 in Johannesburg area townships and raged for two weeks until the government declared a de facto state of emergency and poured in more police and soldiers. It was considered the worst unrest since the mid-1980s. Officials said more than 18,000 township dwellers were left homeless by the fighting. The press association reported Tuesday that analysts estimated it would cost $80 million to replace the 2,000 houses, shops and factories destroyed. Chikane said Tuesday's meeting with de Klerk also covered compensation for victims of the violence and the problems of migrant worker hostels in the townships. Most of the clashes involved hostel residents clashing with rival township dwellers. Tutu said de Klerk had treated the group as respected leaders, unlike previous presidents. ``The difference between him and the others is there was no finger-wagging,'' Tutu said. ``We give him credit for taking seriously the issues before us.'' Police said a 20-year-old man was shot to death Tuesday in Vosloorus, southeast of Johannesburg, and a man was stabbed to death in Umgababa, in the eastern province of Natal. More than 5,000 blacks have died in Inkatha-ANC clashes in Natal over the past five years. The government and many neutral observers portray the conflict as mostly tribal fighting linked to the power struggle between the ANC and Inkatha. Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi has blamed the ANC for instigating the fighting, saying the ANC wants to crush all opposition. The ANC contends Inkatha spread the fighting from Natal to the Johannesburg townships to broaden its constituency. Both groups oppose apartheid but differ on the shape of a future South Africa. Under South Africa's apartheid system of racial segregation, the 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy, and blacks have no voice in national affairs. De Klerk says he wants to end apartheid and negotiate a black-white power-sharing agreement with the ANC and other opposition groups.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomatic Dependents Arrive Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf: ``The Americans,'' to CORRECT Sunday departure point from Kuwait to Baghdad
DOC.TEXT: Forty-seven wives and children of U.S. diplomats reached American soil Tuesday evening after three hard days on the road and in the air putting the perils of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait behind them. ``God bless America,'' proclaimed one leader of the group glad to be home. A chartered jet carrying the 20 women and 27 children touched down almost exactly 48 hours after their 13-car convoy crossed the Iraqi border into Turkey. Many of the youngsters carried stuffed animals as they descended onto the tarmac at Andrews Air Force base near Washington to board buses with their families for an undisclosed hotel. Many of the wives left behind husband who were denied permission by the Iraqi government to accompany their families home. Earlier in the day, the State Department said Iraqi authorities were continuing to round up Americans, taking nine more into custody. Iraq also informed the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad that a 56-year old American died of a heart attack in the port city of Basra. Luz Marina Colwell, wife of the the U.S. consul in Kuwait, William Colwell, fought back tears in a planeside conversation with reporters thanking the Bush administration for bringing the group home. ``During the present crisis we learned to know each other, to care for each other and we became a big family,'' Ms. Colwell said. ``But our hearts are left in Kuwait and Baghdad with all our husbands, members of our families, our private American citizens and members of the international community left behind,'' she added. ``We had to keep being strong and keep our hearts very high. God bles America,'' she concluded. Left behind in Iraq where three young American men, children of U.S. diplomats in Kuwait who were denied permission by Iraqi authorities to accompany the group home when it was realized they were over 18. An additional 54 or 55 U.S. personnel, mostly men, who had been stationed in Kuwait remained behind in Baghdad and are still seeking permission to leave. The Americans left Kuwait late Thursday for Baghdad. They left Baghdad Sunday morning and drove about 20 hours in desert heat through Iraq before crossing into Turkey at 6 p.m. EDT Sunday. Five of the 52 who arrived at the border did not make the flight to Washington. The U.S. embassy in Baghdad was informed that Iraq plans to expel an unspecified number of American envoys in response to the State Department decision Monday to order 36 Iraqi Embassy staff members out of the United States by Thursday. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said six Americans were arrested in Iraq and three in Kuwait since Monday, bringing the total to 70 _ 48 in Iraq and 22 in Kuwait. The dead American was in Iraqi custody at the time he died. Ms. Tutwiler was unable to identify him but said Iraqi officials have agreed to conduct an autopsy. U.S. officials asked that a competent physician chosen by the embassy be present and that the remains be delivered to U.S. custody as soon as possible. She said the death ``underscores the barbaric nature of Iraqi policy towards foreign nationals in Iraq and Kuwait, and makes a lie of Iraq's claim that they are all well treated and in no danger.'' Ms. Tutwiler said Iraqi officials have not responded to U.S. requests concerning 15 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait with special medical needs who the administration believes should be allowed to leave the country immediately. The dead American was not among the 15, she said. There was no immediate State Department response to the announcement of President Saddam Hussein that all foreigners who are women and children in Iraq will be allowed to leave. As for the Iraqi decision to expel U.S. diplomats, Ms. Tutwiler said the United States was awaiting clarification of the Iraqi demand. The head of the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, Joseph Wilson, was informed of the decision Tuesday morning by Iraq's chief of protocol. Wilson also was informed that unspecified restrictions would be imposed on embassy funds. The Iraqi action occurred less than 24 hours after the State Department ordered a reduction in the Iraqi Embassy staff here from 55 to 19 and imposed strict travel restrictions on those left behind. The U.S. action was prompted by an Iraqi demand that the United States and other countries close their embassies in Kuwait. That order has been widely ignored. For the second day in a row, Ms. Tutwiler said the State Department has received reports of additional Americans having fled Iraq and Kuwait. Two weeks ago the State Department estimated that there were 2,500 Americans in Kuwait and 500 in Iraq who were not free to leave. Since Americans have departed the two countries over the past two weeks, those figures are now obsolete. But no updated estimates have been disclosed because the State Department has refused to say how many have escaped.

DOC.HEAD: Multinational Forces Considering Request For U.N. Air Embargo
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The following dispatch is from a pool reporter for The Associated Press, Reuters and Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency.

Defense sources disclosed Tuesday night that the multinational forces are considering seeking a U.N. resolution for an air blockade to stop sanction-busting flights to Baghdad. The sources believe the blockade, which would involve all of Iraq's neighbors banning Iraqi-bound planes from their airspace, would tighten the noose around Baghdad's war-ravaged economy. The move comes after reports that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was building stores of grain and meat before his invasion of Kuwait. A senior defense source in the Middle East, speaking on condition he was not identified, said: ``There is some evidence that he has filled his granaries and ordered meat. ``It is alleged that before the invasion there may have been a lot of early purchasing going on.'' He added: ``There is no evidence that he is running short.'' Any aerial blockade would heighten tension in the Persian Gulf but would also help prevent an inevitable and fatal split in global solidarity against Iraq should sanctions take too long to bite. The British are confident they have the right to impose both naval and air blockades under the U.N. charter but accept other nations may want a resolution specifically covering action against sanction-busters. On Saturday, the U.N. Security Council passed a resolution backing use of force to impose the naval blockade. Earlier Tuesday, at a news conference at Saudi Arabia's massive Dhahran air base, British Defense Secretary Tom King said British forces could remain in the gulf even if Saddam bows to world pressure and quits Kuwait. After visiting Britain's vanguard squadron of Tornado fighters and holding discussions with the local Saudi air commander, Prince Turki, King hinted at a prolonged stand-off in the sand between Iraq and the multinational forces. Pledging to achieve Kuwait's liberation and the restoration of its ousted rulers, by peaceful means if possible, King said: ``We are here to achieve those objectives but we would need confirmation that the situation could not deteriorate again. ``We would want to ensure that there was a secure and stable situation.'' Britain has three squadrons of Tornadoes and Jaguars, 11 warships and support vessels, Nimrod aircraft and 150 soldiers from the Signals Regiment deployed in the gulf. King refused to rule out any military option and a Ministry of Defense team is assessing deployment of more forces during while King meets gulf leaders on his three-day regional tour.

DOC.HEAD: Calif. Assembly Rejects Proposal To Teach Military Necessity of Camps
DOC.TEXT: The California Assembly on Tuesday soundly rejected a proposal which urged schools to teach that the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II was a military necessity. The resolution, introduced by a legislator who served in the Marines, maintained it's wrong to teach that Japanese-Americans were put in ``concentration camps.'' It portrayed the ``relocation,'' as it was called at the time, as a reasonable reaction of people frightened by Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor. The measure was intended to counteract another non-binding resolution approved by the state Legislature last year that called the wartime detentions a human rights violation driven in part by racism. The new resolution was rejected by the Assmebly 60-4. Only the author, Republican Assemblyman Gil Ferguson, a retired Marine spoke in favor of it. Eleven lawmakers opposed it with emotional and anecdotal speeches. ``It unnecessarily reopens wounds that should and must be allowed to heal,'' Minority Leader Ross Johnson, a Republican, said in leading the bipartisan opposition. Ferguson's measure was aimed at one by Democratic Assemblywoman Jackie Speier, that the Legislature passed last year. Speier's measure, which isn't a law but an expression of the Legislature's opinion, urged the state and its school districts to use textbooks that show the internment of Japanese-Americans was ``a violation of human rights rather than an act of military necessity.'' Speier's resolution noted a conclusion of the federal Commission on Wartime Relocations and Internment of Civilians about internment of more than 110,000 Japanese-Americans in fenced, guarded camps. The internment, the commission said, ``was not justified by military necessity and the decisions which followed from it _ detention, ending detention and ending exclusion _ were not driven by analysis of military conditions.'' Speier's resolution added that, ``The broad historical causes which shaped these decisions were race prejudice, war hysteria and a failure of political leadership.'' Ferguson's resolution urged the state and school districts ``to adopt a broad range of instructional materials that discuss and reference these events and facts ... so as to offer California students an honest, objective and balanced education concerning this period in our history.'' Ferguson's proposal stated, ``It is simply untrue that Japanese-Americans were interned in concentration camps during World War II.'' ``The people of California and the designated war zone areas had good reason to fear an invasion attempt after the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor as Japanese submarines cruised off our coast, barrage balloons flew over our harbor areas and great parts of the zone existed under blackout conditions,'' the resolution said. It also said any history that ``omits the attack on Pearl Harbor and the war as a major factor in our nation's relocation policy unfairly denigrates the character of a generation of Americans, including all who fought in that war or who merely were alive at the time.'' Ferguson said Speier was trying to rewrite history. ``For the first time in the history of America, a bunch of politicians are acting as they do in Russia or China and revising history and telling teachers how they should teach,'' Ferguson said. ``I admire and respect Japanese-Americans,'' he said. ``I agree it was a tragic period in our history. I'm sure there was racism in American, just as there is now and is in every country in the world.'' Arguing against the measure, Johnson said: ``What happened was wrong if even one U.S. citizen was denied his or her constitutional rights or freedom not because of what they did but because of who they were. It should never have happened. It must never be allowed to happen again.'' ``This measure (Ferguson's resolution) says somehow if you're really upset and really concerned, it's OK to violate your civil rights,'' added Republican Assemblyman Charles Quackenbush.

DOC.HEAD: Police Seize 2,600 Pounds of Cocaine in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Police seized about 2,600 pounds of pure cocaine and arrested eight people in a raid on a jungle laboratory in southeastern Colombia, a national police bulletin said Tuesday. The drug bust Monday was the biggest since President Cesar Gaviria took office Aug. 7. A special anti-drug police unit in U.S.-made helicopters swooped on the lab and confiscated a DC-3 airplane, two vehicles, three electrical plants and 11 tons of chemicals used to process cocaine, the report said. It said police also discovered three clandestine landing strips. Security forces have seized about 43 tons of cocaine so far this year. The figure for all of 1989 was 33 tons. Police in southwestern Colombia last weekend destroyed a sophisticated drug-processing laboratory capable of producing about 1,500 pounds of cocaine a week, according to a police statement broadcast on Caracol radio network. Colombia's Medellin and Cali cartels supply much of the cocaine consumed in the United States and Europe. Authorities released Fabio Ochoa on Tuesday, the father of three reputed leaders of the Medellin cartel, his wife said. In a statement Tuesday over local TV, Margoth Ochoa said she and her husband were detained overnight at Ochoa's luxury ranch on the outskirts of Medellin, Colombia's second largest city. She said about 50 workers also were detained. The Ochoas' sons _ Jorge Luis, Juan David and Fabio _ are presumed leaders of the cartel. She said security forces in helicopters descended on the ranch Monday _ ``Apparently they were looking for my son Jorge Luis.'' Jorge Luis Ochoa, 41, is considered No. 2 man in the cartel, after Pablo Escobar, and is wanted on drug trafficking charges in the United States. The senior Ochoa, a lifelong rancher, faces no criminal charges. Cartel leaders have been blamed for killing about 500 Colombians in the past year, including three presidential candidates. The Ochoa brothers, along with Escobar, remain at large despite a police and army dragnet to catch them. The government's yearlong war with drug traffickers appeared to be winding down Tuesday as barricades against car bombs were removed from around the capital's government buildings. No major traffickers have been arrested, and the cocaine is still flowing to the United States. Both the government and the Medellin cartel have moved toward defusing the conflict. President Gaviria has said nothing publicly about easing the war against the traffickers, but signs are clear he is looking for some sort of understanding with the Medellin cartel toward ending the violence. The cartel declared a truce July 27, 11 days before Gaviria took office. On Aug. 7, Gaviria hinted in his inaugural speech he might end extradition of trafficking suspects to the United States if the cartel ended its campaign of terrorism. On Aug. 16, Justice Minister Fabio Giraldo said a state of siege would be lifted if the cartel halted its terrorism, and that the next step would be an end to extradition. On Sunday, Bogota Mayor Martin Caicedo said police and private guards for government officials and businessmen must start obeying traffic laws. Escort vehicles crammed with guards toting submachine guns and shotguns have been allowed to force traffic to the side of the road and disregard traffic lights and speed limits. Pedestrians have to run for their lives when they find the bulletproof cars and escort vehicles tearing down streets. Ending extraditions would probably be the biggest single conciliatory gesture toward the Medellin cartel. Drug traffickers stand in dread of being extradited. In Colombia, they have been able to threaten or bribe their way out of trouble.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Students Angry, Fearful After Five Killed
With AM-Gainesville Slayings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fear and anger swept through the University of Florida on Tuesday as students reacted to mounting evidence that five young people had fallen prey to a serial killer. ``We want answers, not double talk,'' a female student told city Police Chief Wayland Clifton at one of two counseling and information sessions held by police and university officials. Hundreds of students left school and went home temporarily, many at their parents' urging, after the bodies of a young woman and a young man were discovered Tuesday, school officials said. Most at the 34,000-student university stayed and continued with classes. The bodies of two young women were discovered Sunday and a third on Monday. All five were killed at off-campus apartment complexes that house students. Reinforcements from the Florida Highway Patrol, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and other agencies poured into town. They patrolled the campus and dozens of apartment complexes where many of the 20,000 students live off campus. Julie Basch, an 18-year-old student at nearby Santa Fe Community College, said she was returning to her home in Orlando. Her parents ``told me I'm coming home,'' she said. A junior journalism student at the university, who refused to identify herself, said her father was coming in from Tallahassee to bring her a gun he'd bought for her. ``I'll stay for a while, but I may drop out this semester,'' she said. More than 1,200 students jammed a student center auditorium to hear Clifton, university President John Lombardi and others explain the killings and outline precautions they should take. Clifton came under fire from students at the two hour-long meetings for holding back information on the killings and refusing to say whether break-ins were involved. Police said there were no signs of forcible entry in the apartment of the first two victims, but Alachua County officials have declined to discuss the method of entry in the other two apartments. ``At least tell us that so we can know what we should do,'' said student Karyn James. ``Here we are buying all kinds of locks and deadbolts, and we don't even know whether we should.'' ``You're not giving us enough information!'' a male student yelled at the chief, expressing the frustration of others in the audience. Police identified the victims late Tuesday. Three of the young women were university students and the fourth woman was from Santa Fe Community College. The male victim was an incoming student at Santa Fe. Clifton, the sheriff's office and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement refused to give specifics of how they died. Officials said they didn't want to release information that would hamper their investigation. Clifton said there was a lot of physical evidence that pointed to one or two suspects. Some of the bodies were mutilated, he said. While some of the students who live in Florida or nearby were going home, others expressed concern because they could not. Carol McCormac, a graduate student in forestry from Scio, Ore., said she and her boyfriend had moved in with friends of his in Gainesville. ``I just arrived a week ago,'' she said. ``Welcome to Gainesville. ... I don't think we're getting enough answers.'' ``People are all stressed out. ... They're scared,'' said Jacob Mellonheim, 19. ``People are getting together, they're not staying alone.'' University officials arranged to provide temporary campus housing at dormitory lounges and other buildings for any single woman who did not want to stay by herself off-campus. The county Crisis Center and the University Counseling Service provided special phone numbers and offered assistance to students. All students, particularly women, were told repeatedly to call home to assure their parents they were all right. ``You know you're all right but your parents and friends don't know you're all right. So please call home,'' said university President Lombardi.

DOC.HEAD: South Carolina Coast Dwellers Eye Their G's and H's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 14-15 to update with evening storm positions.
DOC.TEXT: Hurricanes beginning with G's and H's tend to make people along the coast a little nervous. There was Hazel in 1954, Gracie in 1959, Gilbert _ which raked the Caribbean in 1988. And then there was Hugo. It's no wonder people are keeping an eye on Gustav and Hortense, and an ear to the phone at national hurricane central in Coral Gables, Fla. ``People are saying, `It better not come hit us; we just got our house put back together,' '' said Darryl Graham, an employee at Isle of Palms Hardware. Many residents on the Isle of Palms are still living in houses with plastic covering the holes left by last September's Hurricane Hugo, which killed 29 people in South Carolina and caused an estimated $5.9 billion in damage. ``Folks around (here) are planning to load everything up and head out early if it even looks close, but we aren't selling batteries and water yet,'' he said. Despite word from the National Weather Service that Hurricane Gustav and Tropical Storm Hortense will skip the East Coast, coastal residents are wary. Gustav, with winds of 105 mph, began turning north Sunday night, and Hortense is continuing a northward path that should keep both well out in the Atlantic Ocean, said Silvia Graff, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service's hurricane center in Coral Gables. ``Fortunately, it looks like the steering currents will keep both Gustav and Hortense away from the U.S. and the Caribbean islands,'' Ms. Graff said. ``At least this time around, it looks like South Carolina is off the hook.'' Ms. Graff said weather service phones were ``ringing off the hook,'' with many of the calls coming from South Carolina. Jackie Ford, a Lady's Island Marina dockmaster who is thought by many in the area to have a sixth sense when it comes to predicting the landfalls of large storms, said he spent most of Monday puzzling over the storms' directions. ``I've got just one pin on the chart, and I don't have a good feeling for it one way or the other,'' Ford said. ``It's a little too early to tell, but I guarantee you we will be keeping an eye on both of them.'' Meteorologists watching Gustav believe it's unlikely the hurricane will turn toward the U.S. East Coast as it makes its way north. At 6 p.m. EDT, Gustav's center was located near 22 degrees north latitude and 58 degrees west longitude, or about 425 miles northeast of Antigua. It was moving north at about 13 mph and was expected to hold that course and speed through Wednesday. Tropical Storm Hortense remained a danger only to shipping. The storm was centered near 23.2 degrees north latitude and 45.5 degrees west longitude, or about 1,420 miles west-northwest of the Cape Verde islands. Little change in its strength was expected either. Tropical depressions become tropical storms when their sustained top winds reach 39 mph. Tropical storms become hurricanes at 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold dropped $6.46 an ounce Wednesday, opening at $386.36. It closed at $392.82 Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Raymond St. Jacques Dies of Cancer at Age 60
DOC.TEXT: Actor Raymond St. Jacques, known for his roles in such movies as ``Black Like Me,'' ``The Evil That Men Do'' and ``Glory'' as well as the TV miniseries ``Roots,'' has died of cancer. He was 60. St. Jacques died at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center at 1:30 p.m. Monday, hospital spokeswoman Paula Correia said Tuesday. He had been treated for cancer of lymph glands since entering the hospital on July 30. In addition to his role as the drummer in the 1977 miniseries ``Roots,'' the character actor was in the TV films ``Search for the Gods'' in 1975 and ``Secrets of Three Hungry Wives'' in 1978. He was also a familiar face on a variety of television shows and most recently portrayed the judge on the syndicated TV show ``Superior Court.'' St. Jacques appeared on ``MacGyver,'' ``Fantasy Island,'' ``Love Boat,'' ``Cagney & Lacey,'' ``Hunter'' and ``Starman,'' among others. He was fluent in French and Italian, and appeared in theater performances of ``The Man With the Golden Arm,'' ``Othello,'' ``Romeo and Juliet,'' ``Raisin in the Sun'' and ``Julius Caesar.'' His motion picture credits included ``Black Like Me'' and ``The Pawnbroker'' in 1964, ``Mister Moses'' in 1965, ``Mister Buddwing'' in 1966, ``The Comedians'' in 1967 and ``The Green Berets'' in 1968. He was also in ``Uptight'' and ``If He Hollers, Let Him Go'' in 1968, ``Change of Mind'' and ``Cotton Comes to Harlem'' in 1970, ``Cool Breeze'' in 1972, ``The Book of Numbers'' in 1973, ``Born Again,'' ``Eyes of Laura Mars'' and ``The Private Files of J. Edgar Hoover'' in 1978, ``Sweet Dirty Tony'' in 1981, ``The Evil That Men Do'' in 1984, and ``Glory'' in 1989. St. Jacques is survived by his mother, Vivienne, and a sister, Barbara Birt, both of New Haven, Conn. A funeral was planned at Forest Lawn Memorial Park but arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Secretary Proposes Limited Drilling in Alaskan Wildlife Refuge
DOC.TEXT: Oil exploration in an Alaska wildlife refuge could help boost domestic production in response to the Persian Gulf crisis, U.S. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said Tuesday. ``There is no reason why we should not explore in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge,'' Lujan said. ``It's self-defeating not to have production. ``The less production, the more tankers you have. Oil spills are due to tankers colliding,'' said the secretary, who was making a working vacation swing through the West. A number of spills, including one in 1969 off Santa Barbara, Calif., and the 1987 Pemex spill in the Gulf of Mexico, have come from offshore oil rigs, and others have involved pipelines. Lujan said one possibility was limited exploration in 1 million acres of the 18 million-acre refuge in Alaska's northeast corner east of Prudhoe Bay, the site of North America's largest oil discovery. Alaska's top elected officials also have endorsed exploration in the refuge following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq. At a U.S. Energy Department hearing on long-range energy planning in Fairbanks on Monday, Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper, a Democrat, and Republicans Sen. Ted Stevens and Rep. Don Young testified in favor of granting leases for oil exploration in the refuge. The refuge was established in 1960 and enlarged in 1980 to protect caribou and other wildlife species. When Congress expanded the refuge, it postponed any decision about oil exploration. Environmentalists said drilling in the refuge is not the solution to the nation's appetite for foreign oil. Even if there is a commercial quantity of oil there, it will do little to reduce imports, the environmentalists said. Lujan said the standoff in the Middle East has not created a national oil crisis which warrants unlimited exploration of domestic reserves. But he said new test wells must be considered. ``Overseas oil one of these days is going to run out,'' he said. If oil is found in the refuge, it would take about seven years before it would be available to American consumers, James Ross, president and chief executive of BP America Inc., has said. Only one well has been drilled in the Alaskan refuge and its findings are a closely held corporate secret. The oil industry calls the refuge one of the best chances of finding a significant domestic oil field.

DOC.HEAD: Former Exxon Valdez to Depart for Sea Trial
DOC.TEXT: The ship that caused the nation's worst oil spill is ready for sea trials after a $30 million repair job to its mangled hull, the repair company said Tuesday. The Exxon Mediterranean, formerly the former Exxon Valdez, has been undergoing dock trials at a pier at National Steel & Shipbuilding Co. after being floated out of a dry dock last month. The ship, which was built at NASSCO and delivered to Exxon in 1986, was scheduled to depart early Wednesday for a week of sea trials about 200 miles offshore, said NASSCO spokesman Fred Hallett. It had been undergoing repairs for 11 months. The tanker was renamed in July and Exxon officials said it would be put into service in the Mediterranean. They denied that renaming the tanker and sending it to the Mediterranean were related to the massive spill. The ship spilled almost 11 million gallons of oil when it struck a reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989, fouling hundreds of miles of coastline and killing untold numbers of wildlife. Exxon officials had said the vessel is too big for any U.S. Pacific ports when fully loaded. They said declining production from Alaskan oil fields have reduced the need for such large tankers to be used on West Coast shipping routes. The tanker holds nearly 1.4 million barrels of crude. One barrel contains 42 gallons. Exxon officials didn't return telephone calls about the ship Tuesday. Workers replaced the single-hulled ship's mangled steel with 3,000 tons of new, inch-thick steel. Exxon officials had said last month that the ship would stop in Singapore en route to ports in the Mediterranean, but the current crisis in the Persian Gulf could alter some of those plans, Exxon officials have said.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Concerned by Rise in Anti-Semitism
DOC.TEXT: Home Secretary David Waddington said Tuesday the government is concerned by increased anti-Semitic activity and desecrations of synagogues and Jewish cemeteries. Waddington told four members of the Board of Deputies of British Jews that the government has a ``vigorous commitment to tackling racial violence in all its forms.'' The meeting came less than a week after vandals painted swastikas, pagan symbols and racial slurs at the Gladstone Park Holocaust Memorial in Dollis Hill, northwest London. Police say 27 incidents against Jews and Jewish property were reported in greater London in the first half of 1990, a significant rise from last year.
