Similar attacks were reported in mainland Europe, including one at Carpentras, France, where fascists desecrated 34 graves and exhumed a corpse. In a joint statement issued after the meeting, board president Lionel Kopelowitz said the Jewish leaders expressed ``deep concern at the number of incidents of vandalism.''

DOC.HEAD: President Wants More Efforts for Peaceful Solution to Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak said Tuesday that if Iraq withdraws from Kuwait, he would urge Western forces to pull back from Saudi Arabia. ``For the foreigners to leave, the Iraqis must leave (Kuwait),'' Mubarak said. ``Then we Arabs will stand against the foreign presence.'' Mubarak spoke at at news conference after meeting with eight U.S. senators led by Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``Leave Kuwait now,'' he said, in remarks apparently aimed at Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, ``and I will be the first to call for the withdrawal of foreign forces from the region immediately.'' Mubarak said he told the American lawmakers that efforts should continue to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis peacefully. He said he still hopes for a diplomatic settlement, despite Iraq's repeated refusal to withdraw from Kuwait. ``The American delegation tried to speak to me about war, but I said I did not want to hear the word war and that we must find peaceful means and must have patience,'' the president said, speaking in Arabic. ``There is still hope. We are trying all the ways. We do not want the Iraqi people annihilated,'' he said. Referring to the U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia _ where Egypt has also sent troops _ Mubarak said: ``We do not know if the United States is planning a war or not.'' Dole and other members of his delegation, including Sen. Sam Nunn, said Mubarak made clear his optimism that peace can be won through an international embargo against Iraq. They said they agreed that it must be tried. ``We have to give it more time,'' Dole said. ``We have to pursue every avenue.'' Nunn, a Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, concurred that it is ``important that we give the embargo a chance to work.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Cambodia Accord Caps An August Month of U.N. Action
With AM-Cambodia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council's condemnation of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the agreement by its five permanent members on a Cambodian peace plan made August the finest month in the U.N.'s history, a U.S. official said Tuesday. ``This month began with a U.N. resolution, 660, condemning the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait,'' said John Bolton, the U.S. State Department undersecretary in charge of international organizations. ``That was followed with four more resolutions on that subject, and is culminated today with the agreement of the five permament members of a framework for a solution to Cambodia,'' he said. The adoption of the Cambodian peace plan makes ``this the most historic month in the 45-year history of the United Nations.'' Here are the key actions in August: Aug. 3 _ The Security Council votes 14-0 to condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and demand the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops. Aug. 6 _ The council votes 13-0 to impose a trade and financial boycott on Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Aug. 9 _ The council votes 15-0 to reject Iraqw's annexation of Kuwait. Aug. 18 _ The council votes 15-0 to demand that Iraq free detained foreigners. Aug. 25 _ The council votes 13-0 to give the United States and other nations the right to use military power to inforce the trade embargo on Iraq. Aug. 28 _ The five permanent council members _ the United States, Soviet Union, China, France and Britain _ adopt an accord calling for a cease-fire in Cambodia and U.N. administration of the country until a new government is elected.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Cashiers Officers for Torture of Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: The Brazilian air force cashiered two high-ranking officers and ordered an investigation into charges that soldiers were tortured, the government said Tuesday. The commander of the Anapolis air force base, Col. Gildo Fernandes de Sousa, and his assistant, Lt. Col. Ubirajara Fernandes da Cunha, were removed from their posts, the Aeronautics Ministry said in a communique. A military panel was appointed to investigate charges that four soldiers were submitted to electric shocks, beatings and kickings to confess the theft of two pistols. Rober Soares da Silva, one of the soldiers involved, appeared on Brazilian television showing body bruises and cuts on his wrists. Da Silva claimed he was handcuffed and beaten to admit the theft. The torture allegedly took place in the office of Lt. Col. da Cunha, according to Veja magazibne, Brazil's biggest newsweekly, which broke the story in this week's edition. The guns thought to be stolen turned up later. According to Veja, another soldier had taken them to show to his father. President Fernando Collor de Mello called for an ``immediate and rigorous'' investigation, presidential press spokesman Claudio Humberto Rosa e Silva said. ``In Brazil, torture never again,'' the spokesman said. Torture was common during the 1964-1985 anti-Communist military administration, when the government persecuted known and suspected leftist opponents. A new constitution in 1988 banned torture and made it a crime without bail. The Anapolis Air Force Base, 60 miles southwest of Brasilia, is responsible for the protecting the air space of central Brazil. It has 800 men and one the country's largest combat squadrons.

DOC.HEAD: Some Suspect U.S. Would Fight War to Benefit Oil Companies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 19th graf pvs, `Among the...,' to UPDATE with new protest in San Francisco
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX3
DOC.TEXT: The deployment of troops to the Persian Gulf has given rise to scattered protests that are focusing more on economics than on the political concerns expressed during the Vietnam era. Many of the demonstrators say the soldiers are risking their lives for oil companies and that the financially strapped nation cannot afford the deployment. ``Hell no, we won't go, we won't die for Texaco,'' 200 protesters shouted Saturday outside the White House, echoing words used by demonstrators during the Vietnam War but adding a twist: the name of a U.S. oil company. Opposition to the Vietnam War in the '60s and '70s and to U.S. military policy in Central America in the '80s focused on whether the United States had the right to interfere in the politics of other nations. Opponents of U.S. gulf policy, a minority according to opinion polls, are centering their arguments on the morality of intervention for economic ends. ``We have to tell each other that we will not kill and we will not die for Exxon, for Gulf Petroleum,'' peace activist Becky Minnich said last week during a meeting of 100 dissidents in Minneapolis. The argument might get a sympathetic ear. An Associated Press poll conducted earlier this month said 86 percent of Americans believed the oil companies took advantage of the Iraqi invasion and unfairly raised gasoline prices. The survey of 1,004 adults had a margi of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. Former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark, speaking at a news conference in New York last week, called the U.S. military buildup ``aggression designed simply to dominate oil.'' Another of the protesters' arguments is that America _ $4.16 trillion in debt _ cannot afford a massive troop deployment costing billions of dollars. ``They now run up a military bill to the top of the sky and take it out of federal housing money for Brooklyn,'' wrote Jimmy Breslin, Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for New York Newsday. Many protesters don't believe protecting Middle East oil from Iraq is worth American lives. ``I kissed my son goodbye today,'' college professor Alex Molnar wrote in a letter to Bush published in The New York Times. ``He is a 21-year-old Marine. You have ordered him to Saudi Arabia. ... For what? Cheap gas?'' Images of soldiers boarding transport planes for the Middle East have become a daily staple of television news, but not all are going willingly. One serviceman, Marine Cpl. Jeffrey Paterson, said he will not fight a war over oil and has filed for conscientious objector status to prevent his deployment to the gulf. A Marine reservist, Erik Glen Larsen, said Tuesday he would file for discharge as a conscientious objector. ``I will refuse orders to ship me to Saudi Arabia to defend our polluting, exploitive lifestyle,'' Larsen, a lance corporal, told an audience of peace activists packed into a church in San Francisco. They responded with a standing ovation. The AP poll said 64 percent of Americans supported deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to help defend it against a possible Iraqi attack, while 22 percent were opposed. But the poll said 52 percent of Americans opposed using ground forces to push Iraq out of Kuwait. Thirty-two percent favored such a move. If the United States is drawn into a war to force Iraq out of Kuwait, which is the intent of the economic embargo, the few voices of protest in the U.S. will likely grow. Among the scattered voices raised in recent days: _ In San Francisco, hundreds of placard-bearing protesters marched in front of Chevron Oil headquarters Tuesday. Organized by the Emergency Committee to Stop the U.S. War in the Middle East, the demonstration was directed at what protesters called ``a war for profit'' by the United States and its oil companies. _ In Seattle, two protesters chained themselves to the main gate of the Naval Reserve Center on Tuesday. A dozen other protesters dumped bags of sand and poured oil and fake blood onto the sand. _ In Pittsburgh, about 40 demonstrators on a college campus created a pyramid of 55-gallon drums bearing the slogan ``war oil.'' _ In Amherst, Mass., about 15 protesters elicited a few honks in support from passing motorists, but also the shouted comment: ``Get out of America.'' _ At Westover Air Force Base, Mass., where planes being used to supply troops in the gulf are based, two people were arrested on charges of disturbing the peace Monday during a small demonstration. _ In San Francisco, 15 protesters at the Federal Building held signs saying ``Shed No Blood for Oil'' and promised to continue holding pickets there until the troops come home.

Verbal scores on the SAT have dropped to their lowest level in a decade, and a testing official says that's because too many students are watching music videos and playing video games instead of reading. Combined Scholastic Aptitude Test scores totaled 900 for the 1989-90 school year _ 476 on the math section, 424 on the verbal, the College Board reported Monday. The highest possible score is 800 on each section, for a combined 1,600. Math scores were unchanged among the 1.03 million high school students who took the test. But the verbal average was down three points from the previous school year, marking a steady decline since the recent peak of 431 in 1986. Verbal scores are now at their lowest point since 1980 and equal to the worst levels since national averages were first compiled in 1971.

Blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan had beaten drugs and alcohol and fellow musicians said he was playing better than ever when he died in a helicopter crash shortly after a concert. He was 35. Four others died early Monday after Vaughan and members of guitarist Eric Clapton's entourage took off for Chicago in dense fog. Vaughan, a two-time Grammy winner known for his rocking Texas roadhouse blues style, had shared the bill Sunday night with Clapton and guitarist Robert Cray. ``His death is particularly sad, given that he'd cleaned up and was playing the best music of his life,'' said Jeff Peterson of the ``Austin City Limits'' TV program on which the Texan had appeared.

Beginning next week, all physicians will be responsible for filing reimbursement claims for their Medicare patients. The Sept. 1 change is welcomed by advocates for the elderly as a relief from what many say is confusing and time-consuming paperwork that discourages some patients from filing the forms and receiving reimbursement. But it is dreaded by many physicians who envision a bureaucratic nightmare. ``This is one of those instances where someone is trying to fix something that wasn't broken in the first place,'' said Dr. Joseph F. Boyle, executive vice president of the American Society of Internal Medicine.

General Motors Corp., the world's largest automaker, plans to install air bags on the driver's side of all its cars built in the United States by the fall of 1995. Barring unforeseen design problems, the safety devices would be in all Chevrolets, Pontiacs, Oldsmobiles, Buicks and Cadillacs, the company said Monday. The plan doesn't apply to cars GM makes in cooperation with Japanese companies, such as the Geo and the Nova. The announcement came as GM plays catch-up with its Big Three competitors in installing a safety device that appears destined to become as common as the safety belt. Chrysler Corp. currently equips almost all its North American-made cars with air bags, first announcing the step in 1988, and Ford Motor Co. has air bags in about half of its fleet.

The National Endowment for the Arts says grants for four avant-garde theater performers were vetoed because agency Chairman John E. Frohnmayer decided their work would not ``enhance public understanding and appreciation of the arts.'' The four performers, Karen Finley and Holly Hughes of New York and Tim Miller and John Fleck of Los Angeles, who appealed Frohnmayer's decision, were told Friday that their appeals had been denied. The NEA confirmed the action in a statement Monday. When Frohnmayer vetoed the four grants on June 29, he refused to give any reasons, citing a longstanding endowment policy against discussing grant rejections. The NEA statement Monday represented an unusual departure from that policy in a case that has attracted widespread publicity.

DOC.HEAD: Watching Films in Outer Space
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Bela Lugosi is having a bad day. Murdering brides and stealing their bodily fluids to rejuvenate your aging, cranky wife is a disgusting job. And ``The Corpse Vanishes'' (1942), a sublevel thriller, is a disgusting movie. Just ask the two robots and the guy sitting in the front row. ``No one can hold a candle to him in this role,'' says one. ``Actually, maybe someone could douse him with a flammable liquid and then hold a candle to him.'' Talking back to bad movies is something most people can relate to. But few are as funny (or as weird) as Joel Hodgson and his two robot pals who screen catastrophes of filmmaking on ``Mystery Science Theater 3000'' on Home Box Office's The Comedy Channel. This show with a baffling title and a bizarre premise is something new in the land of comedy television. It's funny, intelligent and off the beaten path. Actually, it's in outer space. As the opening song explains, Joel was a janitor whose bosses at the Gizmonic Institute didn't like him. So they shot him into space. This all takes place ``in the not too distant future.'' Aboard the Satellite of Love, (also the title of an old Lou Reed song), Hodgson is forced to watch cheesy movies such as ``The Corpse Vanishes,'' ``The Crawling Hand'' and ``The Robot vs. the Aztec Mummy.'' Lonely Joel builds two robot buddies out of spare Satellite of Love parts, and together they sit before this orbiting movie screen and deliver a diatribe of bad puns, jokes and sight gags. The three appear in silhouette at the bottom of the movie screen, on which the film plays in its entirety while they quietly comment from the theater's front row. ``Mystery Science Theater 3000'' has become a cult hit for thousands of devotees. ``MST3K'' (as viewers call it) is one of the most popular shows on The Comedy Channel, which just renewed it for a second 13-episode season. The Comedy Channel can use a hit. The 24-hour service that began last November opened to generally terrible reviews. Archrival HA!, launched this spring by Viacom, has been locked in a lackluster duel with the Comedy Channel for what appears to be a small universe of people who want to watch only comedy shows. But ``MST3K'' has its own nationwide fan club of 2,000-plus members and an audience that ranges from hip college kids to middle-aged parents. Newspapers and TV Guide have written about it. Production companies are making offers. ``It's one of the biggest hits on our service,'' said Comedy Channel spokesman Tony Fox. ``These guys are great. People write from all over the country.'' The unorthodox success of Mystery Science Theater is about as offbeat as Hodgson himself, who puts the show together in a warehouse in Eden Prairie, Minn., outside Minneapolis. The 30-year-old comedian stays in Minnesota because he does not like big city life or Hollywood. He has had a speedy brush with fame and decided it was too much. At age 22, right out of college, he came to Los Angeles with his stand-up comedy routine and gadget collection (including a burning purse and a 360-degree head cranker) and ended up doing bits on David Letterman and ``Saturday Night Live.'' Brandon Tartikoff, then the entertainment president of NBC, offered Hodgson his own show. He turned it down. ``I just wasn't happy,'' Hodgson said. Two years after moving to L.A., he was back in Minneapolis. He sold T-shirts and wrote an HBO special with comedian Jerry Seinfeld. In the middle of this re-entry into a more normal life, Hodgson met Jim Mallon, then a production manager at KTMA-TV in Minneapolis. Together, they formed Best Brains Inc. Stand-up comedians and local television people joined on. ``MST3K,'' which debuted on KTMA on Thanksgiving Day, 1988, eventually was shopped to bigger television executives. The Comedy Channel, in need of original programming for its yet-to-be seen network at the time, snapped it up for its premiere late last year. Hodgson, who tends to speak in dry understatement and incomplete sentences, described the genesis of ``MST3K'' this way: ``It started from the idea of talk radio. Someone being really alone. The DJ being alone and you being alone in a car. `Gilligan's Island,' it's kind of like, too. Being isolated.'' On ``MST3K,'' Joel's character is about as isolated as you can get. Hurtling through space with his robot friends Crow and Tom Servo, the trio appear as silhouettes in the lower right corner of the television screen, looking up at a large movie screen. Each two-hour show contains about 450 jokes, Hodgson said. The writing takes place around a table in the Best Brains warehouse, where Hodgson, Mallon and the company's eight other employees watch cheesy films, make fun of them, and jot it all down. In ``The Corpse Vanishes'' episode, as one bride after another drops in a heap at the altar, Joel, Crow and Tom Servo break into ``I'm Getting Buried in The Morning.'' When it becomes apparent the brides are not dead after all, but merely a little low on life-sustaining fluids, an intrepid female reporter proclaims ``You mean they may be alive in a catalytic state?'' ``Iowa?'' shouts Joel.

Elsewhere in television... Reason 876 to Continue Living: NBC's new ``Guys Next Door'' Saturday morning show wants to be the nouveau ``New Kids on the Block.'' A licensing agreement for posters, sweat shirts, sleepwear, towels and banners was announced this week. End Adv PM Wed Aug. 29

DOC.HEAD: The Deployment at Home: The Peace Movement Shakes Itself to Life
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The people who tormented Lyndon B. Johnson with chants of ``Hey, hey, LBJ, how many kids did you kill today?'' are old enough now to have a son or daughter in the Marines. And some of them are ready to take to the streets again. When President Bush deployed the troops, he mobilized the peace movement. The peaceniks of Vietnam and the next few generations of anti-war activists are forming coalitions, planning vigils, keeping the fax machines humming. Human rights lawyer Ramsey Clark called together a ``Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East'' to demand an American withdrawal from the Persian Gulf and to denounce the attempt ``to take the people of this country by surprise and usurp Arab and international peaceful and diplomatic solutions.'' Someone even remembered the ``teach-ins'' of the 1960s at which speakers tried to talk the Vietnam War to death. A Persian Gulf teach-in was quickly scheduled in New York City. But things are different. Bush disarmed the peace advocates by going multinational and going to the United Nations. And the peace movement cannot bring itself to ally itself with Saddam Hussein, who used chemical weapons in the Iran-Iraq war, who gassed his own country's Kurdish minority and who invaded Kuwait, a country that helped finance his eight-year war with Iran. Not even so dedicated an anti-war advocate as Dave McReynolds of the War Resisters League _ which hasn't supported a war since its creation in 1923 by pacifists jailed during World War I _ concedes: ``This is not Vietnam and Saddam Hussein is not Ho Chi Minh.'' Ho was the revolutionary who led communist forces in a ``war of liberation'' in Vietnam. The kids who taunted Lyndon Johnson also used to cry, ``Ho, Ho, Ho Chi Minh'' at him. ``We were so stunned the first day or two at Saddam's invasion that we didn't know what to do,'' McReynolds acknowledged. But it didn't last. The league adopted a position decrying Iraq's ``indefensible'' invasion, but saying, ``The Arab nations should be allowed to resolve the conflict.'' American leftists, McReynolds said, were shocked when Jesse Jackson wrote a statement for The New York Times on Aug. 12 supporting Bush's deployment. ``Saudi Arabia asked for our help,'' Jackson wrote. ``It seems to me that we were obliged to respond.'' McReynolds said Jackson's left-wing supporters are gathering signatures on a letter taking him to task. ``It says what are you doing Jesse?'' he said. ``You are supposed to speak for us. This may have looked presidential to you, but it doesn't look rational to us and you are going to lose our support.'' George McGovern, the Democrats' anti-war presidential candidate in 1972, also told the Times that he supported Bush. Jerome Grossman is another defector. He sold his business, the Massachusetts Envelope Co., in 1975 to devote his energies to the Council for a Liveable World, which he helped found in 1955. During the Vietnam War, he said, he orchestrated the Moratorium marches of Oct. 15, 1969, ``the largest demonstration in the history of mankind.'' Does he think Bush did wrong? Slowly Grossman ticks off his answer: ``No. 1, he set a bad example when he invaded Panama. No. 2, he continued the Reagan policy of not encouraging (energy) conservation. N0. 3, he did not denounce Iraq's use of chemical weapons. But in his handling of the current crisis, apart from the obscene continuation of his vacation, I have no serious, major criticism.'' But most leaders of the old peace movement are less willing to give Bush the benefit of the doubt. Bruce Birchard, disarmament specialist at the American Friends Service Committee, the Quaker group, deplores the huge American buildup. ``Even if the United States does not want war _ and that's not something we're certain of _ any unexpected move could lead to the whole thing blowing up,'' he said. And Ira Shorr, program director at SANE-Freeze, said Americans' initial reaction was ``to rally around the president'' but he said people are becoming convinced that the administration's foremost priority ``is a military resolution to this conflict.'' He draws a lesson from history: ``I think our response to war will forever be changed by Vietnam. We will never be as deeply trustful of our government as we were then.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has covered events in Washington since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Credit Crunch: Self-Imposed?
DOC.TEXT: Activities in the financial and economic world have created many odd lines on charts and graphs during the past three weeks, but one of the oddest is a line describing the availability of credit. Even the Federal Reserve, generally thought to be the entity that tightens or loosens the noose on the nation's money supply, is puzzled and concerned. That being so, there is cause for general concern. Credit is indeed tightening, but the Fed indicates that it isn't the only one doing the tightening. Instead, the constricting appears to be a joint undertaking of lenders, business people, individuals, regulators and the banks. It seems that simultaneously and automatically, large segments of these credit-user categories have come to the same conclusion, that credit has been too easily dispensed and that it is time to slow the flow. No matter where you test for opinions, in business or government or among individuals, you will find large numbers who feel that the economy is slowing, that bad loans are a danger, and that standards must be raised. But no matter what the general opinion, there will always be those in need of money who cannot get it, and these days that includes not just would-be homebuyers, but small, beginning and financially endangered businesses. The latest Fed survey of lending officers found a reduced willingness on the part of banks to lend during the past three months. Of those queried, more than one-third said they had cracked down on lending. Why? Because, it seems, banks' own investment portfolios are down, their capital positions are strained, they have observed many other banks nearing insolvency, they fear for the immediate economic future . . . These are the reasons you would expect, but there are others, too. Federal regulators have been looking warily at the value of many loans already made, and have been insisting that some loans or assets be written down in value. Atop this is the sense among some bankers that they overdid their lending in the past and lowered their standards in doing so. Psychologically, it is the same reaction as that of the big borrowers _ time to straighten out. While some businesses, especially those whose applications contain the words ``real estate'' or ``construction'' or ``developer,'' are begging for money and not getting it, other businesses have withdrawn from the market. Surveys show that businesses are very concerned about economic conditions in general and specifically about financial practices, their own included. A recent survey by the National Federation of Independent Business, for example, found that members weren't especially hurt by a credit crunch, one reason being that they just weren't seeking credit. The consumer has cut back too, and for many of the same reasons that dictate the actions of banks and business; that is, the feeling that borrowing might have been overdone and that now is the time to put matters in order. In summary, the tight credit market today may be partly a reflection of private-sector attitudes, a self-imposed credit tightening, rather than a crackdown by the Federal Reserve. Whatever the reason, it has engendered a rare, almost unheard of, concern from the Fed, ``that the trend to greater restraint in the provision of credit might continue.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europeans Flock To Religious Retreat
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Vladimir Lubaschevsky and his wife Natalia traveled three days by train from Moscow to reach a new world of ``love and freedom'' in Taize. ``We have found here quite another life,'' the 38-year-old engineer said shyly, clutching a dogeared Bible in one hand and Natalia's elbow in the other. ``It is fantastic for us.'' It is a dramatic contrast: the officially atheist Soviet Union, where they share a bleak apartment with his mother, and this liberal religious community nestled in the hills of Burgundy, about 230 miles southeast of Paris. The Lubaschevskys are among tens of thousands of newly free East Europeans descending this year on Taize, a cross between summer camp and ecumenical seminary. Taize observed its 50th birthday Sept. 1 and Cardinal Albert Decourtray of Lyon conducted a special service. For many people who live here, the arrival of the East Europeans is a greater event than the anniversary. ``It's very moving to know what some of them have come through,'' said Brother John, a 38-year-old American. ``Here, you're a Christian and it's no big deal. In East Germany, it meant a guy had to give up his job.'' Taize is a fraternity of 90 monks, most of them clad in sandals and slacks, who hope to reconcile the human family and overcome divisions among Christians through common prayer. Their ideas are a powerful beacon that draws more than 100,000 visitors a year to share prayer, discussion, song and silence. Brother Roger, 75, founded the community during World War II and still leads it. He is a Swiss Protestant, a mystical man who loves Bach and tea, and likes his Christianity simple. He will cross out whole sections of a text by St. Augustine to make the essential message easier to grasp. ``John XXIII was the pope who understood us the best,'' said Brother Roger, who has known them all since Pius XII. ``He was a man of great simplicity and sensitivity.'' Both are embodied in Taize. Visitors sleep in tents. Three times a day, they sit on all-weather carpet in the Church of Reconciliation to pray. In a region known for wine, tripe sausage and escargot, they eat green beans and pears. The monks keep an open ear to anxieties, hoping to turn individual suffering into compassion. ``The brothers offer us a chance to take part in their prayers, their work, which is very important to me,'' said Andrea Hegedus, 25, of Budapest, Hungary. ``This would have been expropriated by the communists'' in Eastern Europe, she said, because ``coming together was a privilege held by the party.'' An estimated 2 million pilgrims have visited Taize in its half-century, including Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa and Pope John XXIII. Pope John Paul II visited as cardinal of Krakow in 1968 and pontiff in 1986. Most visitors are aged 17-25, recognizable by backpacks and faded jeans. Some hitchhike and others arrive at the tiny railroad station. Shuttle buses run from several Polish cities. Mary Tyminska, 16, arrived on a bus from Czem with 40 other teen-agers. Some immediately tried to hitch rides to Paris, but Mary stayed behind. ``Everyone is so happy here,'' she said. ``They treat you like brothers or sisters.'' In 1940, Roger Schuutz pedaled his bicycle from Switzerland into unoccupied France and bought a rundown house in Taize as the home for what he envisioned as a simple community of monks dedicated to prayer and meditation. Then as now, Taize was affiliated with no church and did not accept donations. Brother Roger refused his inheritance, following the example of his mother, who refused too. The monks support themselves with a crafts shop, where they sell articles they make. Visitors pay for meals and sleeping space in a tent. In 1942, the Gestapo chased Brother Roger to Geneva after learning he had helped Jews escape France. He returned after the Allied invasion and conducted services for German prisoners of war in the 13th-century village church. Young people started coming to Taize in the late 1950s. The brothers built a spacious, modern church to hold them. The annual pilgrimage grew to 100,000 in the 1970 and the brothers expanded the church's capacity with circus tents. ``We didn't ever want it,'' Brother Roger said, but his monks adapted, organizing food and lodging for their guests and composing multilingual chants to break down language barriers. Some brothers now live part of the year in North and South America, Africa and Asia to expand contact between Christians. ``We first started making contacts in Eastern Europe in 1962, when we had a German brother who said we must go there to express our humanity,'' said Brother Emile, a Canadian. The revolution in Eastern Europe means many who dreamed of visiting Taize can do so. More than half the pilgrims this year are from the region. ``Here, we feel a unity in faith and being together,'' Lubachevsky said. ``Here, it is approved to have more love and freedom than we ever had before.''

DOC.HEAD: In Sochi, Sand Curtain Separates Elite From Masses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: retransmitting to restore slugline
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: A 10-foot-high concrete barrier separates the elite from the masses on the beach of this Black Sea resort, illustrating the Soviet Union's failure to achieve a classless society. The wall starts in the water and runs over the sand to separate the Riviera, a public beach, from a vast playground reserved for those with position and influence. No one seems to know the name of the private beach or the names of those who use it. Little is known of the services provided, but the sheer size of the sanctum raises eyebrows. On an average day, 15,000 people must crowd onto a public beach only 750 yards long, while about 500 of the upper crust loll on an expanse that stretches more than half a mile. Arkady Melkonyan, a state television correspondent, cited the figures in a recent broadcast. Like Melkonyan, some citizens are indignant. Others shrug it off. ``The Martians live differently than we; why shouldn't they?'' Valery Skripnik, a 40-year-old gardener, said on the Riviera beach. He spoke between chin-ups on an exercise bar. There is increasing criticism of reserving beaches, quality medical care, luxury apartments, special planes and stores for Communist Party and government officials in a country where ordinary people live in cramped housing and stand in line for food and other necessities. Some politicians, most notably Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, have won wide popular support by attacking privilege. Dozens of country homes have been converted from private residences for the elite to public rest homes. The newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna reported Aug. 8 that the number of aircraft reserved for the privileged had been drastically reduced. Those who are more equal than others have a strong grip on Sochi, however, and few of its facilities have gone public. Melkonyan told viewers that, of the resort area's 151 beaches, only 22 were open to ordinary people. In addition to the reserved beaches, Sochi has elaborate private resort complexes, known in Russian as sanatoriums. They do not appear on maps, are generally visible only from the sea and are heavily guarded. Down the beach from the Actors' Sanatorium and Pravda Sanatorium, spas for actors and journalists, is the Dzerzhinsky Sanatorium, the summer hideaway of KGB agents named for Felix Dzerzhinsky, who founded the Soviet secret police. It begins at the seaside with a covered patio adorned with tall, ornate yellow arches and white columns. An elevator takes vacationers up a hill to a main building tucked into a thickly wooded area. Exclusive beachfront facilities nearby include a small yellow villa with white arches that was favored by Lavrenti Beria, dictator Josef Stalin's chief of secret police. Farther along the Black Sea coast are the dachas, as the villas are called, of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and Anatoly I. Lukyanov. At least two resorts have been partly opened to the public after decades of catering to the elite. The 180-acre Green Grove resort, once reserved for Communist Party officials, received automotive workers from Gorky and steelworkers from Magnitogorsk last year, director Ludmilla Voblikova reported. Staffs of Communist Party schools, from janitors to instructors, spend vacations at the complex on a wooded hill overlooking the sea. Voblikova has run the place since 1958, when privilege was not questioned. She proclaimed allegiance to the new policy, but said: ``I think we should all work well, and the better we work, the better we should live.'' At nearby Lenin Sanitorium, the splendor formerly saved for Communist Party officials now is available to workers from collective farms. They live in a gray marble dormitory, built in 1984, that has clean, carpeted, well-furnished rooms. An older building erected in the 1950s has an ``Italian courtyard'' with colored tile, white columns and an ornate fountain. In the main dining room are glass chandeliers, white marble columns and parquet floors.

DOC.TEXT: Oil prices plunged $4 per barrel and stocks rallied to their best gains of the year as the financial markets sensed a reduced threat of war in the Mideast and an OPEC agreement to boost oil production. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the October-delivery price of light, sweet crude plunged $4 to close at $26.91 per barrel. Traders called it the steepest one-day drop in memory. The Dow Jones industrial average posted its fifth largest gain ever in New York Stock Exchange trading.

Personal incomes grew 0.6 percent in July and consumer spending rose 0.5 percent, the government said in a report some analysts contend points to a stronger economy than expected. The Commerce Department said Monday that consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, totaled $3.67 trillion. That was up $16.6 billion from the previous month, although the pace was slower than June's 1 percent increase.

Existing home sales rose for a second straight month in July but analysts predicted a slowdown because of rising mortgage rates linked to the Mideast crisis. The National Association of Realtors said Monday that house resales rose 3.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.44 million units in July following a 0.9 percent gain in June. The June advance was the first in seven months.

Sunbeam Appliance Co. of Milwaukee is recalling 1,400 mixers found to have a risk of severe electric shock, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said. Although there have been no reports of injuries, the commission said Monday the counter-top mixers can cause severe shock if motors and other electrical components shift through shipping or handling and come in contact with the chrome-plated housing.

A jury convicted four prominent professionals, including the ex-head of Guinness PLC, for misconduct over the brewing giant's multibillion-dollar takeover of a Scottish distiller four years ago. Convicted Monday were former Guinness chairman and chief executive officer Ernest Saunders; Gerald Ronson, chairman of Heron International PLC; former stockbroker Anthony Parnes; and millionaire financier Sir Jack Lyons. The case was described by investigators as a web of greed and deceit that almost mirrored Wall Street's insider trading scandal of the 1980s.

United Auto Workers leaders met behind closed doors to map out strategy for the final three weeks of bargaining with the nation's Big Three automakers and to choose a bargaining ``target.'' The UAW was expected to announce its target company on Tuesday. The union's contracts with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. expire Sept. 14.

Defaults on student loans will cost taxpayers nearly $2 billion this year, and a major reasons given by people who welsh on debt is that they are out of work, according to the Education Department. Many said they simply didn't like the education they got, the department said Monday. ``Unemployed and without income'' was cited more than any other reason, slightly ahead of ``working, but insufficient funds,'' the department said in an 80-page booklet.

An appeals court agreed to reconsider a decision overturning the conviction of a stockbroker charged with trading on inside information about the 1986 takeover of the Waldbaum supermarket chain. Prosecutors had asked for the rehearing in the appeal of stockbroker Robert Chestman of Gruntal & Co., saying that a May decision by a three-judge panel of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals threatened future insider trading prosecutions. The full court Monday said it would rehear the case.

Federal securities regulators launched an administrative action against a Florida man accused of selling more than $4 million in unregistered or risky securities. The Securities and Exchange Commission charged Monday that Michael C. Beatty, of St. Petersburg, Fla., sold $4.2 million in promissory notes and other unregistered securities to investors between 1984 and 1988, while falsely claiming they were safe investments in a sound company.

Stock prices rolled up their sharpest gain of the year Monday, with the Dow Jones average up 78.71 to 2,611.63. Bond prices jumped as worries about the Mideast waned. The dollar dropped to a post-war low against the German mark, while gold prices tumbled more than $25 an ounce. Most commodity futures were battered. Precious metals, grain and soybeans were down, but livestock and pork futures gained.

DOC.HEAD: Cheaper Oil Might Not Provide Quick Relief for Motorists
DOC.TEXT: A sudden, steep drop in oil prices shocked some traders, but motorists shouldn't be surprised if they keep paying increased prices when they fill up their cars, at least for now. Critics of the oil industry contend that companies tend to pass on higher prices much more quickly than they pass on savings. They say the lag that follows cheaper oil prices is an example of oil company gouging. Oil companies bristle at the the accusation, saying the pricing of petroleum products is left to market forces. Some industry analysts defend the policies, saying the cost of crude oil and gasoline on world markets has risen far faster than retail prices in recent months. Crude oil fell $4 per barrel Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, while gasoline for September delivery declined 17.1 cents to 87.5 cents per gallon. According to the American Automobile Association, gasoline prices at the pump have risen an average of 20 cents per gallon since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. While pump prices weren't expected to fall immediately, Conoco Inc. in Houston said it would lower the price of its branded wholesale gasoline by 2 to 5 cents per gallon beginning today because of ``softer market conditions.'' It also said it would cut prices for unbranded wholesale gasoline by 10.65 cents per gallon. Because retailers are required by federal law to set pump prices, lower prices for drivers could not be guaranteed, Conoco said. A Ralph Nader consumers group, Buyers Up, said it generally takes up to several weeks for lower oil prices to translate into lower retail gasoline prices. James W. Brock, a business professor at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, said he believes the behavior of prices has shown that oil giants are taking advantage of consumers during the current crisis. ``The oil companies jumped on it to raise prices instantly,'' he said. ``That hasn't been true when it goes down.'' In addition to complaints from consumer groups, cries of price gouging have been heard from members of Congress and numerous state attorneys general. Oil companies repeatedly have denied charges that they are operating unfairly, and say pump prices did not rise as much as wholesale prices following the Iraqi invasion. According to a Lundberg Survey of 13,500 stations nationwide, wholesale prices rose nearly twice as much as retail prices in the period from Aug. 10 to Aug. 24. In addition, federal law bars companies from setting pump prices, which is left to local service stations. Also, the need for oil companies to purchase large amounts of gasoline on so-called ``spot'' markets is less now than a month ago, at the peak of the nation's summer driving season. With summer demand at its tail end, U.S. oil companies now can rely more on their own producing and refining capabilities and will be less affected by the price drops, some experts said. Gus Ensz, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, said pump prices are likely to follow crude prices. ``Logic is logic,'' he said. ``What goes up comes down or what goes down comes up.'' There is no reliable way for anybody to predict how prices will move, or when, Ensz said. ``There's no fixed formula,'' he said. ``There are thousands of people making decisions on it. There's not only companies. There are middlemen. There are dealers themselves. Literally tens of thousands of people make those decisions. There's not a central headquarters where it's done.'' Ensz acknowledged a public perception that oil companies are quick to pass along higher costs but slow to pass along savings. ``There is that feeling,'' he said. ``I think that in the long run, studies have shown that everything equalizes eventually.''

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Settles Claims From $250 Million Trading Loss in 1987
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. and its insurers have settled a set of claims stemming from $250 million in losses from trading mortgage-backed securities announced in April 1987, officials said. Merrill also agreed to release more than $1 million in compensation plus interest previously withheld from Howard A. Rubin, a senior trader Merrill had blamed for a substantial portion of the losses. Merrill spokeswoman Monica Prihoda said Monday that Merrill had received $17.5 million from insurance companies that provide its directors and officers with liability coverage to settle various lawsuits brought by shareholders for the firm. Merrill had dimissed Rubin after the losses occurred and said it had given the Securities and Exchange Commission information relating to allegedly unauthorized trading. Rubin earlier this year settled SEC charges without admitting or denying guilt that he had aided and abetted a record-keeping violation in connection with the trades. ``It is worth noting that these lawsuits are being settled without him paying anything and, indeed, with Merrill paying him,'' said George Yankwitt, an attorney for Rubin. ``I consider this a complete vindication of Mr. Rubin's position, which is that he had not engaged in any unauthorized or wrongful trading,'' he said. Prihoda declined to comment on details of the settlement with Rubin as cited by Yankwitt. The lawsuits against the firm had mainatined that the losses were caused by Rubin and that his superiors had failed to supervise his activities. ``The settlement with Mr. Rubin was to resolve prior contractual claims unrelated to the trading loss,'' Prihoda said. She also said Merrill believes all shareholder allegations about who was to blame for the trading losses arev without merit, ``except those relating to the conduct of Howard Rubin.'' In addition to the trading losses, various Merrill shareholders had filed other claims on the firm's behalf against several executives and officers. The lawsuits cited lease agreements, various transactions and Merrill's investment in a resort development in St. Thomas in the U.S. Virgin Islands. The $17.5 million payment also represented a settlement of those claims, said David A.P. Brower, a lawyer for various Merrill shareholders.

DOC.HEAD: Driver's-Side Air Bags To Be Offered in All 1995 GM Cars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `Chrysler Corp. ...' to ADD background on federal law requiring air bags or automatic seat belts; Version also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp., the world's largest automaker, plans to install air bags on the driver's side of all its cars built in the United States by the fall of 1995. Barring unforeseen design problems, the safety devices would be in all Chevrolets, Pontiacs, Oldsmobiles, Buicks and Cadillacs, the company said Monday. The plan doesn't apply to cars GM makes in cooperation with Japanese companies, such as the Geo and the Nova. The announcement came as GM plays catch-up with its Big Three competitors in installing a safety device that appears destined to become as common as the safety belt. Chrysler Corp. currently equips almost all its North American-made cars with air bags, first announcing the step in 1988, and Ford Motor Co. has air bags in about half of its fleet. Under federal law, all cars made in the United States after Sept. 1, 1989, must have either an air bag or automatic seat belt for drivers and front-seat passengers. GM last November said that driver's-side air bags would be standard or optional equipment on 1.3 million 1991 models, up from 450,000 model 1990 cars. Air bags normally are stored in the steering wheel and inflate rapidly during a crash. They have been mainly on the driver's side because that seat always is occupied and because many injuries are caused on impact with the steering wheel. GM President Lloyd Reuss said the company will begin offering passenger-side air bags in the 1992 model year. Officials said GM is conducting research on rear-seat air bags, but there are no firm plans to offer them. Engineering and market considerations led GM to decide to install driver's-side air bags by late 1995, said Donald Postma, spokesman for GM's Technical Staffs Group. The only GM cars lacking driver's-side air bags would be those in which the systems posed unforeseen design problems. ``As far as we know there won't be any exceptions,'' Postma said. GM first introduced air bags as optional equipment in the 1988 model year. Since then, the automaker has made the devices standard on some models and introduced them as options on others, which Postma said would continue until 1995. Postma declined to say how much each air-bag system costs GM. Air bags on the 1990 Oldsmobile 98 and Oldsmobile 88 are options costing the consumer $850, he said. The 1.3 million 1991-model cars equipped with air bags are expected to represent between one-third and one-half of GM's sales for the model year. Before deciding to install air bags in all cars, GM wanted to ensure suppliers could handle the production volume required, Postma said. He added that the automaker ``wanted to make sure people were ready for this amount of safety. The automotive marketplace has shown that safety is beginning to sell cars.'' The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety estimates that air bags have inflated in about 2,500 crashes since the early 1980s. It estimates that widespread air bag use could save up to 9,000 lives annually.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Members Agree To Allow Temporary Production Increases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with meeting postponed until Wednesday. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `But after...' DELETES redundant 11th graf, Iraq and Libya... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Nearly all OPEC ministers today tentatively backed a deal that would permit increased oil production by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and some other nations to help offset losses arising from the Middle East crisis. However, officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries delayed until Wednesday a meeting to give formal approval to the arrangement, which would temporarily lift the cartel's supply quotas. Senior delegation sources said on condition of anonymity that 10 of the 11 nations participating in the informal Vienna talks favored allowing extra pumping by some producers. Only Iran failed to support the arrangement. Iraq and Libya did not attend the talks, and the meeting was postponed so messages could be sent to them. ``We are trying, of course, to get everybody (in the accord) ,'' said OPEC Secretary-General Subroto. Libya had been expected for several days to send a delegation to the cartel talks, which began on Sunday. Iraq had opposed holding the gathering. Earlier today, the ministers tried to persuade Iran to go along with the agreement. Iran had indicated that if the situation in the Persian Gulf worsened, it might boost production. But after morning talks, the Iranian oil minister, Gholamreza Aqazadeh, called the OPEC move a ``big mistake.'' Aqazadeh said Western nations should first draw on oil stocks to help meet the crisis. ``It is not the responsibility of OPEC only,'' he said. ``For this reason, I cannot support an increase in production.'' The increased output would help fill a gap of about 4 million barrels of oil a day, pulled off the market by the international embargo against Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The prohibitions were imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``Most countries have already agreed to sanction production increases for the simple reason that ... (the countries) are going to do it anyway,'' said a source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``If they do it outside OPEC, it may be difficult to have them back in the mold again,'' he said Monday. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela have said they will boost pumping to help make up for the lost crude caused by the crisis. But the two would like a nod from the others before going ahead. A source close to OPEC said it appeared Saudi Arabia already has increased production to meet the extra demand. But he refused to say by how much or give other details. It would take about a month for the oil to enter the market. Saudi Arabia, which pumps about a quarter of the cartel's crude, has an OPEC supply quota of 5.4 million barrels a day. The output ceiling for all 13 members is 22.5 million barrels a day. With fears of oil shortages, crude prices have skyrocketed, reaching more than $30 a barrel last week. In trading Monday, they fell $4 a barrel. Iran's Aqazadeh said Monday ``it is not necessary'' now to boost output ``but maybe in the future.'' Iran has benefited greatly from the higher prices brought on by the crisis. It contends there is enough excess oil stored in industrialized nations to make up for any shortages. The consuming nations and their oil companies first should draw from these inventories before asking OPEC for help, the Iranians say. The arrangement permitting greater pumping was expected to contain promises that production must fall back to current levels once the crisis ends, according to the sources. It also was likely to call on consuming nations to use some of their oil in storage to cover shortages, they said. It was unclear whether the final agreement would be formally signed by the members or be more of an ``understanding'' among the nations. OPEC nations are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Overturns $148 Million Award to Liggett Group
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has overturned a $148.8 million jury award to cigarette maker Liggett Group against Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp., which had been found guilty of predatory pricing. U.S. District Judge Frank W. Bullock in Greensboro, N.C., said Monday the jury had come to its decision in March using legally insufficient evidence. He denied a motion for a retrial by Liggett, which had accused its larger rival of trying to put it out of business. Brown & Williamson is the nation's third largest cigarette maker with brands including Kool and Viceroy. Liggett, the nation's smallest cigarette maker, has the L&M, Lark and Chesterfield brands. Bullock said Liggett had failed to show that Brown & Williamson had injured Liggett in a dispute that centered on generic cigarettes, which cost about one third less than the average pack price of $1.60. Alan Hilburg, a Liggett spokesman, said company lawyers were studying Bullock's decision and had not decided whether to appeal. In its lawsuit, Liggett argued that Brown & Williamson in 1984 and 1985 used volume discounts and rebates to wholesalers, which forced Liggett to match the incentives and reduced its profits. Liggett's market share was the industry's lowest before it entered the discount business. Liggett, based in Durham, N.C., also charged that Louisville, Ky.-based Brown & Williamson had copied Liggett's plain black-and-white packaging in an attempt to confuse consumers. After 115 days of testimony and nine days of deliberations, a federal jury in Greensboro awarded Liggett $49.6 million in damages, which automatically is tripled under the law. ``The judge's ruling underscores that what happened when Brown & Williamson began selling generic cigarettes is exactly what's supposed to happen in a free-enterprise system,'' Brown & Williamson said in a statement. Industry figures show that Liggett Group had a 14.4 percent market share in discount cigarettes in 1989, down from 15.2 percent the previous year. Brown & Williamson's generic share was 23.3 percent in 1989, up from 20.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: American Rockers Court Japanese Fans
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It's a performer's dream: audiences who idolize them, full houses, high ticket prices, potentially huge record sales. And for many of the world's hottest musicians, Japan is the best place to be. Whether it's rock, classical or jazz, Japan has become a must stop _ often the first stop _ for traveling bands. Madonna kicked off her 1990 world tour, ``Blond Ambition,'' with a seven-concert tour of Japan beginning April 13, then went back to the United States and on to Europe. ``The money (in Japan) is certainly a factor,'' said Liz Rosenberg, a publicist for Warner Bros. Records. ``Tour sponsorship in Japan is on a much bigger scale than in other parts of the world. Financially, it's very worthwhile.'' Although Rosenberg refused to say how worthwhile, fans paid about $4.5 million to attend Madonna's first three concerts in Tokyo alone. There was no indication how much of that went to Madonna and how much to local organizers. The singer's flashy show in Tokyo consisted of little more than deafening music and a garishly lighted stage. Still, about 35,000 young fans at an outdoor stadium screamed and cheered under driving rains through shows that lasted for two-hours. Other pop performers who played for Japanese audiences in the first half of 1990 include Paul MaCartney, the Rolling Stones, Michael Jackson, Janet Jackson, Tracy Chapman, Bobby McFerrin and David Bowie. Rock stars perform in huge stadiums, packing in tens of thousands, while classical music concerts are much smaller. But while Madonna's top ticket price was about $56, good seats for the Chicago Symphony in Tokyo ran as high as $168 each. For classical music lovers, the Chicago Symphony, St. Louis Symphony, Cleveland Orchestra and the London Symphony, with Leonard Bernstein conducting, have all made recent tours of Japan. Many of the orchestral world's top batons are enthusiastic about the Japanese music consumer. St. Louis Symphony Conductor Leonard Slatkin finds Japanese audiences ``quiet, polite and appreciative.'' ``European audiences often take the music for granted. Japanese never do,'' said Christoph von Dohnanyi, the conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, which toured Japan for two weeks in May. Israeli conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim, who has been coming to Japan to perform for 25 years, agrees. ``I'm always struck by the silence with which the Japanese audiences listen to music. It makes me feel the music is not just entertainment, but that there is a deep respect _ almost awe _ for the music,'' said Barenboim, musical director-designate of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, in an interview. ``That is something I find inspiring. No other audiences are like this.'' No other audiences buy records like the Japanese do either. Henry Fogel, executive director of the Chicago Symphony, says that among the three largest record markets in the world _ Europe, the United States and Japan _ the orchestra's royalties payments are highest from Japan. Fees paid to the orchestra by musical presenter Kajimoto Concert Management Co. are about twice what the Chicago Symphony gets when it tours European capitals, but costs are higher in Japan too, says Fogel. Sponsorship from Motorola, Inc., and Kajimoto's fee just covered the $2.1 million cost of the orchestra's three-week Japan tour last April. ``We'll break even,'' Fogel says. Japan is also home to some well-known festivals that attract the giants of jazz. This summer's Mount Fuji Jazz Festival featured Wynton Marsalis and Dizzy Gillespie. Another festival outside Tokyo, ``Select Live Under the Sky,'' will feature Pat Metheny, Herbie Hancock, Wayne Shorter and Jack Dejohnette. Japanese jazz fans will pay $270 a ticket to see Miles Davis at a small Tokyo club this month. Jazz has been popular in Japan since it was first introduced by U.S. occupation forces after World War II. American jazz labels such as Blue Note have said they were able to remain in business during slumps in jazz's popularity in the United States because of continuing support in Japan. Japan is the second largest market after the United States, and jazz music sales here total about $66 million a year.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Tues Sept. 4

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Says New Newspaper Exceeds Circulation Guarantee
DOC.TEXT: The European, a weekly newspaper launched in May, exceeded the circulation guaranteed to advertisers in June and July, publisher Robert Maxwell said Tuesday. Maxwell said weekly sales in June were estimated to be 360,000, and 340,000 in July. Advertisers had been guaranteed circulation of 225,000, Maxwell said. The paper, published in London every Friday, had average sales of 153,000 on the European continent in June, Maxwell said. He said circulation for July through December will be audited by the Audit Bureau of Circulation.

DOC.NOTE: $adv03
For release Monday, Sept. 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Taiwan's China Policy Under Review
DOC.TEXT: The government says the love affair with China needs better chaperoning to prevent the Communists from taking advantage, and plans to restrict investments on the mainland that could h how many men had died in the accident, Yugoslavia's worst mining disaster. Relatives reported the names of three more miners missing since Sunday, who were not among the 170 names listed in the Yugoslav press, Zelic said. Rescuers continued to clear rubble and debris clogging the shafts leading to the main work site in the mine, where the remaining victims are believed to be, he said. The government of Yugoslavia's central state of Bosnia-Hercegovina, where the Kreka mine is located, has declared a three-day period of official mourning, the national Tanjug news agency reported. It said a day of nationwide mourning would be proclaimed once all the bodies were recovered.

DOC.HEAD: Trader Enters Surprise Guilty Plea Two Weeks Before Trial
DOC.TEXT: A soybean broker has changed his plea to guilty just two weeks before he was to have gone on trial in the government's probe of suspected fraud at the nation's largest futures exchanges. James D. Nowak, a key witness in the case, pleaded guilty Monday to one count each of racketeering conspiracy and filing a false federal income tax return. He also agreed to testify against his former colleagues from the Chicago Board of Trade. In exchange for his plea, federal prosecutors agreed to drop more than 200 other charges against him. Nowak, 48, of northwest suburban Elk Grove Village could be sentenced to a maximum 23 years in prison and fined $350,000. He was among 48 people indicted last August in the undercover investigation of the Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Nowak is the second trader to plead guilty to a charge relating to the Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations statute, or RICO. A scheme or criminal conspiracy must be demonstrated for RICO convictions. Nowak admitted to participating in a wide-ranging scheme that involved systematically cheating Board of Trade customers, according to a report in today's Chicago Sun-Times. The report said he said he formed a ``bank'' with two other traders and an undercover FBI agent posing as a corrupt trader, and siphoned profits from customers to his colleagues. Nowak said he received kickbacks in return. His surprise plea could encourage other indicted traders to cooperate in the probe, the newspaper reported, citing sources it did not identify. A trial that was to have included Nowak is still set to begin Sept. 10 before U.S. District Judge George Marovich. That case involves 12 traders. Another trial, against more than a dozen Japanese yen traders, is set to begin Sept. 5.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 383.31 up 2.04 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Former Guinness Boss Gets Five Year Prison Term in Fraud Case
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOPS with 8 new grafs to note fine against Ronson was biggest ever assessed by British court, editing changes to conform. Picks up 7th graf pvs, Saunders was . . .
DOC.TEXT: A judge today sentenced the former head of Guinness PLC to five years in jail for what he called ``dishonesty on a massive scale'' in the company's hotly-contested takeover of a Scottish distillery four years ago. Judge Sir Denis Henry also levied the biggest fine on record from a British court, nearly $10 million, against another defendant in the case. The judge sentenced Ernest Saunders, 54, the former chairman and chief executive of Guinness, to five years in prison on two counts of conspiracy and two counts of theft. Saunders was also sentenced to 3{ years in prison on eight counts of false accounting. The sentences are to be served concurrently. Co-defendant Gerald Ronson, 51, chairman of Heron International PLC, was sentenced to one year in prison, fined 5 million pounds or about $9.75 million, and was ordered to pay about $858,000 in prosecution costs. The fine was the largest ever imposed by a British court. The previous high was 525,000 pounds, then worth about $750,000, assessed against the National Graphical Association in 1983 for illegally picketing a newspaper plant, according to the Guinness Book of Records. The book is owned by a subsidiary of Guinness PLC. Saunders, Ronson and two others were convicted Monday in what has become known as the biggest white-collar fraud in Britain and followed the country's explosive financial-market growth in the 1980s. Guinness' $5.2 billion buyout of Distillers Ltd. in 1986 was the nation's biggest takeover to that point. ``I am quite satisfied, as the jury by their verdicts have shown, that you were at the center of the dishonest conduct that occurred in Guinness at the time of the Distillers takeover,'' the judge told Saunders. Saunders was not fined. He says he has been impoverished by his legal expenses, and was granted legal aid for the trial. His son James said the family would seek further legal aid for an appeal. Former stockbroker Anthony Parnes, 44, was sentenced to 2{ years in prison and was ordered to pay $858,000 prosecution costs. Parnes collapsed during the sentencing. An ambulance was called but he revived and remained in court. Parnes, Saunders and Ronson had spent their first night in jail on Monday. Their bail was revoked following the jury verdict on Monday at Southwark Crown Court. A fourth convicted man, financier Sir Jack Lyons, 74, was free on bail to give him time to prepare for and recover from an operation on Friday for a tumor. He will be sentenced Sept. 25. The four men were variously convicted of conspiracy, theft and false accounting. Saunders was acquitted on a charge of destroying Guinness documents. After a 112-day trial, a jury found the four guilty of secretly and illegally rigging the stock market to inflate the price of Guinness PLC shares in 1986 when the company battled competitors for control of Distillers, a Scotch whisky and gin manufacturer. Ronson, Parnes and Lyons are millionaires. Saunders earned $682,000 a year but his attorney said he was now bankrupt and penniless, his marriage had collapsed and he was living on a weekly state handout of $59. While awaiting trial, Saunders complained to reporters that he no longer had a chauffeur-driven car, could not afford taxis and was compelled to travel on the crowded London subway. Prosecutor John Chadwick said at the start of the trial on Feb. 14: ``These are not men who were likely to make mistakes in their commercial affairs. These are men who were greedy and arrogant and who thought that they were above the law.'' To secure control of Distillers, Guinness invited Distillers stockholders to exchange their shares for Guinness stock. That meant Guinness stock had to be more attractive than that of its chief competitor in the takeover fight, Argyll Group PLC, a supermarket operator. The prosecution charged that Saunders _ who had taken charge of the ailing Guinness in 1981 and transformed it into a highly successful business _ used the company's funds to get others to buy Guinness stock. The large purchases of Guinness stock boosted the market price of Guinness shares. More than $76.86 million worth of shares were purchased during the takeover. The prosecution claimed Guinness paid about $48 million in unlawful indemnities against losses and in fees. Guinness succeeded in April 1986 in what was then Britain's largest takeover. Saunders personally was set to make more than $5 million from the operation. The Department of Trade and Industry launched an investigation in December 1986, after receiving information from U.S. authorities who had arrested a major Guinness supporter, Ivan Boesky, for insider dealing. In May 1987, the police were called in and the arrests of Saunders and the others followed. The Daily Telegraph reported the trial was the most expensive in British criminal history, with total legal costs estimated at $29 million. The hearing involved 107 days of testimony by 62 witnesses, as well as Saunders who took the stand for two weeks in his own defense. The judge spent five days on his summing-up before the jury of seven men and four women returned their verdicts after 34 hours' deliberation spread over six days.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Rebound After $4-Per-Barrel Drop in Previous Session
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with today's prices, comments, details from OPEC's informal meeting, no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Markets
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rebounded a bit today after falling $4 per barrel a day earlier, as traders wondered what will happen in Thursday's planned meeting between the U.N. secretary-general and Iraq's foreign minister. ``It's just a very choppy market at this point,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``I think it will chop around for a couple of days. You'll probably see a lot of emphasis put on that meeting.'' Oil took its biggest fall in recent memory on Monday, partially on news that the U.N. secretary-general, Javier Perez de Cuellar, would meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to discuss the Middle East crisis. Traders were also betting on the possibility of increased OPEC production. In early trading this morning on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price of light, sweet crude rose 29 cents to $27.20 per barrel for October delivery. The contract fell $4 a barrel on Monday. Other petroleum futures also showed slight recoveries today. Unleaded regular gasoline was up 1.69 cents to 89.25 cents per gallon on September contracts after dropping 17.10 cents on Monday. Home heating oil was up 1.50 cents to 79.60 cents per gallon on September contracts after Monday's decline of 12.86 cents. But natural gas for October delivery continued its descent, slipping from $1.502 to $1.500 per 1,000 cubic feet. It had fallen 2.3 cents on Monday. Kevelson said today that Thursday's meeting could send oil prices down again if any progress appears to have been made. But if the meeting fails to come off, or if nothing notable is accomplished, prices could move back up. ``Until then, you're going to kick around in somewhat of a big range,'' he predicted. Analysts said Monday's sharp decline in oil and petroleum product prices was also based partially on the prospect of increased OPEC production, which could offset much of the 4 million barrels a day kept off the market through the international boycott of Iraq and Kuwait. Meeting today in Vienna, nearly all OPEC ministers tentatively backed a deal that would permit increased oil production by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and some other nations to help offset losses arising from the Middle East crisis. However, the OPEC officials they would wait until Wednesday to hold a meeting for giving formal approval to the temporary lifting of the cartel's supply quotas.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Begins Nationwide Distribution of Home Computer Line
DOC.TEXT: IBM said Tuesday its 2-month-old line of home computers will be available nationwide starting next month. The computer company also announced new accessories for the machines. International Business Machines Corp. launched the Personal System-1 line in June in three metropolitan areas: Chicago, Dallas-Fort Worth and Minneapolis-St. Paul. IBM said it will promote the nationwide rollout with a television and magazine advertising campaign. The computers will be sold at more than 800 Sears Brand Central stores, 32 Dayton-Hudson and 62 Dillard's department stores, as well as IBM authorized dealers. Selling its products at general retailers represents a strategy change for the world's largest computer company, which previously only sold its machines at computer stores. James A. Cannavino, an IBM's vice president in charge of the home computer line, said the two-month kickoff in the three metropolitan areas ``exceeded our expectations.'' However, IBM did not disclose sales figures. IBM said in a news release that the PS-1 machines are finding a broader audience than expected among both advanced and first-time computer users. Also, buyers have shown greater-than-expected preference for the top-of-the-line PS-1 model, which has a list price of $1,999. Eight out of 10 buyers so far chose that model, which includes a color screen and a hard disc drive, a type of memory device with a large capacity, IBM said. Among the accessories IBM announced for the computers is a printer that it says offers letter-quality printing and four typefaces for $499. IBM also announced a device that allows users to hook up an electronic keyboard to the computers. IBM says the device will allow uses to compose music much the way they work with words on the machines. IBM said the PS-1 line also will be available in Canada and Europe in September. This is IBM's second attempt at a home computer. Its first, the PCjr, failed to catch on and IBM halted production of the machines about a year and a half after their introduction in 1983.

Prices fluctuated on Wall Street today as wary traders shied away from making any major commitments in a nervous market. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 11.13 to 2,600.50 as of noon EDT after having changed direction several times. But the broader market was moderately higher. Advancing issues were ahead of decliners by a margin of about 10 to 7, with 791 stocks rising, 569 falling and 478 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to a relatively light 63.16 million shares at midday. After an early wave of profit-taking, the market traded in a narrow range. Analysts said Wall Street did not have enough momentum to carry the gains of the previous two sessions _ in which the Dow Jones average surged more than 128 points _ into another day. ``Players don't want to commit in either direction,'' said Dennis Jarrett, an analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co. Traders continued to watch the Middle East closely for any developments that could sway the market. Oil prices, which plunged on Monday, regained some ground today and that helped keep the stock market in check. The near-term price for light, sweet crude was up 64 cents a barrel today after falling $4 Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Northeast Utilities was the most actively traded issue on the NYSE, rising \ to 18{. Among blue chip issues, Philip Morris was down [ at 44|, AT&T was off } at 32], and Boeing was down | at 47}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.17 to 176.01. On the American Stock exchange, the market value index was up 1.10 to 321.83.
