DOC.HEAD: Birthplace of Kentucky Fried Chicken Becomes Museum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sunday reference in 2nd graf is Sept. 9
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In 1956, Harland Sanders, threatened with financial ruin by the advent of a new superhighway, left his little restaurant here and took his idea for Kentucky Fried Chicken on the road. On Sunday, the 100th anniversary of the fast-food legend's birth, the owner of that original restaurant is bringing a little bit of Colonel Sanders back home. After almost a decade of planning, one of the colonel's first restaurants has been turned into a museum by John R. Neal, whose company, JRN Inc., owns 87 Kentucky Fried Chicken franchises. It's Neal's way of honoring the white-suited entrepreneur whose home-cooked meals served to hungry travelers at a southeastern Kentucky service station spawned a fast-food empire that now boasts 8,000 outlets in 58 countries. ``It revolutionized fast-food service,'' Neal said. ``And it all started right there in Corbin.'' The museum, which opens Sunday, is housed in the colonel's third restaurant, where he developed both his finger-lickin' good secret recipe and the pressure-cooker method that gave birth to the fast-food era. ``It gives me the opportunity to share . . . the fruits of the effort, the idea of Colonel Sanders and the Kentucky Fried Chicken dream,'' Neal said. ``It's really a very important piece of Americana.'' Built in 1940, the Harland Sanders Cafe and motor court were on old U.S. 25, then one of the main north-south routes across the United States. But plans for Interstate 75 threatened to divert travelers around his restaurant, and Sanders saw the end of his life's work. But Sanders, who at age 65 already had guided his business through the Depression and World War II, had enough confidence in himself and his product to take his idea on the road. He loaded his car with pressure cookers and bags of spices and built his empire, one handshake at a time. Sanders, who died in 1980, obtained the ``colonel'' appellation in the 1930s from Kentucky Gov. Ruby Laffoon, who named him a Kentucky Colonel, a honorary state title, in recognition of his contributions to the state's cuisine. He started franchising his restaurants in 1952. By 1964, when he sold the business to a group of investors that included future Kentucky Gov. John Y. Brown, he had more than 600 franchises in the United States and Canada. The company, which was bought in 1986 by PepsiCo Inc. for $840 million, now has annual sales of about $5 billion. The renovation of the cafe _ the motel now longer stands _ has been two years in the making, and it wasn't easy. Paul Cross, JRN's director of special projects, had to look to Hollywood, Calif., to find companies to reproduce the battleship linoleum used on the cafe's floors and the wheel-etched glass that bore the colonel's name on the front of the building. But the most difficult items to locate were the period appliances for the kitchen: a Vulcan oven and a Hobart dishwasher. After miles of dead ends, Cross finally found the appliances at his old junior high school in Shelbyville, Tenn. Both pieces still were in working order _ the oven's pilot still was lit. ``I feel like I have a guardian angel,'' he said. Cross and his team worked from pictures and postcards of the cafe and from the accounts of townspeople. But they also had some consulting help from the folks who knew the restaurant _ and Sanders _ best: his family. ``They have really gone to every length to get it back like it was in the beginning,'' said Mildred Sanders Ruggles, the younger of Sanders' two daughters and his ``first field representative.'' ``They have certainly done it,'' she said. Other consultants include Sanders' other daughter, Margaret Sanders of West Palm Beach, Fla., and his widow, Claudia Sanders, who lives in Shelbyville, Ky. Visitors to the museum will be able to purchase their food at a state-of-the-art KFC kitchen adjacent to the original building, but they'll eat in the old dining room. Surrounding them will be exhibits illustrating Sanders' life, including such items as the china on which he served his famous home-cooked meals, the certificate of incorporation for his first restaurant, the first photograph taken of him in his white suit, his gold-tipped walking stick, and handwritten recipe cards _ though not the one with his secret recipe. The exhibit also includes an exact reproduction of the model motel room Sanders built near the ladies' restroom to lure families to spend the night. ``We think that's a fairly ingenious marketing strategy,'' Cross said. Mrs. Ruggles is just glad her father's old restaurant is being taken care of the way he would have liked it. ``It wasn't daddy,'' she said of the restaurant before the renovations. ``It didn't have any class. And now they're going back and making it all the way it was. It's something that we as a family will be proud of . . . and my daddy would say, `A job well done.' ''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues PMs, Sept. 4

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Airline Order Tops $500 Million
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese airline company has ordered $580 million in General Electric Co. aircraft engines for 17 airplanes, GE announced Tuesday. All Nippon Airways Co. ordered GE's CF6-80C2 engines for 17 747 airplanes, GE said. With this order, GE is now supplying the engine to 43 All Nippon Airways 747s, GE said. Robert Allan, director of North Pacific sales for GE Airlines, said All Nippon Airways is operating nearly 200 installed engines in its fleet and has almost 300 engines on order. ANA will take delivery of its first 747 later this month, with deliveries for the new order beginning in 1995 and extending until 1999, GE said.

DOC.HEAD: Steinhardt Partners, Others Raise USAir Stake
DOC.TEXT: An investor group including New York money manager Michael H. Steinhardt announced Tuesday it had increased its stake in USAir Group Inc., the parent of the airline USAir, to 9.46 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the investors said that between June 26 and last Friday it had purchased more than 400,000 shares of common stock at prices ranging from $14.07 to $25.83. Previously the investors, which include two limited partnerships, Institutional Partners and Steinhardt Partners, and the corporations SP International and Gamcan Limited had an 8.38 percent stake in the Arlington, Va.-based carrier.

DOC.HEAD: FundAmerica Announces Revised Marketing Plan
DOC.TEXT: FundAmerica Inc., the buying club accused of operating a pyramid scheme, announced a revised marketing plan it hopes will satisfy regulators and allow it to resume business. ``We've modified the marketing plan so that the focus of the program is in selling memberships, rather than buying them,'' said Mitchell G. Blumberg, FundAmerica's new president and chief executive officer. A company statement issued Monday did not provide details on the marketing plan. The plan is intended to discourage the sale and resale of blocks of company memberships by its sales associates, Blumberg said in the statement. Irvine-based FundAmerica has about 100,000 members. Critics say its discounts on goods and services are available free through other channels or are subsidized by its membership fees. In lawsuits, they allege its true business is high-pressure marketing of memberships. Under the new plan, memberships will be available only to buyers who have identified legitimate retail prospects, Blumberg said. ``This is a major step in rebuilding our business,'' he said. ``New management is committed to restructuring FundAmerica and to resuming its operations as soon as practicable, and this is where we must begin.'' FundAmerica filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors on Aug. 17. The company is the subject of a $150 million class action suit in San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Awards Maintenance Facility to Houston
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines today announced it will build its $190 million dollar aircraft maintenance center and a world headquarters complex in Houston. The maintenance facility, to be built at Houston Intercontinental Airport over the next three years, is expected to create up to 4,000 jobs, a $150 million annual payroll and a $600 million economic impact for the city. The headquarters building, to house 4,000 workers, will consolidate Continental offices around the city and result in some employee transfers from operations elsewhere. It would be near the airport on city-owned land. Houston-based Continental said it needs the maintenance complex because of planned acquisitions of new equipment. That facility also will consolidate numerous Continental offices on a 150-acre, campus-style complex. ``Our commitment to this project will help strengthen the economic foundation of Houston and the state of Texas, while continuing Continental's program of growth for the decades to come,'' said Continental Chairman Frank Lorenzo. Houston's Department of Aviation will finance the deal through revenue bonds, which Continental will pay back. Continental will lease the sites from the city. Houston won out over Shreveport, La.; Denver; and three other Texas cities: El Paso, Corpus Christi and Beaumont. Continental has not yet picked a site for a separate engine overhaul facility, to employ up to 1,200 workers. Cities competing for that project include Beaumont, Corpus Christi, Denver, Houston and Shreveport.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar and Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with late European rates and prices plus midday New York quotes.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended higher today against most major currencies in calm European trading as fears of a worsening Mideast conflict receded. Gold failed to sustain a recovery. The precious metal rebounded in early European trading but then fell to finish sharply lower. In late trading in Europe, the dollar was quoted at 1.5525 German marks, up from 1.5423 marks late Monday. The dollar traded at 1.5535 in early afternoon New York trading. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 143.20 yen, down 1.60 yen from Monday's close of 144.80 yen. Later in London, it had crept higher to 143.40 yen. At around midday in New York, the dollar was quoted at 143.475 yen. The British pound was quoted at $1.9470 late in London, cheaper for buyers than $1.9505 late Monday in Europe. Markets were closed in London for a holiday. A pound fetched $1.9415 shortly after midday in New York. Traders said the yen gained against the dollar as oil prices fell. Brent crude for October delivery traded at about $26.30 a barrel late Tuesday in London after trading above $29 for most of the European day Monday. ``The yen-selling factor is dwindling because of the decline in crude oil prices,'' said Masahiro Sahara, a dealer with Industrial Bank of Japan. Other late dollar rates compared with late Monday's levels were: 1.2815 Swiss francs, up from 1.2670; 5.2065 French francs, up from 5.1745; 1.7470 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7365; 1,149.25 Italian lire, up from 1,142.75; and 1.1416 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1335. Selected midday New York dollar rates included: 1.28165 Swiss francs; 1.14265 Canadian dollars; and 1,148.25 Italian lire. Gold in London traded at $383 a troy ounce late Tuesday, as activity resumed after the holiday on Monday. Gold finished in London last Friday at $411.75 an ounce. In Zurich, the late bid was $382 an ounce, down from $401 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong closed at $392.59 per ounce, down $18.36 from Friday's closing price. The Hong Kong market also was closed Monday for a holiday. Silver traded in London late Tuesday at a bid price of $4.85 a troy ounce, down from Friday's $5.14.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Close Higher
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Shares in London lost some of their sharp early gains Tuesday but ended higher on the day following strong rallies overseas the previous day. The market, which was closed for a holiday Monday, reached its highest point in the first half hour of trading. ``We were looking for a new attitude for the market this morning following Tokyo,'' which rose strongly both Monday and Tuesday, said one trader. But caution over events in the Middle East continued to restrict trading activity. Although the market looked better than expected, one trader said the trading level for the day was ``abysmal.'' ``There is simply no supply or demand,'' said another. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 39.7 points, or 1.9 percent, at 2,126.1. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index was up 40.5 points at 1,657.4. The Financial Times 500-share index closed at 1139.95, up 19.49. Volume of 281.6 million shares was down from Friday's 347.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: Pick GM As Target Company In Autoworker Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES erroneous reference to `hourly' in lede; CLARIFIES status of unionized workers in 8th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union today picked the biggest of the Big Three automakers as its target company in contract negotiations covering 450,000 active auto workers. UAW President Owen Bieber said General Motors Corp., which employs 300,000 of the active workers affected by the three national contracts, would be the target company. ``We were here to choose a target company at which we can achieve a pattern agreement for 1990,'' Bieber said. GM said it welcomed the UAW's decision. ``Because it represents the largest segment of the UAW, it seemed appropriate that the company be selected to lead contract negotiations,'' GM said in a written statement. Bieber declined to talk about specifics that led to the selection of GM and refused to talk about strategies the union may pursue with just 18 days left in the current agreement. Talks at Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. will be put on hold while the UAW tries to work out a three-year agreement with GM that then would be used as a pattern for talks at No. 2 Ford and No. 3 Chrysler. National contracts _ which cover about 450,000 hourly workers and several thousand salaried workers _ expire Sept. 14, raising pressure on negotiators to reach an agreement quickly to avoid laying the groundwork for a possible strike. The contracts cover issues common to all unionized autoworkers, such as wages and benefits. Local contracts, many of which are being negotiated now, cover issues such as local work rules and seniority rights. Chief negotiators for each company have said they want to be the national bargaining target because it gives the automaker a chance to negotiate an agreement more tailored to its needs. GM and Ford negotiated their current agreements with the UAW in 1987, when Ford was chosen as a target. Chrysler's current contract was negotiated in 1988. In 1984, GM and Ford were selected as dual targets. In the last week of bargaining, the UAW decided to focus on GM. The union hit GM with a seven-day strike that shut down all of its assembly plants and other factories. Speculation about which company would be the union's target this year has been going on since talks began in mid-July. Observers gave little chance of Chrysler being chosen as the target because of its relatively weak financial condition. In fact, one of the biggest questions is whether Chrysler would remain part of the bargaining pattern the UAW fought to re-establish this year. The last time the three contracts had a common expiration date was 11 years ago. Chrysler broke from the pattern in the early 1980s, when union members accepted concessions to help the strapped automaker survive a near-brush with bankruptcy. This year, Chrysler's chief negotiator, Vice President Anthony St. John, contends that since the company's per-employee labor costs are much higher than GM's or Ford's, it has special needs and may not be able to afford a GM- or Ford-negotiated contract. St. John said simply continuing the current contract provisions for another three years would add 16 percent to Chrysler's labor costs _ an expense the automaker couldn't afford. UAW officials have brushed aside questions about negotiating separately with the target and Chrysler, saying pattern bargaining is here to stay.

DOC.HEAD: Eskimo Pie Introduces Fat-Free Treat
DOC.TEXT: Eskimo Pie Corp. on Tuesday introduced a fat-free dessert that company officials hope will double the firm's share of the frozen novelty market. The Fat Freedom Eskimo Pie Sandwich is the first frozen novelty using Simplesse, a fat substitute made from egg white and milk protein. Simplesse was introduced earlier this year by Monsanto Co.'s NutraSweet subsidiary. It was first introduced in Simple Pleasures, a frozen dairy dessert rolled out earlier this year by Simplesse Co., a division of NutraSweet. David V. Clark, Eskimo Pie president, said he hopes a Fat Freedom line of products eventually will push his company's share of the frozen novelty market from 4 percent to 8 percent. The market segment includes frozen pies, bars and sandwiches. ``Fat Freedom fits in very well with our existing product, and we're trying to offer healthier, good-tasting products to the consumer,'' Clark said. The Fat Freedom Eskimo Pie Sandwich features two fat-free chocolate wafers and a frozen dessert filling made with Simplesse. The product initially will be tested in Illinois, Missouri, Indiana, Iowa, Arkansas and Tennessee. Eskimo Pie is best known for its chocolate-covered vanilla ice cream bar. In 1987, the company developed a sugar-free frozen dairy novelty using NutraSweet. Last year, the company introduced an Eskimo Pie light bar that uses sunflower oil rather than coconut or palm oils.

DOC.HEAD: Fluor Gets Big Contracts in Texas, Chile
DOC.TEXT: Fluor Corp. said Tuesday it won a contract worth more than $200 million to upgrade a Corpus Christi, Texas, oil refinery operated by Valero Refining Co. The Irvine-based construction giant also announced a $50 million contract to engineer and help build and manage a copper ore and molybdenum processing plant 200 mile north of Santiago, Chile. The contract is with Los Pelambres Copper, a Chilean company. Fluor Daniel Inc., Fluor Corp.'s chief subsidiary, is handling both projects.

DOC.HEAD: Layoffs at A.L. Williams
DOC.TEXT: The A.L. Williams Corp., acquired by Primerica Corp. nine months ago, will eliminate about 250 jobs, a company spokesman said. The cuts are part of a restructuring that will affect all levels of the insurance and financial services company, Williams spokesman Mark Supic said. He said the majority of the job losses will come from A.L. Williams Corp. and Massachusetts Indemnity and Life Insurance Co., which together employ about 1,700 people. The restructuring by Primerica already has affected some top Williams officials, including president William Keane, who left the company earlier this month after his position was eliminated. ``These actions are the result of a months-long post-merger review of all Primerica subsidiaries and are expected to improve operating efficiencies,'' Supic said. Primerica completed its acquisition of Williams last November, when it paid $470 million for the company's remaining publicly held stock. Primerica spokeswoman Mary McDermott said the job cuts at Williams are part of an effort to restructure all of the corporation's holdings. The move began in 1988, when Primerica was acquired by Commercial Credit Corp., she said. ``All of our companies have gone through, and are still going through, some restructuring and downsizing,'' Ms. McDermott said.

DOC.HEAD: Fiat Temporarily Lays Off 35,000 Workers
DOC.TEXT: Fiat SPA announced Tuesday it would temporarily lay off 35,000 of its 116,000 factory workers. The layoffs were to address sharper-than-expected declines in European auto sales during the second quarter, said a spokesman for Fiat, Italy's largest industrial group. ``The second quarter has been far below expectations,'' the spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said the layoff plan, which will involve work suspensions ranging from one to three weeks over the next three months, will help reduce excess production capacity that has built up due to the poor growth of the European auto market. The suspensions will begin the week of September 24 and continue through December. Fiat, under the layoff plan, has also frozen hiring of unskilled blue-collar workers and stopped authorizing overtime. The spokesman said Fiat had planned to sell more than 2.4 million units in 1990 based on an average growth rate of 2.2 percent of the European car market during the first quarter. Fiat posted record sales in that quarter, helped by an above-average 5.7 percent growth rate of the Italian car market, he said. But after second-quarter sales figures showed the European market was actually shrinking by 3.6 percent, Fiat had to revise its sales projection to 2.24 million units in 1990, he said. Fiat is also expected to be hurt by the crisis in the Gulf and consequent higher oil prices. ``We will reduce our capacity by some 75,000 units by the end of the year,'' the spokesman said. Under Italian law, companies can suspend workers with pay under adverse market conditions, including an excess of capacity. The workers receive 85 percent of their full salary through a pool of funds to which the company contributes. Fiat's share of the Italian market fell to 54.3 percent in the first semester of 1990 from 58 percent in the first half of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Mixed in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in light trading Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Analysts said traders were taking a wait-and-see attitude after Monday's sharp decline of prices in the grain market. The selloff was tied to the drop in crude oil and precious metals prices. ``There was very little action in the stocks, oil and precious metals, so the grains traded both sides of market,'' said Jerry Zusel, an analyst with Balfour Maclaine Corp. in Chicago. Grain and soybean prices were pushed higher last week on fears of war in the Middle East and fears of inflation in the United States, he said. ``People are watching events in the Middle East,'' Zusel said. ``If we get a new spate of news on a negative note, then grain prices will rise again. Otherwise grains will be on the defensive.'' The latest state crop reports indicate the condition of corn and soybeans has improved because of hot, dry weather conditions. Prices are also being pressured by a lack of export demand. At the close, wheat was a \ cent to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.79} a bushel; corn was a \ cent lower to 2 cents higher with September at $2.54 a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 5 cents lower with September at $1.08{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents lower to 1\ cents higher with September at $6.19{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Carrier President Steps Down
DOC.TEXT: William A. Wilson will step aside Saturday as head of Carrier Corp. amid slumping sales at the world's largest maker of air conditioning and heating equipment. Wilson, 56, will leave his post as president and chief executive officer at Carrier to become senior vice president for commercial-industrial operations at United Technologies Corp. until he retires March 1. Hartford, Conn.-based UTC is Carrier's parent company. UTC spokesman Dan Harrison said Wilson's decision to leave Carrier was voluntary. He will be replaced with Karl J. Krapek, president and chief operating officer of UTC subsidiary Otis Elevator. Wilson became Carrier's president in 1984 and chief executive officer in 1986. His tenure at Carrier was marked by large-scale layoffs, a revamping of the company's product line and a shift in the company's global headquarters from Syracuse to Hartford, Conn. Carrier employed more than 7,000 people at its Syracuse operations in the early 1980s. In mid-July it announced it was closing is 309-employee CC-1 plant by the end of 1991, bringing its workforce to below 3,800. The latest Carrier shuffle took some industry experts by surprise. ``It's kind of a shock,'' said Gordon Duffy, publishing director of Air Conditioning, Heating and Refrigeration News, a trade magazine. ``Wilson was really the driving force at Carrier, and the whole thing is kind of surprising to me,'' he said. Harrison said Carrier's North American sales declined substantially in the second quarter, due to slow housing starts and cool weather, although international sales improved. No quarterly figures were available, but Duffy said sales are down industrywide. Carrier had 1989 sales of $4 billion, up from $3.5 billion the year before. In a move to increase revenues, Carrier on Monday announced a 5 percent to 9 percent price increase on part of its commercial line, effective on equipment shipped after Nov. 14.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Pledges Alexander Shares as Loan Security
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump has pledged his 27.2 percent stake in Alexander's Inc. as collateral for his $65 million financial rescue from casino and bank debt, documents disclosed Tuesday. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Trump revealed that as part of the restructuring of some $2 billion in debt last week, he pledged more than 1.35 million shares in the New York department store chain as security. The three New York banks to which the Alexander's stock was pledged were not identified in the documents. The slumping New York real estate market and disappointing results from his Atlantic City, N.J., casinos put Trump in a cash squeeze earlier this year, endangering his ability to pay his debts on time. On June 15, Trump failed to make a $43 million payment on bonds issued to build the Trump's Castle hotel and casino in Atlantic City. He also was overdue on a $30 million loan payment to a group led by Manufacturer's Hanover Trust Co. But the New Jersey Casino Control Commission approved the bank bailout to help restructure about $2 billion of Trump's $3.2 billion casino and bank debt.

DOC.HEAD: Stiff Sentences in Britain's Biggest Financial Scandal
LaserPhotos LON5-6
DOC.TEXT: A judge came down hard Tuesday on convicts in Britain's biggest white-collar fraud, sentencing the former head of brewing giant Guinness PLC to five years imprisonment and a co-defendant to a record fine. Another defendant collapsed in court as judge Sir Denis Henry was about to pronounce his sentence in the Guinness PLC scandal stemming from the company's multibillion dollar takeover of a Scottish distiller four years ago. Four prominent professionals were convicted Monday on 19 counts of fraud and other charges in the scandal, which revealed the dark side of the takeover craze that swept Britain in the late 1980s. It symbolized an era of greed akin to the insider trading scandal that rocked Wall Street at the same time. Henry said he ordered the stiff punishment for the lead defendant, former Guinness chairman and chief executive officer Ernest Saunders, because of what the judge called his ``dishonesty on a massive scale.'' The judge levied an unprecedented $9.75 million fine against millionaire- businessman codefendant Gerald Ronson, as well as a one year prison term for what the judge described as ``an attack on the integrity of the market.'' Former top stockbroker Anthony Parnes, sentenced to 2 1@2 years' imprisonment, passed out during the proceedings, causing a 90-minute delay while a doctor treated him. Ronson and Parnes also were ordered to pay more than $850,000 each for the costs of the prosecution. Millionaire financier Sir Jack Lyons, 74, convicted with the others Monday, will be sentenced on Sept. 25. The judge freed him on bail so he can undergo surgery. A jury found the four had secretly and illegally rigged the stock market to inflate the price of Guinness shares in 1986. That helped the company successfully battle competitors for control of Distillers Ltd., a whisky and gin manufacturer. The judge said the Guinness case had shown that ``when men are hell-bent on victory, greed is in the saddle and the normal commercial proprieties and respect for the law are cast aside in the rush.'' The mammoth trial at Southwark Crown Court lasted more than 100 days. Henry especially criticized Saunders, 54, for what he called the former executive's dishonesty in allowing the payment of illegal multimillion dollar fees to prop up Guinness' stock price. That helped Guinness win its $5.26 billion takeover battle against supermarket operators Argyll for Distillers. At the time, it was Britain's largest takeover. ``I am quite satisfied, as the jury by their verdicts have shown, that you were at the center of the dishonest conduct that occurred in Guinness at the time of the Distillers takeover,'' the judge told Saunders. Saunders' son James, 24, called the sentence ``appalling'' and ``totally unwarranted'' and said his father would appeal. ``My father has been made a scapegoat. He has lost everything in his entire life,'' he said. Saunders has lost his country home and his job and split with his wife Carole since the scandal broke. Saunders will stand trial again later this year with three other Britons accused of misconduct during the Distillers takeover. British authorities are trying to have American lawyer Thomas Ward extradited from the United States to be tried with them. The fine against Ronson, 51, breaks the record for the highest court fine, previously held by the National Graphical Association union. It was fined $750,000 in 1983 for illegally picketing a newspaper plant. Ronson's lawyer Lord Mishcon said he was ``shocked'' by his client's sentence. ``Obviously Mr. Ronson and the family ... find it difficult to accept because they regard Mr. Ronson as Mr. Ronson regards himself, as having acted honorably and honestly,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Leaders Hope '90s is the Decade for Workers' Issues
DOC.TEXT: American workers wracked by the widening gap between the well-paid and the poorly paid are likely to force labor issues _ particularly health care _ to the forefront in the 1990s, analysts and union leaders predict. ``That middle class that's been stepped on and pushed down to a lower class is starting to resent it and fight back,'' Richard Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers, said in advance of this first Labor Day of the 1990s. ``People will no longer tolerate the fact that they work 40 hours or more a week and don't have health care, that their children don't have health care,'' Trumka said. Jim Green, a labor historian at the University of Massachusetts, said that the coming years would bring ``a lot of anti-corporate sentiment from people who are having a hard time making it. ``I think people are scared and angry about the uncertainty of their lives, about what's happened to the safety net. If we're working harder, why aren't we getting ahead? ``The '80s was a decade of yuppies and BMWs . . . an ostentatious, wasteful display of wealth,'' Green said. ``In the '90s, I think we're going to see a lot of social unrest as people start to realize that there's been a real decline in their quality of life.'' Real earnings _ or wages after adjustment for inflation _ ground to a standstill for many Americans in the 1980s, according to figures provided by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Using 1977 as a base, the median weekly salary in 1980 was $257, but that translated to $190 after adjustment for inflation, the bureau said. This year's figures show that the median weekly salary for the April-June period was $413, but after inflation, it was just $195, giving workers only a minuscule improvement in their purchasing power over 1980, the BLS said. ``That American myth about being able to pull yourself up by your bootstraps _ it doesn't exist anymore,'' said Barbara Otto of 9to5, National Association of Working Women, an advocacy group for secretarial and clerical workers. Another study released this weekend by the Economic Policy Institute, a labor-backed group, found that from 1979 to 1988, the incomes of the wealthiest 5 percent of American families grew 17.6 percent _ five times faster than incomes for the bottom 80 percent. That study also said real wages for the average American worker have declined by almost 10 percent over the past decade and that an additional 5.8 million people were living in poverty, compared with 1979. Barry Bluestone, an economist with the University of Massachusetts, contends that the recent shift to a service sector economy has produced thousands of ``McJobs'' at fast-food chains rather than good-paying jobs. He says workers' standing will worsen if the nation slips into recession soon, as many economists fear. ``The working Joe or Jane did not have much to celebrate during the 1980s ... It seems clear to most economists that the early 1990s will treat the average worker even worse than the '80s,'' Bluestone said. ``I see a continuation of the trends that we saw in the 1980s, the polarization between the well paid and poorly paid.'' Michael Dukakis tried to make a declining middle class a main theme of his 1988 presidential bid. But voters overwhelmingly rejected the Democrat's argument, instead favoring Republican claims that the longest peacetime expansion in the nation's history had created millions of new jobs in the 1980s and given Americans unprecedented prosperity. Union leaders are hoping that workers' growing dissatisfaction will help revive the labor movement, which suffered a series of blows in recent years. Membership has dropped: the 17 million Americans who belonged to unions last year made up just 16.4 percent of the work force, down from the 18 percent they accounted for in 1985. In addition, labor's ultimate weapon _ the strike _ has lost a bit of its firepower because more and more companies feel emboldened to hire permanent replacement workers. Union leaders pin the start of that trend on former President Reagan's firing of air traffic controllers in 1981. One of labor's immediate priorities is to get Congress to outlaw the practice, used most recently in the Greyhound drivers' strike and against machinists and pilots at Eastern Air Lines. Trumka, noting that the American labor movement originally grew out of social unrest, said unions are counting on a similar movement in the '90s. ``In the '80s, working people's issues were like holding your hand out in the sunlight. It never got burned,'' said the mineworkers' president. ``In the '90s, it's going to be like holding a magnifying glass out in that sunlight and focusing on one spot on that hand.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar turned mixed in domestic trading Tuesday after finishing mostly higher overseas, but much of the day's activity centered on other currencies. Gold prices pulled back again after plunging more than $25 an ounce in the previous session. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $385.00 a troy ounce, down $3.30 from Monday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold at $384.50 an ounce, down $4.50. Trading was relatively quiet as fears of a worsening Middle East conflict receded. ``Nothing has happened (in the Persian Gulf) so far, so the market is beginning to think it is less of a concern,'' said Linda McLaughlin, a trader at Chemical New York Capital Markets Group. ``The market is quite comfortable not to worry.'' Much of the day's activity centered on the Japanese yen, which declined on profit-taking after a sharp runup in recent days. Many other dealers were focused on the Swiss franc, which also lost ground. ``Comments from the Swiss National Bank last week that the franc has appreciated too fast and too far continued to weigh on the Swiss franc,'' said Bill Jansen, a trader with Discount Corp. He summed up the session by saying it was ``a day concentrated on cross trading.'' Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 143.20 yen, down 1.60 yen from Monday's close of 144.80 yen. Later in London, it had crept higher to 143.40 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 143.75 yen, down from 144.20 yen on Monday. The British pound was quoted at $1.9470 late in London, cheaper for buyers than $1.9505 late Monday in Europe. Markets were closed Monday in London for a holiday. In New York it cost $1.9429 to buy one pound, less expensive than Monday's $1.9434. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates included: 1.5560 German marks, up from 1.5505; 1.2860 Swiss francs, up from 1.2735; 5.2175 French francs, up from 5.2010; 1,149.25 Italian lire, down from 1,149.50; and 1.1416 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1432. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's rates included: 1.5525 German marks, up from 1.5423; 1.2815 Swiss francs, up from 1.2670; 5.2065 French francs, up from 5.1745; 1.7470 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7365; 1,149.25 Italian lire, up from 1,142.75; and 1.1416 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1335. Gold in London traded at $383 a troy ounce late Tuesday as activity resumed after the Monday holiday. Gold finished in London last Friday at $411.75 an ounce. In Zurich the late bid was $382 an ounce, down from $401 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong closed at $392.59 per ounce, down $18.36 from Friday's close. The Hong Kong market also was closed Monday for a holiday. Silver prices also declined. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.840 a troy ounce, down from $4.848 on Monday. In London the metal fetched a bid $4.85 a troy ounce, down from Friday's $5.14.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices Rebound Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures on Tuesday regained some of the huge losses that occurred in the previous day's trading, but analysts said trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange was confused due to a lack of news in the Persian Gulf. On other markets, precious metal futures were off; grain and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and pork futures fell. ``Today's market was a function of yesterday's market,'' said Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D. & F. Man International Futures Inc. ``We bounced up, but there was not any particular news to account for the rally.'' Crude oil futures prices had their sharpest one-day decline in history on Monday, due to expectations the Middle East crisis would be resolved diplomatically. ``We ended higher, yet a lot of the news is bearish,'' said an analyst who asked not to be named. ``I thought we would see more what we saw yesterday.'' While the price of spot crude was higher, prices for later contracts were lower. Traders said the losses in the later months were a correction of the distortion that developed Monday as trading limits prevented those contracts from falling as steeply as the prices for current delivery. Light sweet settled 66 cents lower to 99 cents higher with the contract for delivery in October at $27.88 a barrel; heating oil was 1.79 cents to 4.43 cents lower with September at 79.52 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 6 cents lower to .97 cent higher with September at 88.53 cents a gallon. On the New York Commodity Exchange, precious metals continued the selloff that began Monday. ``Precious metals remain totally dependent on what goes on in Iraq and on the crude oil market,'' said William O'Neill, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Futures Inc. in New York. ``No other factors are having an impact on prices.'' O'Neill said producer selling is the primary reason for the overall weakness of precious metals. He said the price levels reached by gold and silver in recent weeks have been the best in a long time. ``The producers _ Australia, South Africa and the Soviet Union _ took advantage of that and dried up speculative interest,'' O'Neill said. Gold was $3.30 to $4.10 lower with August at $385 a troy ounce; silver was .80 cent to 3 cents lower with August at $4.840 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean prices were pushed higher last week on fears of war in the Middle East and fears of inflation in the United States, he said. ``People are watching events in the Middle East,'' Zusel said. ``If we get a new spate of news on a negative note, then grain prices will rise again. Otherwise grains will be on the defensive.'' The latest state crop reports indicate the condition of corn and soybeans has improved because of hot, dry weather conditions. Prices are also being pressured by a lack of export demand. Livestock and pork futures were lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as profit-taking set in after Monday's price climb. DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Edge Higher in Light, Cautious Trading

The market shook off an early wave of profit-taking and then became locked in a narrow trading range for the rest of the day. Analysts said the fluctuations and the relative lack of volume showed the market was very cautious, and that traders were reluctant to make major commitments while the situation in the Middle East remains uncertain. Oil prices, which helped spark Monday's big rally, kept the market in check Tuesday. The near-term price for light, sweet crude rose 97 cents to $27.88 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. A $4 plunge in oil prices on Monday had helped boost stock prices. Jack Barbanel, a stock market analyst with First Global Management Inc., said Tuesday's trading ``tells me we have to be very suspect'' about Monday's big rally. ``They really pushed it to the limit, but there's no follow-though today,'' he said. DOC.HEAD: United to Comply with Judge Ruling
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines promised to comply with a federal judge's order to make changes in schedules at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. American Airlines went to court Monday to press for the changes, contending United's proposed schedule was misleading. U.S. District Judge John McBride ordered the change the same day. The Fort Worth-based carrier said United schedules starting Oct. 1 reflect not-yet approved deviations from federal guidelines on takeoffs and landings at O'Hare. The rules are high-density slot rules, intended to regulate traffic at four of the nation's busiest airports by designating times for takeoffs and landings. ``United will comply with the court's order and we expect the FAA on Friday to approve formally our schedule, which we carefully designed to reduce congestion and delay at O'Hare,'' United said in a statement. McBride has scheduled a hearing for Sept. 4 to decide whether to issue a preliminary injunction that would bar United from operating under the new flight schedules, American spokesman Ed Stewart said. Earlier this year, United resumed its position as the nation's largest carrier, replacing American.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of Money-Losing Ameritrust Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Ameritrust Corp., which has lost more than $33 million in the first half of this year, has resigned, the bank holding company said Tuesday. Jerry V. Jarrett will be replaced as chairman on an interim basis by Craig R. Smith, 65, an Ameritrust director since 1980 who is a former chairman of Warner & Swasey Co. James D. Rode, 42, president of both the holding company and the bank, was named chief operating officer of the holding company and chairman and chief executive officer of its principal banking subsidiary. Jarrett also resigned as a director of both the corporation and the bank, which lost $51.6 million in the first three months of this year after a regulatory examination led to a special $120 million addition to its reserve against possible loan losses. The corporation lost $33.2 million in the first half of the year and laid off 780 people Aug. 16. Analysts have criticized the company for not being careful enough in making risky loans. Ameritrust and its subsidiary banks have more than 200 banking offices in Ohio and Indiana.

DOC.HEAD: Nabisco Introduces Fat-Free Cracker
DOC.TEXT: Nabisco Brands Inc. announced Tuesday it will begin marketing a fat-free cracker next month. The Fat Free Premium crackers will be on store shelves by Sept. 10 with a price tag of $1.79 for a 15-ounce package, said Ann Smith, spokeswoman for the company, which is a division of RJR Nabisco Inc. The label on the cracker says it has zero grams of fat per half cup, or five crackers, compared to the original Premium cracker, which has two grams of fat for the same quantity. Smith said the previous fat level ``is a fairly high amount especially since people rarely eat crackers alone.'' The company began developing the new crackers about two years ago as many consumers began to lower fat and cholesterol intake and as other companies introduced fat-free cakes, yogurts and other products, Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Resolution Trust Corp.'s Overriding Power
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on Tuesday ruled that the government's Resolution Trust Corp. can override Arkansas bank branching laws in approving the sale of a failed savings and loan. The 2-1 ruling by the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned a lower court ruling that said the sale of Federal Independence Savings to Worthen Bank and Trust Co. would violate Arkansas state law. At issue is an RTC regulation that permits banks making emergency acquisitions of insolvent thrifts such as Independence to operate the branches of the thrift as bank branches. Independence has 20 branches in 15 counties. U.S. District Judge Stephen M. Reasoner of Little Rock, Ark., had ruled that the RTC's proposed sale to Worthen would violate Arkansas' bank branching law, which limits banks to branches within their home counties. The RTC argued that it was granted broad rule-making authority by Congress in its mission to maximize the returns and minimize the losses in resolving failed thrifts. ``We consider today's ruling to be a significant victory for the taxpayers of the United States,'' Worthen President and Chairman Curt Bradbury said in a statement. He said the bank believes acquiring Independence will be a ``beneficial stabilizing force for the financial-services segment of our economy.'' RTC attorney Dorothy Nichols said the case had national implications because 26 states have similar laws. The RTC's authority has been challenged in New Mexico and Colorado, RTC spokesman Steve Katsanos said. He said a district court judge in New Mexico sided with the RTC earlier this year. In Colorado, a hearing on the case is scheduled for Sept. 5, Katsanos said. The District Court has issued a restraining order to keep the RTC from going ahead with any transaction that would involve overriding Colorado state law. In the Independence case, Arkansas State Bank Commissioner Bill J. Ford and the Arkansas Independent Bankers Association had filed suit June 28 to block the proposed sale to Worthen. In arguments before the appellate court, the RTC's Nichols argued that most of Independence's branch offices would be shut down by the RTC if the institution was sold piecemeal. ``The most valuable assets of S&Ls in dire straits aren't their loan portfolios,'' she said. ``The most valuable asset of a failed thrift is its branches.'' Ford argued that the state's 1988 branching law, which would permit statewide branches gradually over 10 years, was necessary to ensure fair competition. Tuesday's opinion was written by Circuit Judge John R. Gibson for Circuit Judge Frank J. Magill. Senior Circuit Judge Gerald W. Heaney dissented, agreeing with Arkansas officials that the RTC's regulation referred only to the ability of the savings associations to operate branches and not to the ability of a bank to retain and operate branches.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Water Not Naturally Carbonated Under EC Rules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT to third label change; INSERTS 5 grafs after 4th pvs, `A dirty...' to ADD background on U.S. labeling changes. PICKS UP 5th graf pvs, `The latest...' EDITS to conform; Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Source Perrier will replace the label on its sparkling water in Europe because it doesn't meet European Community criteria for naturally carbonated water, officials said. The label that describes Perrier as ``Naturally Carbonated'' will be replaced in Europe Nov. 1 with one reading ``Natural Mineral Water Fortified With Gas From The Spring.'' This marks the third label change in six months for Perrier. Earlier this year, traces of benzene were discovered in some bottles, leading to a worldwide recall of 160 million bottles. Labels for bottles produced after the recall carried the words ``New Production'' to distinguish them from the earlier vintage. A dirty filter on a gas line caused the benzene contamination. Then in April, Source Perrier and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration agreed that the word ``naturally'' would be dropped from the label reading ``Perrier Naturally Sparkling Mineral Water.'' British Deputy Food Minister David Maclean praised the change in Europe as a victory for European consumers. ``Similar changes in labeling had already been agreed for the U.S. market and it is right that U.K. consumers should also have the same treatment,'' Maclean said. The U.S. changes will occur in late October, said Jane Lazgin, spokeswoman for Perrier Group of America Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., the company's U.S. distributor. In Europe, Perrier will exhaust its stock of old labels before switching to the new ones this fall. The latest labeling change developed after the British government filed a complaint with the EC's executive commission alleging Perrier's labeling violated EC regulations and misled consumers. The dispute arose from the way Perrier produces 1 billion bottles of water a year, said British officials and Peter Thomas, Perrier's international marketing director. Carbon dioxide gas occurs naturally at the Perrier spring at Vergeze in southern France. Perrier normally separates the water from the gas underground and pipes them separately to the bottling plant. They are remixed during the bottling process. Thomas said that Perrier adds additional gas to the water by drilling deeper into the spring and tapping pockets of natural carbon dioxide. That gas forms perhaps a little under half of the carbon dioxide bubbles in a bottle of Perrier, Thomas estimated. ``It is a naturally sparkling mineral water,'' Thomas said. ``We also reinforce that with gas from deeper in the spring.'' But the EC's Natural Mineral Waters Directive states that the term ``naturally carbonated'' applies only to waters containing the same gas they had in the spring. If other gas from the spring is added, the water comes under the ``fortified'' heading. Perrier voluntarily agreed to change the label after agreeing with the EC commission and the French government that the new billing would better describe the product, Thomas said. The Nov. 1 change affects the 12-nation European Community, about 60 percent of Perrier's market, Thomas said, adding that other nations may request similar treatment. Perrier's sales and prestige fell sharply after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration discovered benzene in some samples in February. The U.S. ordered a recall and Perrier voluntarily extended it around the world a week later when benzene-laden bottles turned up in other countries. The company, which stakes its reputation on the purity of its bottled water, quickly regained the lost sales this spring. Sales are at 75 percent of their level last winter, Thomas said, while in France, Perrier sold more bottles in July this year than in July 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Eastman Kodak Sued by Spinal Disease Sufferers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pharmacal in 4th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Victims of a debilitating spinal nerve disease sued Eastman Kodak Co. and four other companies Tuesday over a dye used for diagnostic purposes, the attorney for the class action said. The 25 plaintiffs, who live in 18 states, allege they were not adequately informed of the dangers of Pantopaque, a dye injected into the spinal membrane for diagnostic purposes. Eastman Kodak is the principal manufacturer of iophendylate, the sole active ingredient in Pantopaque. Also named in the lawsuit are Alcon Pharmaceutical Laboratories Inc. of Fort Worth, Texas; Alcon Puerto Rico Inc. in Humacao, Puerto Rico; Lafayette Pharmaceutical Inc. of Fort Worth; and Lafayette Pharmacal Inc., which operated in Indianapolis but has since been acquired by Alcon. The four firms assisted Rochester, N.Y.-based Kodak in manufacturing, marketing and distributing the dye, which has been on the market since the 1950s, according to the lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Newark. The lawsuit said the plaintiffs had the substance injected into their spine at least once to diagnose back or spinal injuries. They blame the dye for causing arachnoiditis, an inflammation of the arachnoid membrane that envelopes the brain and spinal cord. Victims of arachnoiditis suffer from ailments ranging from chronic pain to quadriplegia to death, said Gary Meyers, the plaintiffs' attorney. The plaintiffs live in Alabama, Arizona, California, Florida, Illinois, Iowa, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Missouri, Nebraska, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Utah and Wisconsin. The lawsuit was filed in New Jersey because Eastman Kodak is incorporated there.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Hands Over Financial Disclosure to Regulators
DOC.TEXT: Arizona businessman Charles Keating Jr., a key figure in the savings and loan debacle, gave financial disclosure statements to the government Tuesday, a day past a federal judge's deadline. ``We were preparing a contempt case against him when the paperwork was filed,'' said Thomas P. Mason Jr., a spokesman for the Office of Thrift Supervision. Keating says he is broke. The OTS had ordered Keating to prove it and partially froze his assets in connection with its efforts to recover $41 million from Keating and five associates. That effort stems from the failure of Irvine-based Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which Keating controlled and has been accused of looting. Regulators have estimated the collapse may cost taxpayers $2 billion, contending with Miami's CenTrust Bank as the nation's costliest failure. The OTS got a court order enforcing its administrative action from U.S. District Judge Stephen V. Wilson in Los Angeles last week. The deadline for disclosure was Monday. Keating also has been ordered not to send any money out of the country and to give 48 hours notice before spending more than $5,000. Keating earned huge salaries, lived lavishly, and contributed heavily to politicians while he headed American Continental Corp., a Phoenix development company that owned Lincoln. He contends he never broke any laws and that government officials are making him a scapegoat to conceal their own failure to prevent the S&L disaster. However, Keating suffered a significant defeat last week in Washington, where he was trying to make that case. U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin dismissed his lawsuit to recover control of Lincoln, saying actions by Keating and his cohorts ``amounted to a looting of Lincoln.'' After the ruling, he resigned as chairman and chief executive of American Continental, which is in bankruptcy proceedings. The thrift office and lawyers for Keating are due back in Wilson's court in Los Angeles on Monday. The judge has indicated he is likely to extend his orders against Keating, which initially were made in the form of a 10-day temporary restraining order. The financial disclosure statement will not be made public. Carolyn Lieberman, senior counsel for the thrift office, said last week that regulators want to know if Keating transferred money out of the country because he had traveled extensively in Switzerland and the Bahamas in the last few years. Keating says he has never transferred funds overseas.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Inn in Las Vegas Put Up for Sale
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire Kirk Kerkorian put the Desert Inn and Casino up for sale Tuesday, hoping to raise $200 million or more to help finance a planned theme park and 5,000-room hotel on the Las Vegas strip. In a statement, Kerkorian associate Fred Benninger said developing the theme park project had reduced time to devote to the Desert Inn, Howard Hughes' onetime flagship and one of the oldest resorts in Las Vegas. Small by Las Vegas standards with 821 rooms, the Desert Inn has found a successful niche catering to high-rollers from Asia. It unofficially had been on the market for some time, analysts said. The 185-acre site has a championship golf course, 34 undeveloped acres on the strip and another five acres on which luxury condominiums could be built. Kerkorian hopes those factors will help sell the Desert Inn, which is coming onto the market at a tough time. Junk bond and bank financing for deals has dried up, and huge new resorts have sliced away profits at older hotels. ``I think the buyer ... will be someone with vision and an interest in fully developing the property,'' said Michael Tennenbaum, a vice chairman at Bear, Stearns & Co., the investment banking firm retained to handle the sale. Tennenbaum said the Desert Inn's well-known name might be used at a chain of hotels. He said the price ``could be in excess of $200 million'' if the right buyer can be found. Bear Stearns is looking worldwide. ``There are a couple of very famous Pacific Rim clients who go there, and we suspect the Pacific Rim buyers are the most likely,'' he said. Kerkorian owns the Desert Inn through his Los Angeles-based MGM Grand Inc., which also operates a luxury airline. MGM Grand announced last October it planned to lure families to Las Vegas by building a movie theme park and huge hotel on the site where the Tropicana Country Club and Marina Hotel now stand. Kerkorian is in the process of trying to sell MGM-UA Communications Co. to Pathe Communications Corp. Pathe's chief, Giancarlo Parretti, has agreed to pay $1.3 billion for MGM-UA, but has yet to arrange financing. Kerkorian paid $167 million for both the Sands hotel-casino and the Desert Inn when he bought them from Summa Corp. in September 1987. He sold the Sands in April 1988 for $110 million to Massachusetts-based Interface Group. Business at some Las Vegas resorts has been sagging since last November, when the 3,100-room Mirage resort opened to record gaming revenues. Gaming figures are not broken down by the Nevada Gaming Control Board. But other resorts, including Caesars Palace, acknowledged in recent months that the Mirage has hurt their earnings. The 4,000-room Excalibur, billed as the world's largest resort, opened in June to big crowds. However, it is aimed primarily at the middle America market and does attract the type of players the Desert Inn does. Other hotels have in the past year either announced or embarked on expansions or remodeling projects in an effort to keep their share of business, although overall gaming revenues for the Las Vegas area are at record highs.
